HEADLINE: Army Corps May Give Up Fire Island Plan

BYLINE: By JOHN RATHER 

 BODY:
SAYING New York had become "strangely silent" about a $52 million interim project to rebuild beaches and dunes in populated areas of Fire Island, a senior official of the United States Army Corps of Engineers said last week that the corps may soon drop the plan.
The official, Joseph R. Vietri, the deputy chief of planning for the New York regional office, said the corps had written to Governor George E. Pataki last week to make what he described as a final plea that the state take a position on whether the project should go forward. 
 "If we do not get a letter of support, we will terminate all work on the project, and we are very close to being at that point now," Mr. Vietri said. He added that he was "not optimistic" a letter of support would be received.
The project would involve pumping 7.47 million cubic yards of offshore sand -- an amount that would fill 830,000 cement trucks -- onto sections of Fire Island near or in summer communities.
It would be the most extensive and expensive such undertaking on the Island since the closing of a half-mile breach in the residential area of the Westhampton barrier island in the mid-1990's. That event, calamitous by homeowners' standards, was attributed to oceanfront groins that the corps erected in the 1960's and 70's.
Mr. Vietri said that four months after the close of public comment on the environmental study for the Fire Island project, the corps had still not received state position papers or a financial commitment. New York's share of the cost is to be 30 to 35 percent; the federal government would pay 65 to 70 percent. A portion of the state's share, probably more than $5 million, would be paid by local governments.
A spokesman for Mr. Pataki, Michael F. McKeon, declined to say whether the state still supported the project.
Albany's apparent reluctance to back the project, which state officials had initially asked the corps to design and carry out, seems to signal a distinct waning of political backing for a publicly financed program that could be construed as primarily benefiting private land owners.
Gerard Stoddard, president of the Fire Island Association, which represents property owners, has said in the past that Fire Island communities would pay up to half the local share. But costs would still be borne by other taxpayers.
The Fire Island property owners argue that 100,000 residents of mainland areas of the South Shore would be the primary beneficiaries of rebuilding Fire Island because the project would reduce coastal flooding. The corps's environmental study said 80 percent of the benefits would be to reduce mainland flooding.
Mr. Stoddard said the state's inaction reflected a struggle between the Department of Environmental Conservation, which favors erosion control, and the Department of State, which prefers a policy of retreat from oceanfront areas.
"What you see here is the State of New York playing Russian roulette with the South Shore in order to effect a philosophic change in the way we manage the coast," he said.
But environmental groups and others say such benefits will not occur. The Department of the Interior, the parent agency of the National Park Service, which operates the Fire Island National Seashore, has also filed strongly negative comments.
The department, which forbade the dumping of sand in large areas of the national seashore, said the corps's environmental study failed to justify the need for the project. It said shoreline stabilization would reduce breaches that are in fact beneficial to marine habitats.
Among its 10 objections, the department also said the study failed to comply with federal environmental law by ignoring reasonable alternatives, like preventing further development on Fire Island.
"It doesn't address a lot of the concerns and issues we have in protecting a national park," said Constantine Dillon, park superintendent of the national seashore. "Our position has been that the beach was never in danger, it just moves. And generally speaking, the best approach to shoreline management is to allow natural processes to occur."
New York State and the Interior Department must approve the interim project before work can begin.
The Fire Island project could be a precursor to a far larger restoration project for 81 miles of the South Shore, from Fire Island Inlet to Montauk Point. That project, first proposed nearly 40 years ago to protect the mainland from hurricane surges, among other objectives, is the subject of a corps study due in 2003.
Earlier this month, in another sign that prospects are dimming, Senator Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York, toured the South Shore by helicopter with Mr. Vietri and other Army officials but refrained from commenting. Instead, Mr. Schumer backed the longer-range approach, saying erosion "clearly begs for a comprehensive solution that addresses the coastline as a whole, rather than in a piecemeal fashion."
Staff workers for Representative Rick A. Lazio, the Republican from Brightwaters, who owns a house on Fire Island, told a delegation from Ocean Beach before his nomination to run for the Senate that he had reservations about the interim project.
"He has backed away from it," said Natalie K. Rogers, the mayor of Ocean Beach. "They are concerned about people rebuilding." Such rebuilding could occur in places where houses destroyed or damaged by storms and erosion were rebuilt.
Mrs. Rogers, who called those fears unfounded, said village residents were imploring Governor Pataki to stand behind what she said were his promises to help Fire Island.
"It's time for him to step up to the plate," said Mrs. Rogers, who is also a member of the Fire Island Association. "The Army corps has worked like heck and done a very splendid job, and I think they are totally disgusted and discouraged."
But opponents said the corps's withdrawal from the interim plan would be welcomed.
The Environmental Defense Fund, the Nature Conservancy, the National Audubon Society and other groups have repeatedly attacked the interim plan as ill-conceived, environmentally damaging and likely to foster private development in newly protected oceanfront areas at public expense.
"The interim project as currently designed would encourage development and redevelopment in state-designated coastal erosion hazard areas," said James T. B. Tripp, the general counsel of the Environmental Defense Fund. "It makes absolutely no sense for the state and federal government to spend tens of millions of dollars on a project that would have that effect."
Some of the most pointed criticism has come Stephen P. Leatherman, director of the Laboratory for Coastal Research at Florida International University.
Dr. Leatherman, who has studied the South Shore, said the argument that the interim project would protect the mainland was fallacious. To say that beach nourishment on Fire Island would prevent flooding on the mainland is "clearly a stretch," he said.
"It's like building a dam with two gaping holes in it," he said, referring to the Fire Island Inlet and the Moriches Inlet, which bracket Fire Island.
In comments to the corps in February, Dr. Leatherman derided its assertion that the prevention of mainland flooding accounted for more than 80 percent of the benefits and thus justified the project.
"This is the first time I have ever seen the U.S. Corps of Engineers or any other agency try to base beach erosion abatement for an offshore barrier island on mainland flood protection," he said. "This is a novel and possibly precedent-setting approach of trying to show economic benefits and public good outside the project area in order to protect private real estate vulnerable to gradual, long-term and storm-induced beach erosion."
Mrs. Rogers said politicians were being cowed by the environmental groups. "They are all concerned about offending the conservationists," she said.
She called for the governor to reaffirm state support for the project. "The state, by it's silence, is killing it," she said.
Dr. Leatherman took another view: "These communities do everything they can to keep the public out, and now they have this huge spin project to benefit the private property owners at the cost of government. That's not going to wash."

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: 513 Acres Are Bought in Putnam County;
State Adds To Parkland

 BODY:
A 513-acre strip of private land -- described by one conservationist as the mouth between the western jaws of Clarence Fahnestock State Park in Putnam County -- has been purchased by New York State, providing increased public access to the rocky outcroppings that offer broad views along the Hudson River.
Governor George E. Pataki announced the $2 million purchase on June 6. The funds are to come from the state's Clean Water/Clean Air Bond Act. 
 "It is hilly, forested terrain stretching between Route 301 and Indian Brook Road in Garrison, N.Y.," said Erik Kulleseid, the state director of the Trust for Public Land. The trust, along with another not-for-profit conservation group, the Open Space Institute, arranged the deal between the state and a private family that owned the completely undeveloped property that juts into the 11,000-acre park.
In the early 1990's, plans to build about 50 private homes on the land fell through during the last recession.
"The area we are talking about is the western end of the park," Mr. Kulleseid said. "There are two long extensions, like jaws, and this property will sort of fill in the mouth." Besides the views from the outcroppings above the Hudson, Mr. Kulleseid said, "this is going to create even longer hiking trails through Fahnestock."

HEADLINE: L.I. @ WORK;
Where Startup Execs and Investors Go to Tango

BYLINE: By WARREN STRUGATCH 

 BODY:
THURSDAY morning went O.K. for David Butler at the Long Island Capital Forum. Thursday afternoon, though, was fantastic.
The difference was Alan Patricof, in particular the cautionary tone the legendary venture capitalist took in his keynote comments during lunch. Mr. Patricof, whose list of early-stage investments includes America Online and Home Depot, weighed in on the decline of dot-com fever. 
 The Park Avenue financier didn't quite say the bubble has burst. But he did offer a verbal cold shower to Internet entrepreneurs looking for the kind of investment money they had been used to getting.
"It's all going to be about bandwidth now," declared Mr. Patricof, whose investment portfolio is approximately $7 billion. "It's going to be about delivery. It's going to be about fundamentals."
Mr. Butler's Edgewood-based company, North American Internet Systems, supplies buildings with broadband Internet access -- in other words, bandwidth, delivery and fundamentals. Right after lunch Mr. Butler strode to the podium to tout his company and deliver his pitch for $12 million in investment capital.
"The timing really could not have been better," he said later with a smile. "I have 14 people I'm getting back to next week to set up meetings."
Those contacts were made at the Long Island Capital Forum, an annual event where entrepreneurs meet people with money to finance their dreams. Last year, the forum made more than $50 million worth of connections. For the sixth annual event, held on June 8 in Melville, 22 entrepreneurs paid $400 apiece to make an eight-minute pitch.
If keynote speakers at industry conferences are sometimes faulted for preaching to the choir, pap was not on the menu at the June 8 forum. Mr. Patricof assured his dot-com-studded audience that "we will never see dot-com market valuations this high again. It's history.
"Market valuations stopped representing the fundamentals," he continued, "and we had companies that had no profits, and no prospects for profits, with these extraordinary valuations."
Jeffrey L. Bass, founder and chairman of the event, and a partner at the Garden City accounting firm of Margolin, Winer & Evens, insisted that the dot-com financial train had not completely left the station. Most of the 22 exhibitors were dot-coms.
"Whenever you look at a hot market segment, you see companies that are succeeding and companies that are not," Mr. Bass said. Declining market valuations "really remind us of the importance of fundamentals, like getting good management into place. That's what investors increasingly want to see. And the companies we've selected to present today have that."
Certainly, investors expect entrepreneurs to be able to make a sound business case, something they haven't always done at the forum. In its first several years, ill-prepared entrepreneurs often rambled about obscure features and benefits, at times drowning their messages in technical jargon and amateurish presentations. This year, in contrast, presenters strode on and off the platform with desktop multimedia presentations and, in general, clockwork efficiency, thanks to vigilant forum officials.
"I guess I talked too long, because they herded me from the stage," sighed Daniel Yarosh, a biochemist winding up a pitch for $15 million for his Freeport company, AGI Dermatics.
The more professional presentations were no accident. The speakers had all had been offered presentation coaching by Mr. Bass and his colleagues on the board of the Long Island Venture Capital Group, which sponsors the event.
"This year, they were clearly better prepared for raising money," said Herman Fialkov, the much-admired dean of Long Island venture capitalists, who was among those trolling the event. "It was very professional."
Despite running over his time, Mr. Yarosh hoped that he would connect with a source of much-needed funding.
"It's been so expensive getting a product approved" by the Food and Drug Administration, said the biochemist, who founded AGI in 1985. "We need bridge or mezzanine financing. If we make a single solid financial contact today, we'll consider this event successful. My concern coming in was that the venture capitalists would send their e-commerce analysts and not be prepared to assess" other sectors, such as biotech.
One dot-com fund-seeker, David Bensol, got to deliver his pitch before lunch, at least. On his first day as chief executive of Bethpage-based Zydical.com, Mr. Bensol took the podium and asked for $6.5 million to build up what he described as an "Internet B2B health-care solutions portal" -- in other words, a web site that brings together sellers and buyers of medical products and services.
Afterward Mr. Bensol called the experience the "most terrifying thing" he had ever done. Avoiding the breathless predictions of geometrically expanding market and boundless revenues that accompanied earlier dot-com investment pitches, he instead played up business-to-business applications that are already integrated into today's economy. Mr. Bensol's message became the event's mantra: "Investors want to see experienced, quality management, and we have that."
"We're not looking to burn through millions of dollars in advertising," he said, as thousands of dot-coms have done. "We have a solid brick-and-mortar strategy that will earn investors money."
Pitching her dot-com business after lunch, Marlene Hahitti insisted that anyCloseout.com was not "just another Web site." Positioning her Manhattan-based Internet company as a way for manufacturers to lower the often substantial losses associated with excess inventory, she touted her own industry experience and the presence of former New York City comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman on her board. Her Web site, she emphasized, "currently has over $10 million worth of inventory."
Entrepreneurial fund-seekers were not alone experiencing stress. Financiers, for their part, said their roles were demanding as well, in part because they had to whittle entrepreneurial expectations down to size. "They're aching for last year's overvaluations," said Martin Boorstein, a partner in Walden Capital in Manhattan, nodding appreciatively at Mr. Patricof's lunchtime remarks. "They're still looking for the kind of multiples they got last year. But when they get any kind of funding, they'll be happy."
Manny Ratafia of Woodbridge, Conn., said that events such as the Long Island Capital Forum induced him to travel around the tri-state area in search of deals under a million dollars.
"Many venture capitalists have had so much success raising money that they need to invest larger amounts" to achieve desired payback, he said. They also need payback earlier than most start-ups are prepared to deliver. Consequently, many venture capitalists are turning away from the relatively small investments sought at events such as the Long Island Capital Forum. "That creates opportunity for people like me," said Mr. Ratafia, who specializes in smaller deals.
As the meeting began to wind down, an upbeat David Butler spotted Mr. Patricof ambling about the exhibition hall. He introduced himself and thanked the financier for his remarks on broadband technology.
"I told him what we did, and he seemed amused," Mr. Butler said, "but he didn't ask for a meeting. So it's up to us to give him a call."

HEADLINE: Pataki as Legislator: Less Than a Team Player

BYLINE: By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ 

DATELINE: ALBANY

 BODY:
FOR all his success at rising to the pinnacle of state government, George Elmer Pataki earned a reputation as a defiant outsider through much of his career as a lawmaker here.
Mr. Pataki, who became the first Republican governor in a generation after defeating Mario M. Cuomo, served in the Legislature for 10 years, first in the Assembly for eight years and then in the Senate for two. 
 In 1985, Mr. Pataki joined the Assembly, where members of the Republican minority have little power and are reduced to engaging in empty acts of defiance against the Democratic leaders. As a result, he accomplished little during his four terms.
But he is remembered for finding ways of irritating the chamber's Democratic leadership, most notably his decision in 1990 to stage a highly unusual filibuster to draw attention to the Republicans' stand against higher taxes and spending increases.
Not only was he an outsider in the Legislature, Mr. Pataki did not play a major role in the Westchester delegation.
Richard L. Brodsky, a Democratic assemblyman from the county, said he thinks that Mr. Pataki simply didn't enjoy being a member of the Legislature.
"George always had decent personal relationships with his colleagues," Mr. Brodsky said. "The two of us played basketball together. But I don't think he ever much trusted or liked participating in the legislative process."
Mr. Pataki did earn a good reputation among environmentalists, primarily because of his support for measures to protect water quality and open spaces.
But as a member of the minority, he did not sponsor any major environmental legislation that passed in that chamber.
Mr. Pataki left the Assembly in frustration in 1992, choosing to run for the State Senate.
He defeated the Republican incumbent, Senator Mary B. Goodhue, in a bitter primary, which led leaders in his own party to harbor deep resentment toward him.
As a member of the Republican majority in the Senate, Mr. Pataki is best known for defying the party's leadership to vote against the state budget in 1993 because it called for tax and spending increases.
His stance on such matters laid the foundation for his 1994 campaign against Mr. Cuomo, permitting Mr. Pataki to cast himself as a fiscal conservative who could save the state from an economic tailspin resulting from years of reckless spending.
But he was not exactly the ideological purist he made himself out to be.
When he defied the Republican leaders in the Senate and voted against the state budget in 1993, he said he was doing so because it included the tax and spending increases he so loathed.
But here's what he didn't say: a few weeks earlier, Mr. Pataki had persuaded the Senate leadership to include $500,000 in the budget to help finance pet projects in his district.
The budget passed without Mr. Pataki's support, as was widely expected, and Mr. Pataki, for his part, pointed to the pork it contained as evidence of the good work he had done on behalf of his constituents. RAYMOND HERNANDEZ

HEADLINE: At Last, Strawberries Sweet and Lovely

BYLINE: By NANCY POLK 

DATELINE: CONNECTICUT

 BODY:
Strawberries are bred for their luscious flavor, not for shipping. They are delicate, juicy and perishable unlike their more rugged West Coast counterparts.
"You can throw a California berry at a brick wall and nothing happens," said Sandi Rose, who raises six varieties of strawberries on 10 acres in South Glastonbury. She explained that field-ripened berries have the best flavor because the natural sugars are allowed to develop to their peak. 
 Since the 17th century, when William Butler wrote "Doubtless God could have made a better berry but doubtless God never did," strawberries have been popular.
In 1998, 93.7 percent of American households surveyed reported eating fresh strawberries, according to the federal Department of Agriculture. Connecticut produces a tiny percentage of that. Norman Gaulthier, an associate professor in the Department of Plant Science at the University of Connecticut, said all the strawberry fields in the state total 1,000 acres or less. And those are berries that stay in Connecticut. Even those farms large enough to sell the fruit wholesale sell it to other local farmstands.
In Connecticut, strawberry season is short, generally tapering off by the first week in July, said Rick Macsuga of the State Department of Agriculture.
One strategy farmers use to prolong the season is planting different varieties to offer early, middle and late crops during the season.
John Lyman operates a pick-your-own fruit and farm market complex on 250 acres in Middlefield. He does not believe that most consumers notice the change from one type to another. "To the average person," Mr. Lyman said, "a strawberry is a strawberry, but using different varieties tends to stretch our season."
Donald Dzen runs the largest strawberry farm in the state, in South Windsor. He offers pick-your-own as well as fruit already picked retail and wholesale. With 40 acres under cultivation he knows strawberries well and he thinks the sweetest-tasting berries are not dark red but orange. He favors the variety called All Star, which several other Connecticut growers also offer. Some of the other varieties to be found this year include Kent, Cavendish, Delmarva, Jewel and Winona.
Strawberries, blueberries and raspberries combined contribute about $2.1 million directly to the state's economy, Mr. Macsuga said. (California, the largest strawberry producing state, valued their 1998 crop at $783 million.)
But Connecticut strawberries fulfill another economic function.
Mr. Lyman, who has cultivated the berries for 25 years, said, "Strawberries get the season started." He reports that pickers often load up on strawberries in the field, then go to the store to purchase other produce. And strawberries lure out-of-state visitors to Connecticut. Mrs. Rose said strawberry growers were "in the business of entertainment farming."
The berries also play a significant role in the tourism industry. More and more Connecticut farms are switching to pick-your-own since they find the cost of labor prohibitive. It is grueling stoop labor where harvesters must remain on their hands and knees for the work day. Most of the workers come from Mexico and return to the same farms year after year.
Very few local people are willing to do this kind of work. An exception is Terry Jones's farm. He began raising strawberries in the early 1960's when he was a high school student. Today he employs students who want to learn more about agriculture and the environment. They spend many hours on their hands and knees pulling weeds. Mr. Jones, a sixth-generation farmer, sees farms, and especially pick-your-own operations, as a "tremendous complement to the tourism industry."
Mr. Jones also feels passionate about farmland preservation. He says that when customers come to the farm to buy fruit, vegetables and plants, they are "voting with their consumer dollars to save some precious farm land."
Picking the fruit rather than buying it already picked does save money. The cost to consumers this year will be not much more than it was last year, perhaps 5 or 10 cents a pound more. Mr. Macsuga estimated the cost at $1 to $1.25 a pound to pick your own, and $3 to $4 to buy strawberries by the quart.
An early heat wave followed by below-normal temperature left the strawberries a bit confused, but they have adjusted and the strawberry season had a strong start this year. What could ruin the tender crop would be heavy rain. Last year was a washout for some farmers since heavy rains came in the middle of their season. For others, the rain came at the right time or they irrigated and their crop produced at record levels.
At the Glendale farm in Milford the plants suffered during the drought and they will not offer any strawberries this year.
Strawberry season is very intense for the farmers. George Hindinger, who farms six acres of berries in Hamden, said: "When they are ripe they have to be picked and not left a couple of days like blueberries. They have be picked and they have to be brought to market fast."
When the rush is over his family sells strawberry products such as fresh jam at their farm market.
For those worried about sampling unwashed berries, Mr. Gaulthier offers some reassurance. Connecticut's climate, he said, is mild so pesticides are used minimally and none as harvest time approaches.
Mrs. Rose warns consumers to avoid plastic wrapping and heat. "Use paper towels," she advises and "remember heat is the enemy of strawberries." She explained that modern frost-free refrigerators "zap the moisture out of strawberries so they must stay covered." Visitors go to Rose's Berry Farm for breakfast pancakes with strawberries from 8:30 a.m. to 1 p.m. on Sundays only.
After the strawberry season comes to an end Mrs. Rose serves her pancakes topped with fresh blueberries.

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/New Jersey;
To Compete, Real Estate Companies Join Forces

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
GVA WILLIAMS, a Manhattan-based commercial real estate services company with a national and international reach, wanted a stronger presence just across the Hudson River in New Jersey.
And Associated Realty, a commercial brokerage company in Parsippany, was entrenched in the state but wanted to expand worldwide. 
 Six weeks ago, GVA Williams bought Associated Realty, which has been renamed GVA Williams New Jersey. The move enabled both companies to meet their goals to"better compete in the market and improve services to our clients in the region," said Michael T. Cohen, the president and chief executive of GVA Williams, the parent company.
The new company, which will operate from Associated's current office in Parsippany, will be headed by Eric Witmondt, who founded Associated nine years ago. His title will be chief executive, and David Simson, a former senior vice president in the New Jersey office of CB Richard Ellis, will be the company's president.
The deal reflects the continuing trend of consolidation in the commercial real estate brokerage industry, although at a less frenzied pace than a few years ago. The trend, many industry executives said, better meets the needs of global corporate clients who are demanding national and international management and brokerage capabilities.
Moreover, they add, as corporations farm out the real estate operations they once handled internally, they have also become unwilling to deal with different service providers in multiplying markets.
"After the downsizing and outsourcing by corporations in the late 80's and early 90's, strong brokerage companies became more important," said Stan Kurzweil, the president of the New Jersey chapter of the Society of Industrial and Office Realtors and a vice president in the Somerset office of Colliers Houston & Company, a brokerage company based in Teaneck. Corporations now want "a seamless delivery of service and a single source of contact," he said.
In time, many real estate executives predict, there will be a few large multinational companies that will dominate the market. Though smaller, entrepreneurial companies will survive as niche players, the pressure, they said, will be on larger regional companies to acquire or be acquired.
"The industry is evolving into a two-tier business with three or four or five national and international firms and a lot of local brokerages," said Donald P. Eisen, an executive managing director for the New York area at Cushman & Wakefield, the international real estate services company. "It's all about branding and harnessing resources, putting companies in the middle in a very difficult place to defend."
As a corollary, a very strong office market now exists in the 11 counties of northern and central New Jersey. Brokerage companies of all sizes are seeking to become important players in one of the largest markets in the nation, with 147 million square feet of office space and 724 million square feet of industrial space in the 11 counties. The area is also home to a couple of dozen Fortune 500 companies, many of which are expanding.
"The demand is there, and so are the larger transactions as corporations look for headquarters and full-building deals," said Thomas Giannone, one of two managers in the Edison office of the Julien J. Studley real estate services company. "Everyone is jockeying for these larger, more lucrative deals, which require a higher level of services."
Joining networks is one tactic being embraced by smaller, independent companies, including Alexander Summer L.L.C., the Garibaldi Group and most recently, the Schultz Organization. Generally, networks are confederations of independent companies in different geographic locations that refer business to one another and share the revenue generated. By linking, the companies can offer clients access to affiliates elsewhere in the nation or the world.
EARLIER this month, the Schultz Organization, a full-service commercial real estate company in Woodbridge that focuses on regional and institutional clients in New Jersey, joined TCN Real Estate Services of Dallas, a brokerage network with 58 offices worldwide.
Jonathan Schultz, the president of the 10-broker company, he had resisted being acquired by or merging with a larger company to retain his entrepreneurial edge. "There is a host of regional companies in New Jersey that want the services we provide, so there is still room for firms like us," Mr. Schultz said. "But this is all client-driven, and for our clients that want us to service their needs outside New Jersey, a network affords us a way to do that."
The 15-broker Garibaldi Group in Chatham, whose national clients include Bristol-Myers Squibb and Schering-Plough, is affiliated with Corfac International, a real estate brokerage network with 76 offices worldwide. Its headquarters are in Arlington, Va. "In today's global economy you're expected to have greater depth and reach," said James J. Garibaldi, the company's chief executive. Now, with many clients expanding west into Pennsylvania, he said his company was planning to open an office in Lehigh Valley, Pa.
Big multinational companies like Cushman & Wakefield and Insignia/ESG see the present as a good time to expand in the state.
"New Jersey has a large supply of office space and a diverse geography, but a highly fractured market in terms of service providers that over time will see more consolidation," said Patrick Murphy, the executive director of Insignia/ESG of New Jersey, in Saddle Brook. "Other than Cushman & Wakefield, no one else has an significant market share, so we see opportunities to grow."
He said that within the next two weeks his company planned to open a second office in New Brunswick and was in the process of forming an alliance with Buschman Partners, a Princeton concern with four brokers. Insignia/ESG, a publicly traded company, now has offices in 48 states and in 13 countries. The New Jersey office also has expanded its research and consulting services and by the middle of next year will increase its New Jersey staff to 50 from the current 35, Mr. Murphy said.
Mr. Eisen of Cushman & Wakefield, which has 143 offices in 44 countries, said his company sees "New Jersey as the high growth sector for the metropolitan area and intends to exploit our advantage in the state."
The plan, he said, is to recruit more people and to open a third office in the state, in Iselin, by this summer. The two existing offices now have 50 brokers, and the third office would add 12 to 15 more.
GVA Williams is not a newcomer to the New Jersey market. For the last decade the company has had an alliance with Jacobson, Goldfarb & Tanzman, which has 28 brokers in Woodbridge, but that affiliation has now ended. Stanley Simon, the company's chief executive, said: "We were in it for the New York connection, but the affiliation didn't have a great impact on our prosperity."
Mr. Simon said that he was not sure if his company would join another network. "We will rely on our experience as a dominant player in central New Jersey and expand services, going into retail as well as asset and property management."
Mr. Cohen of GVA Williams said the acquisition of Associated Realty was driven by his company's desire to grow in the New York metropolitan area, countering the popular belief that regional companies will get squeezed out.
The acquisition will offer clients uniform services and technological capabilities, important pluses, he said, since the markets in New York and New Jersey are so intertwined but difficult to achieve in an informal alliance. Since GVA Williams is a founding member of GVA Worldwide, a network of affiliates in 20 countries, the company can also offer one-stop services to clients with national and international requirements.
"Our vision is to expand strategically in this region by buying companies and building partnerships," Mr. Cohen said, noting that with Associated, "we bought a controlling interest and kept the partners on by giving them an equity stack." Mr. Witmondt and Mr. Simson said that they each had equity in the company, but they would not name the percentage.
Future plans include opening a second office in New Jersey, adding to its staff of 14 brokers, and expanding into Westchester, Long Island and Connecticut.
Mr. Witmondt said that by joining GVA Williams, his company gained a global reach "that would have taken us years to cultivate" as well as technological resources "that would have cost us millions of dollars to achieve."
Mr. Cohen conceded that in the race all brokerage companies are running, Williams's approach was conservative. "We are the tortoise, rather than the hare," he said.

HEADLINE: IN BRIEF;
Institute of Technology Promotes Its Provost

BYLINE: By ALLAN RICHTER 

 BODY:
Edward Guiliano, provost and vice president for academic affairs for the past five years at the New York Institute of Technology in Old Westbury, has been appointed president and chief executive.
Dr. Guiliano, 50, replaces Matthew Schure, who is leaving after 30 years to be president of the Philadelphia College of Osteopathic Medicine. 
 Dr. Guiliano, whose appointment is effective this fall, said he hoped to promote the school more visibly than his predecessor did.
The new president, who lives in New York City but was raised in Dix Hills, said he would step up efforts in Manhattan to develop more student internships and fund-raising opportunities. The school has a campus at Lincoln Center, but "we've been much more of a player on Long Island, and I think that has to change," he said.
Dr. Guiliano, who advocates greater use of technology in the classroom, said the school should capitalize on New York's position as a center of the global economy. Through Internet-based distance learning and other measures, he said, he wants to develop more programs with other countries, like the exchange of students and teachers that the school has with China. ALLAN RICHTER

HEADLINE: Nixon and Eisenhower

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Steven R. Weisman (Editorial Observer, June 11) cites as a factor in Richard M. Nixon's narrow loss in the 1960 presidential election his "proud refusal" to ask President Dwight D. Eisenhower to campaign for him.
In fact, Nixon wanted Eisenhower to campaign and would have asked him but for an emotional phone call by Mamie Eisenhower to Pat Nixon, in which Mrs. Eisenhower implored her to persuade Nixon not to ask the president to campaign with the caveat that "Ike must never know I called you." 
 This account from Nixon's papers is confirmed by my mother, Tricia Nixon, who was present when Mrs. Eisenhower called my grandmother to tell her that Eisenhower's heart was not up to the strain of campaigning.
Looking for reasons for Nixon's loss in 1960, Mr. Weisman might search economic history, which shows that Americans lost 800,000 jobs during an economic contraction that started in April 1960 and ended in December 1960 and which had a strong effect on an electorate with fresh memories of the deep 1958 recession.
 
CHRISTOPHER NIXON COX
New York, June 12, 2000

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: EAST SIDE -- BUZZ;
At U.N., Serving Iran's Food To Eager if Ignorant Diners

BYLINE: By DAVID KIRBY 

 BODY:
THE SETTING -- The bustling, steamy kitchen of the United Nations Delegates Dining Room, where a dozen people were taking a behind-the-scenes cooking class, part of a series sponsored by the New School University that brings students to top eating spots. This month, the United Nations is celebrating the food of Iran, so chickpea fritters, savory shish kebabs and Persian baklava swimming in rosewater were all on the menu. It was the first time, according to the United Nations, that the Islamic government of Iran has sponsored any official event outside the country.
THE BUZZ -- "I know Iran has been out of favor for some time, but taste buds are taste buds, and this food is fabulous," said Dick Scanlan, a writer who took the $80 class as a gift "from a friend who's a real foodie." Mr. Scanlan wondered if perhaps Iran, currently liberalizing, had embarked on some "kinder, gentler P.R. campaign" in which fine Persian cuisine is just the opening salvo. 
 "What's next?" he asked. "Commercials with young honeymooners in bikinis running through the streets of Tehran?"
"Yeah, right," said Alan Effron, a lawyer eating flatbread with spinach-yogurt dip. "Iran is for lovers."
The class began with Iranian cocktails, from which alcohol is banned by Islamic law. Juices of pomegranates, oranges and limes were offered, along with a sour yogurt-milk concoction that Lou Piuggi, the United Nations executive chef and teacher for a day, called "an acquired taste." Nobody acquired it.
Then Mr. Piuggi began cooking, with the able assistance of Ata Samii, an Iranian caterer who has lived in New York for more than 30 years.
Iranian cuisine, it turns out, is not so different from other Middle Eastern food, but it has a subtlety derived from ingredients like saffron, walnuts and rosewater. The chicken and beef shish kebabs were infused with herbs and cooked on swordlike skewers. Tarragon and mint were served to cleanse the palate.
"It's wonderful," said Rhonda Fingerman at the sit-down lunch after class, which she took as part of a season of self-imposed unemployment. "This is my summer of food and wine," Ms. Fingerman said. "This is my summer of Rhonda."
Nearby, Rhona Newman ate baklava with her friend Elaine Katz. "To understand food is to understand culture," Ms. Newman said. "We're expanding our horizons."
Ms. Katz said she wanted to have an Iranian dinner party "with belly dancers and everything."
Would that include wearing the traditional chador? "You mean those big black things?" she asked. "Sure. Then I wouldn't even need makeup." DAVID KIRBY

HEADLINE: Eve's Revenge, The Python's Sorrow

BYLINE: By C. J. CHIVERS 

 BODY:
ONCE, snakeskin had the fashion cachet of a prison tattoo. Urban cowboys and rockers wore it. So did creeps. Snakeskin? Think Joey Buttafuoco's signature boots.
What a difference a little marketing makes. Designers satisfied this year's cash-rich consumers by giving a makeover to python, skin taken from Asian snakes laced with primeval, netlike designs. Yves Saint Laurent sold out its line of $9,250 python trench coats. Jimmy Choo offered $550 python slides in traffic-stopping bright green. A pink python jacket from Chanel, with white chiffon trim and matching skirt, retailed at $8,455. It sold out, too. 
 "Python did incredibly well," said Mariah Chase, a Jimmy Choo spokeswoman. "It was all about luxury and exoticism. It was a maximalism kind of thing."
For fashion houses, the metamorphosis of python from ruffian chic to Park Avenue popularity has been an irrefutable hit. But among conservationists, the snake's makeover has been ringing alarms. Does it signal a new round of consumers wearing wildlife products with light-headed nonchalance? If so, which animals will be next? And what about those snakes? In an era of shrinking habitat, are there really enough pythons out there to outfit every acquisitive fashion princess?
Having a python cellphone cover may be unmistakably hip, but it is an image oddly disconnected from the product's origins. A world away from the cubicles where fashion magazine pages are designed, this year's python craze is supplied by an international industry that snatches hundreds of thousands of wild pythons from jungles each year, kills them and ships their skins to European and Asian garment factories, all the while avoiding the notoriety that has dogged other commercial wildlife harvests, from the seal hunters of Newfoundland to the whalers of Japan.
The python hunt is legal, as is the export of the skins. But conservationists say that no one is certain whether the most heavily traded species, reticulated and blood pythons, both agents of rat control in some of the world's poorest nations, can sustain their numbers under the sort of hunting that keeps department stores stocked.
Pythons are creatures virtually without advocates. Many details of their lives are unknown.
"For most of these snakes, there is absolutely no information on what is happening with the hunts or how the species are faring," said Dr. John Thorbjarnarson, a herpetologist with the Wildlife Conservation Society, headquartered at the Bronx Zoo. "That is really a frightening thing." Pythons are nonvenomous tropical predators that strike from hiding and then twist their bodies around their prey, flexing their hold until the animal suffocates. The dead victim is swallowed headfirst. Sated pythons slither off to digest.
Since 1975, trade in these reptiles has been subject to guidelines set by the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Flora and Fauna, or Cites, a wildlife commerce treaty signed by 150 nations, which require each country to establish and supervise a conservation policy. According to the convention, more than 10 million pythons have been reported taken from the wild in the last 15 years.
The snakes are harvested from a long list of nations, including Malaysia, the Philippines and Vietnam. But the unequivocal export leader is Indonesia, where harvesting pythons is a highly organized business. From 1985 to 1998, the last year for which data are available, Indonesia exported more than 4.5 million pythons, either skinned or alive.
"It is a huge industry, but it keeps to itself," said Kamuran Tepedelen, who owns Bushmaster Reptiles, a Boulder, Colo.-based company that employs Indonesian snake catchers for the pet trade.
Spokeswomen for four fashion houses that use python said they had no idea where the skins come from, a response evidently little different from that of consumers. "It's very rare, honestly, that we think about where they come from, and what the ecological impact might be," Ms. Chase of Jimmy Choo said.
The most coveted species in the exotic leather trade is the reticulated python, arguably the largest snake in the world. Reticulated pythons are the anacondas of Asia, having been reported at lengths of more than 30 feet, although 10- to 17-foot snakes are typical. They feed on a variety of vertebrates, including rats, ducks, chickens, porcupines, pigs and monkeys. In rare instances the largest specimens have attacked humans.
Each year from 1985 to 1998, between 305,000 and 834,000 reticulated pythons were reported harvested worldwide; a large portion came from Indonesia. Actual trade is believed to be larger because of smuggling. Much of the rest of the trade is in skins from blood pythons, fat-bodied snakes that reach maximum lengths of about seven feet. Once considered uncommon, blood pythons have benefited in recent years as vast tracts of rain forest have given way to oil palm plantations. These new habitats -- replete with brush piles and palm fruit -- support an extraordinary density of rats.
Experts say the rats' abundance has allowed blood pythons, which feed on them, to colonize the plantations. And as their numbers have increased, the snakes have attracted skin hunters. In 1985, 32,000 blood pythons were exported worldwide. In 1998, reported shipments reached 127,000.
To convert pythons into profits, Indonesia's snake-harvesting industry relies on an army of catchers. Most are villagers who simply encounter a snake and pounce on it, selling it later for serendipitous cash. Others are more systematic and take regular walks through the palm plantations, peering into brush piles and plucking blood pythons from hiding places. A few ambitious hunters work in groups, settings nets, traps and baited hooks for the larger reticulated pythons. Captured snakes are stored in canvas bags and sold to primitive skinning plants. What happens next is unsightly, although industry representatives and scientists say it is no more unsettling than what occurs in meat-packing houses around the world.
The pythons are dumped from their bags and killed by suffocation or mallet blows. The carcasses are hung by their heads and inflated with water. A skinner then slits open the carcass, snips out the guts and scrapes away the meat. Depending on the market, some of the meat ends up being eaten, and some is used as livestock feed or discarded. In some cases python gall bladders are sold for use in traditional Chinese medicine. But the main product is the skin, which is pegged, dried and sent to tanneries. Most tanned skins are exported to Europe, where they are converted into all manner of clothing and accessories.
The industry employs about 174,200 people, including everyone from skinners to international sales agents, according to the Indonesian Reptile and Amphibian Trade Association, which represents licensed tanneries and reptile-product exporters. About 150,000 of the workers are snake catchers, most of them in persistently poor regions. They are paid a small sum for each snake.
"I think the reality is that for these Indonesian villages, the snakes are an important economic resource," said Dr. Richard Shine, a University of Sydney herpetologist who toured Indonesian skinning plants for python studies.
The industry has existed for decades, subject to the capricious moods of the fashion industry and its equally capricious customers. But some conservationists say the skins' recent appearance on the runways is tied as much to the fine points of international trade law as to the vagaries of taste.
Six years ago, the endangered species convention adopted rules requiring tags and permits for crocodilian products shipped across international borders. These rules, which did not affect snakes directly, complicated shipments for products from certain reptiles -- crocodiles, alligators and caimans -- often causing border delays or seizures, a potential catastrophe for retailers expecting seasonal merchandise.
Since python skins are not covered by the tagging rules, they cross borders with comparative ease. Experts say this characteristic made them attractive when designers began seeking exotic leather for consumers flush with cash.
"Snakeskins are not nearly as complicated to import and export," said Craig Hoover, of Traffic-North America, the trade monitoring arm of the World Wildlife Fund. "They just don't run into the same possibilities of delays."
Accordingly, wildlife inspectors say they have noticed a significant increase in the number of snakeskin products entering the United States. "From an industry's standpoint I guess I can understand it," said Sheila Einsweiler, a senior inspector for the Fish and Wildlife Service. "It's a little easier to move snakeskins around."
As more skins entered the country and began to bear brand-name labels, python's sudden popularity invigorated a long-running debate among scientists about the species' sustainability. Herpetologists are particularly worried about reticulated pythons, which do not seem to thrive in plantations, and whose skins bear the netlike pattern most desired by designers.
"Reticulated pythons are giant snakes, remarkable creatures, but they are not adequately protected, and their trade is barely regulated," said Peter Brazaitis, a herpetologist and the former curator of animals at the Central Park Wildlife Center. "Five years from now, if python fashion keeps going, how many of them will be left?"
The answers are not clear. Under endangered species trade rules, exporting countries must base their hunts on scientific studies and limit harvests "to maintain the species throughout its range and at a level consistent with its role in the ecosystem in which it occurs." But little field research has been done on Asian pythons. Wildlife experts say there is almost no way of knowing whether the convention's standards are being met and whether the various species, or their roles in the ecosystem, are being preserved.
Some studies are not encouraging. A 1990 report done for the convention's secretariat noted that for reticulated pythons, "there is reasonable evidence for a significant decline in Bangladesh, and the species is reported to be depleted locally over much of the remainder of the range, including Indonesia, Laos, Malaysia, Myanmar and the Philippines."
But since then, opinions on the hunt's impact have varied. Mr. Tepedelen, of Bushmaster Reptiles, said harvests are sustainable because catchers generally do not kill immature reptiles, meaning most of those killed have already been allowed to lay clutches of eggs and propagate the species.
"The species that are in trade are just booming," he said.
Dr. Shine, the Australian herpetologist and one of the few scientists who have studied the harvest of reticulated pythons, said he has been surprised by the species's resilience. "Reticulated pythons have the life history of a garter snake," he said. "They grow fast, mature quickly and have a lot of eggs in each clutch. As a species, it can withstand a fair bit of pressure."
In spite of these characteristics, the species has declined in some areas. "It's not an issue about extinction, but there is no doubt that the commercial trade is reducing the numbers," Dr. Shine said.
The Indonesian reptile traders' organization has been working with field researchers and the Indonesian government to ensure that the hunt is sustainable. But field biologists caution that sustainable or not, it may have public health consequences. That is because the snakes are being removed from an ecosystem heavily populated with rats.
While harvesting pythons may generate profits locally, some scientists say, they leave behind rats, which carries social costs, including increases in disease and damage to crops. "I think we have to ask ourselves, what is the value of a python?" said Mr. Brazaitis. "Is it as a pair of expensive pants? Or is it as a means to check exploding rat populations in nations where communicable diseases are rampant?"
This month, the knockoff-bag merchants were selling fake python clutches and baguettes on the sidewalks outside Bloomingdale's, a sure sign the snakeskin craze has gone down-market and is nearing its end. And even though python products remained in some display windows throughout the city, a salesman at the Original Leather Store, which operates six boutiques in Manhattan, was pronouncing the snake dead.
"I'm so sick of it," he said, pointing toward a pair of python pants on display overhead, rich maroon hip-huggers, the remains of a mid-size reticulated python. The salesman rolled his eyes and sighed. "It's going to be very dated, very fast," he said. "I think it's the acid wash of 2000."
Whether sinking snakeskin sales in New York City will mean more pythons in the wild is an open question. The skins remain popular in Europe, and snakeskin boots are likely to maintain their hold over would-be rock stars and barroom cowboys.
But in New York, at least, pythons may soon be getting a reprieve.
"I've heard," the salesman said, "that in the fall, it's ostrich that will be hot."

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW;
Latest Style For Pruning Companies Lop the Top

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
FIRING workers, like capital punishment, is applauded in America. Just the announcement of a mass downsizing in the mid-1990's would raise a company's stock price. Now that happens when a chief executive's head rolls. A faltering company seems somehow cleansed.
We even have a self-appointed scorekeeper: Challenger, Gray & Christmas, a Chicago firm that helps companies find new jobs for workers they lay off. As a sideline, Challenger in the 1990's began tracking layoff announcements and issuing grim monthly tallies. In the current robust economy, mass layoffs are way down and out of fashion. Shedding the chief executive is increasingly popular, and Challenger began last August to keep this new score. 
 The total through last Thursday was 706 chiefs of publicly owned companies, an average of 15 a week. Some retired in the usual way or jumped to better jobs, but the vast majority were dismissed. Durk I. Jager's ouster from Procter & Gamble on June 8 was departure No. 36 this month, and the toll has since risen to 48.
More formal studies confirm the trend. One found that 40 percent of new chief executives lose their jobs within 18 months. Another, by Rakesh Khurana at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, found that for the same poor performance, a chief executive was three times as likely to be fired in 1996 than in 1985.
"We are asking them to pitch no-hitters every day," said John A. Challenger, chief executive of Challenger, Gray. The game, in sum, rides entirely on the pitcher, not on the other players or on field-tested team strategies. As Peter Cappelli, a management professor at the Wharton School, put it: "We are substituting people for strategy. Instead of working out plans and goals, directors look at another company that is doing what they think they want to do, and they hire an executive from that company and hope" he will do the same for them.
Failure is defined as two or three quarters in which profits fail to rise at a 15 percent annual rate, and the stock price fails to keep up with the expectations of the bull market. That was the background music for Mr. Jager's departure. Or a new chief executive fails to bring about a merger or reorganization. Four out of five directors expect their chief executives to lead in this direction, according to surveys by the National Association of Corporate Directors.
Hold the tears, of course. Ordinary workers, even middle managers, are lucky if they walk away from a downsizing with enough in savings and severance to support their families for a year. The chief executives depart with enough not only for their families but their descendants for several generations. Knowing the high risk of being fired, they negotiate huge pay and severance packages, granted by the very directors who will later do the firing.
Just 25 years ago, a typical American chief executive was deeply entrenched. His cronies dominated the board, his company made money despite its inefficiencies and he resisted change. The rise of corporate raiders and leveraged buyouts brought an end to such inertia, and the increasingly powerful financial markets took control of most boards; today, directors are more likely than not to speak for shareholders.
A decade ago, if a big institutional shareholder like a pension or mutual fund did not like management, it sold the stock. Now it presses the board to drop the chief executive. Instead of being deeply rooted, the chief sways on a limb.
Is that an improvement? Probably, said Mr. Cappelli -- provided that directors become more committed, participate in strategic planning and shift more management authority to lower levels. Above all, they must be patient, giving the chief executive time to carry out a strategy, even if profits and the stock price do not quickly respond. The Eaton Corporation behaved this way, according to Stephen R. Hardis, who will retire next month at 65 after five years as chief executive. "My predecessor owned the board," he said. "My board owned me. But they always gave me a lot of support."
New technologies and product innovation force companies today into constant, risky change. Eaton makes auto and truck parts and transmissions, and in the Hardis years, the product line was redesigned to add electronic controls. The process involved the kind of staff upheaval that might have brought down a chief elsewhere. "You cannot change a company without changing people," Mr. Hardis said.
He wonders, then, whether Mr. Jager, who led Procter & Gamble for just 17 months, lacked skills, or the board lacked patience. "When I read about Jager, I wondered if it would make other chief executives more risk averse," he said "If you have to fundamentally reshape a business, it takes time, and makes people unhappy."

LENGTH: 701 words

HEADLINE: AT THE GATE;
Testing Pizzas' Pizazz As Maker Hits Market

BYLINE: By SANA SIWOLOP

 BODY:
PHILLY cheese steak. Thai chicken with roasted peanuts and ginger sauce.
Purists may cringe, but these are the kinds of toppings that California Pizza Kitchen sprinkles over its paper-thin crusts, to the delight of new-wave pizza fans in 21 states. 
 But while the designer pies have
won a following, the question of whether investors will develop a similar taste will be answered only in July, when the chain, based in Los Angeles, is expected to go public.
As of Friday, the company had not set a price for its offering or announced how many shares would be available. According to its prospectus, it wants to use the proceeds to pay back about $40 million in bank debt and to buy back some of its $45.4 million of preferred stock.
The chain has had a mixed record since a pair of lawyers, Larry S. Flax and Richard L. Rosenfield, founded it 15 years ago. During its first seven years, it had a relatively low-key growth plan, gradually opening 23 restaurants. But in 1992, Pepsico bought a controlling interest, and California Pizza binged, opening 60 outlets in five years.
Analysts say that under Pepsico's stewardship, the chain showed little aptitude for picking viable locations or maintaining quality. In 1996, sales actually declined at restaurants open at least a year. That year, Pepsico decided to focus on its soft-drink and snacks businesses, and in 1997 Bruckmann, Rosser, Sherrill & Company, a New York investment firm, bought a 67.4 percent stake, which is now down to 39.5 percent. The founders remain co-chairmen.
After Pepsico's departure, the company closed 16 of the 60 restaurants it built in its fast-expansion days. It has since followed a conservative growth plan and now has 100 restaurants to its name, 74 of them company-owned. And it has upgraded food quality while keeping high service standards, analysts said.
California Pizza is part of what the industry calls the casual-dining category -- a segment whose sales are expected to grow 8.7 percent a year over the next five years, according to Technomic, a Chicago consulting firm, versus just 5.7 percent for the overall industry.
Some of California Pizza's recent figures have been strong. Sales at company-owned restaurants grew 6.1 percent in 1998, 4.1 percent in 1999 and 6.8 percent during the first three months of 2000. That compares with just 0.6 percent in 1997.
The numbers impress Ron Paul, president of Technomic, because the casual-dining segment considers annual growth of 2 to 3 percent as "pretty good." He also likes that the average check for California Pizza customers is just $10.50; he thinks casual-dining customers see $10-and-under bills as good value.
Of course, this is not the hottest market in which to sell restaurant shares. The Standard & Poor's restaurants index is down 21 percent for the year through Friday. And the new-issue market itself is rife with postponements and cancellations.
California Pizza reported total debt of $40.1 million on April 2. Last year, earnings fell 48.6 percent, to $5.4 million, while overall revenue grew 7.2 percent, to $179.2 million.
While it is evident that premium pizza is not merely a fad, Phil Lempert, the editor of the Lempert Report, an industry newsletter in Santa Monica, Calif., said California Pizza would have to spend heavily on advertising to remind the public that it also has other items on its menu.
Others, like Randall Hiatt, a consultant at Fessel International in Irvine, Calif., question whether California Pizza can expand effectively outside its Western base. Indeed, he wonders if the chain is now growing too slowly. While investors have punished restaurant companies that expanded too quickly in the mid-1990's, he thinks they are now rewarding those that are pursuing sustained growth, like the Cheesecake Factory and P. F. Chang's China Bistro, whose numbers of outlets are growing at least 15 to 20 percent annually.
California Pizza has opened only 10 company-owned restaurants since the beginning of 1998; four are under construction. "I don't think the market will sustain low growth in this industry," Mr. Hiatt said. "I think the company is going to have to expand geographically."

HEADLINE: Bush, Harvard Business School And the Makings of a President

BYLINE: By JOHN SOLOMON; John Solomon, a writer in Manhattan, is a member of the Harvard Business School class of 1991.

 BODY:
ON their first day at Harvard Business School, a dean told the students of the class of 1975 that what they would learn there would prepare them less for the job they would take immediately after graduation than the job they would have in 25 years.
A quarter of a century later, one of those students is up for a big management position that has never been filled by someone with such preparation. If he gets the job, George W. Bush would be the first president with a master's degree in business administration. 
 And while it is not a part of his biography that he often discusses, Mr. Bush is in many ways the archetypal Harvard Business School-trained manager. As someone who went through the same training, 16 years after Mr. Bush, I find it striking how his style -- generalist, big picture, highly delegative -- is almost exactly in line with the management approach taught at Harvard.
But is that a good thing? Is a Harvard M.B.A. appropriate training for the presidency? And how much of George W. Bush, presidential candidate, is really a reflection of his Harvard years?
In his autobiography, "A Charge To Keep" (William Morrow & Company, 1999), Mr. Bush mentions his time at Harvard only briefly, calling it "a turning point for me" that taught "the principles of capital, how it is accumulated, risked, spent, managed."
Classmates and professors say that while the raw elements of Bush management were in place when he arrived at Harvard, business school had a significant role in melding his style.
They remember a relaxed attitude and an unusual confidence that stood out even in a class of some of America's most confident. Alumni scoff at the suggestion that Mr. Bush is not smart enough to be president -- though, of course, that is not necessarily an impartial view, given that his grades fell in the middle of the bell curve, along with most of theirs.
Mr. Bush was known as a quick study -- not a very deep thinker, but an efficient one. In class, he was more of a listener than a participant. (That may be why Mr. Bush left Harvard without having substantially improved his extemporaneous speaking abilities, though it also may be that heredity ultimately trumps business school.)
Instead, he distinguished himself more in team-oriented activities. Whether in the campuswide business simulation game or on the intramural basketball court, he was often the consensus choice to run things.
"George's leadership was not based on raw brain power," recalled Mitch Kurz, a classmate who now runs his own marketing consulting firm in Norwalk, Conn. "He had an intangible quality about him, that there wasn't a problem that couldn't be solved -- not necessarily by him, but somehow."
IN 92 years of training presidents, Harvard Business School has never trained a president of the United States. Indeed, the M.B.A. has not been widely viewed as proper preparation for a career in politics, in part because of the management failings of one of the school's best and brightest: Robert S. McNamara, the former secretary of defense. But Mr. McNamara's quantitatively driven analytical style, which led him astray in Vietnam, is actually antithetical to the more broad-based, qualitative general management taught by Harvard.
There is also a misperception -- even among many students in the school -- that Harvard's management training is applicable solely to business. It is true that a high percentage of the case studies used in its courses are corporate situations. And most students come from the private sector and return there upon graduation. But Harvard Business School training is much more about process than content; its problem-solving and decision-making methodology is easily transferable to the public sector.
In Mr. Bush's class, that point was made presciently during discussion of one of the very rare public-sector case studies, on the paper flow in the office of Edward M. Kennedy, then as now a senator from Massachusetts. Classmates said that when a student challenged the case's relevance to a business degree, the professor responded: Who knows? Someone in the class could end up as president of the United States.
From his seat in the top row, Mr. Bush -- often relied upon for humor -- raised his arms over his head in a Nixonesque victory gesture.
M.B.A.'s now in elective politics say that course work at business school -- including marketing, finance, accounting and political economy -- has become as relevant to governing as any other academic training, if not more so.
"The president," said Representative Chet Edwards, a Texas Democrat who graduated from the school in 1981, "is the manager of the largest and most powerful corporation in the world." Of course, the public sector is different: there, popularity is a more important performance criterion than profitability, and checks and balances are not financial terms but constraints on executive authority.
From the start, Mr. Bush made a distinct impression on Section C, the group of 84 students with whom he would go through his first year of course work.
"I was sitting in the front row, and I heard this strange noise coming from up behind me," Mr. Kurz recalled. "I remember thinking, 'What the heck is that?' I turned around and there was George spitting tobacco juice into a cup."
Under the school's forced grading curve, about 5 percent of the 800 or so students in each class will be asked to leave after the first year. Early on, almost everyone thinks it might be him or her. "Plenty of students were scared out of their wits when they got there," said Rudy Winston, who taught Human Behavior and Organization to Section C that year.
But not Mr. Bush, who was 27 and had just completed his service in the Air National Guard when he arrived at Harvard. Mr. Winston remembers entering the class the first day and seeing Mr. Bush flying paper airplanes around the room. "George felt that this environment was something he could handle," Mr. Winston said.
In each of the three daily, 80-minute classes at the school, one student is "cold called" to "open" with a five-minute action plan and analysis of a case study, a well-researched narrative of a real-life situation seen through an executive's eyes. A free-for-all Socratic discussion follows, with classmates either building upon or tearing apart the presentation. The stakes are high, because class participation can count for up to 50 percent of the grade -- not to mention the thrice-daily opportunity to embarrass yourself in front of your peers.
"The case method relentlessly trains you come up with solutions to problems," said Michael E. Porter, the Christensen Professor of Business Administration, whose first teaching assignment at Harvard was Mr. Bush's Section C class.
The back row of the amphitheater-style classroom is called the Sky Deck, and "if the seating chart is an allegory, then George was the perfect Sky Decker," said Charles Braxton, a section mate who is now an energy company executive in Charlotte, N.C. "He wanted to take it all in, hear everybody and pick his spot to make a big-picture comment."
It was in team activities that Mr. Bush asserted himself. In the three-day, campuswide business simulation game, Section C elected Mr. Bush one of six team presidents. His 15-person "company" did not win, but Mr. Porter, the group's faculty supervisor, told the class that it worked best together and would have had the best long-term results.
"He was not a star academic performer here," said Mr. Porter, now an economic policy adviser to the Bush campaign. "But he was very good at getting along with people and getting things done."
There was more evidence of those abilities in the highly competitive intramural basketball league. Despite hoop skills that one teammate described as "mediocre at best," Mr. Bush, at point guard, took control of a squad of more talented players.
Jim Schroer, a 6-foot-5 former college basketball standout, acknowledged having been the toughest management challenge. "I was a prima donna. I know the rest of the guys appreciated that George was able to get through to me," said Mr. Schroer, now vice president of global marketing at the Ford Motor Company. "Not too many people in my life were able to whip me into shape."
By the mid-70's, distrust of the cold certitude of the McNamara style -- expert-oriented management by numbers -- put a premium on the consensus-building style of someone like Mr. Bush.
"Everyone was keenly aware that the model of putting the expert -- the smartest guy -- in charge was changing," Mr. Braxton recalled. "George was not leading from technical expertise. He was of the new model that was not afraid of teamwork and of not knowing the answer to everything."
MR. BUSH has not yet announced if he will attend the 25th reunion of his Harvard Business School class in late September, in the heat of the presidential campaign. If he does, he can be assured his classmates will be attentive to his comments during planned reunion classes like "Business and Politics Along the Technological Frontier" and "National Economies in the Global Village."
"We listened to him 25 years ago," Mr. Kurz joked. "But the fact that he could be the leader of the free world does give him a little more credibility."
Peter Gebhard, another Section C student who now runs a metal-finishing company in Providence, R.I., even has a possible campaign slogan ready: "The lawyers and the generals have had their chance. Why not give an M.B.A. a shot?"

HEADLINE: PERSONAL BUSINESS;
A Peek at Your Credit Scorecard

BYLINE: By MICKEY MEECE

 BODY:
THINK of the numbers that matter most when you apply for credit. You know your date of birth, Social Security number and annual income well enough, and you may know just how much money you have in the bank. But the make-or-break figure is one that lenders are privy to but that you have probably never seen: your credit score.
The veil is lifting from this mysterious metric, in response to pressure by consumer groups, by legislation before Congress and by loan-service Web sites like E-Loan that were eager to spill the beans to customers. Fair, Isaac, the San Rafael, Calif., company that pioneered credit scoring 40 years ago and dominates the field today, has published on its own Web site, www.fairisaac.com, its general recipe for scoring consumer credit. 
 The factors considered are payment history (35 percent of the overall score); amounts and types of outstanding debt (30 percent); length of credit history (15 percent); amount of new credit recently sought or gained (10 percent); and types of credit in use (10 percent). Points are added to yield a score that ranges from the 300's to the 900's -- the higher, the better.
In large part, Fair, Isaac's recipe confirms popular notions of what good credit means: that people who borrow moderately and pay on time can expect to score better than those who borrow to the limit or not at all, or those who chronically pay late. But some idiosyncrasies and potential pitfalls revealed in the scoring system may surprise consumers.
Moves to remove credit blemishes, for example, may not help, or may even backfire. Closing an account that you once paid late won't remove it from consideration. And say you think you are carrying too much debt on too many credit cards, so you get a loan from a personal finance company to consolidate the debt into a single, easier-to manage payment. A good move? Not for your credit score: finance-company loans are considered a greater sign of risk than owing the same amount on credit cards. On top of that, if you consolidate the debt into one loan and close the credit card accounts, you have reduced the credit available to you without reducing the amount you owe, which hurts your score.
Consider a consumer who always pays her credit card balances in full each month. Her credit scores will rise, based on zero card debt, right? Wrong. The scoring system generally picks up the balances on her most recent statements -- before she has paid them. So if she racks up a lot of charges each month -- say, to earn bonuses like airline miles -- it is possible that her score will be pulled down a bit by what the formula considers heavy debt relative to her credit limit, even if she has never missed a payment.
Even shopping aggressively online for the best rate on a new loan can lower your score. Each time you enter personal information like your income and Social Security number on a Web site's form, it may be reported to credit bureaus as a credit inquiry. Too many credit inquiries will count against you, though Fair, Isaac said it had taken steps to collapse multiple inquiries for a particular loan over a short period into a single hit for scoring purposes.
"Inquiries are not enough to make or break someone's score," said Cheri St. John, a senior vice president of Fair, Isaac, who oversees its credit bureau scoring services unit. Still, she advises, "only shop for and accept the credit you need."
For years, consumers setting out to establish credit were told that more credit is better, a myth "that took a while to dispel," Ms. St. John said. In fact, getting too much credit at once makes a person appear risky, she said; building up gradually and establishing a good payment history is a better approach.
While Fair, Isaac provides the models used to calculate scores, it does not have access to credit bureau data on individuals. The scores are used in three out of four mortgage originations as well as for other kinds of loans; a score in the middle 600's is generally high enough to get a mortgage on favorable terms. Keith T. Gumbinger, a vice president of HSH Associates, a research firm in Butler, N.J., said the federally sponsored mortgage agencies, like Freddie Mac and Fannie Mae, use 620 as a cutoff for high-quality loans.
As a result, loans below that score are harder to package and sell, so many mortgage lenders will deny credit or charge higher interest rates, added fees and more points up front, Mr. Gumbinger said. But contrary to popular belief, he said, in the mortgage world, "there's almost no benefit for having a better score" than 620.
For now, the only way a consumer can obtain his or her current credit score is from a lender, which will usually reveal the score only when an application is denied. Starting next month, consumers who know their scores can get an explanatory report on the Fair, Isaac Web site; people who do not know their scores can have their lenders provide them to Fair, Isaac on their behalf, and then pass along the explanation.
Eventually, Fair, Isaac said, it would like to be able to provide scores directly to consumers. And later this year, Trans Union, one of the three major credit bureaus, plans to create its own credit scores and explain the results to consumers.
 
Raising Your Score
 
Here are some ways to put your best foot forward in the complex arithmetic of credit scoring.
 
Apply sparingly. Seek credit only when you need it, not on a whim.
 
Don't change indiscriminately. Putting all your spending on a credit card can make you look deep in debt, even if you pay it all off each month.
 
Avoid maxing out. Using all your available credit makes you look risky; either borrow less or have your limit raised.
 
Pay on time. Late payments do more to hurt your score than almost anything short of default and bankruptcy.
 
Inspect your credit report. Errors and omissions in credit bureau data are common.
