HEADLINE: Oil Ministers Might Agree On Small RiseIn Production

BYLINE: By NEELA BANERJEE 

 BODY:
OPEC ministers meeting today in Vienna are expected to agree on a modest production increase, but the move is unlikely to bring much relief to American gasoline consumers who are paying more than $2 a gallon in some regions.
"If U.S. consumers are looking to the OPEC meeting as some kind of salvation from gas prices this summer, they will be very disappointed," said Raad Alkadiri, an analyst with the Petroleum Finance Corporation, a consulting group in Washington. 
 Oil ministers arriving for their meeting in Vienna today said they were confident they would reach an agreement quickly, and a consensus appears to have formed around an increase of 500,000 barrels a day, or about 2 percent of current output. Such an increase has the support not only of Saudi Arabia, the most influential OPEC member, but also the support of Iran, which angrily rebelled at a production increase three months ago.
But the ministers of Algeria and Qatar said in preparing for the Vienna meeting that there was no shortage of oil in the world, apparently suggesting that raising output by that much is not necessary. Oil prices, which have surged in recent weeks, rose further today on the conflicting messages.
In the supply-and-demand balance, most people have focused on the supply side ever since crude prices began climbing last year. Understandably so, because a decision by OPEC in early 1999 to cut supply led to a sharp rebound in oil prices, driving them to more than $30 a barrel by this spring.
In March, under heavy pressure by the United States and other industrialized countries that import petroleum, OPEC decided to increase production by 1.7 million barrels a day, or about 7 percent, to about 24.7 million barrels a day. Crude prices initially dipped, only to surpass the $30 mark once again in the last few weeks, despite estimates by many analysts that OPEC is already pumping about 500,000 barrels more than it had agreed upon three months ago. At the same time, average United States gasoline prices have risen sharply, up nearly 13 percent since late April, according to the Department of Energy. They show no sign of easing just as the summer driving season is starting.
In the Great Lakes region, where gasoline costs more than $2 a gallon, consumer anger has led to federal inquiries into possible price gouging by area refineries.
Even at such levels, gasoline prices adjusted for inflation are still lower than they were for most of the century up to 1968, according to a recent study by Cambridge Energy Research Associates.
"But this is a price that people very easily get very angry about," said Daniel Yergin, chairman of Cambridge Energy.
OPEC leaders like the Saudis have intimated that they, like much of the rest of the world, are uncomfortable with current high crude prices. If prices stay above $30 for a long time, that could hurt the economies of affluent oil-consuming countries and even lead to a recession, which would hurt OPEC as much as anyone else.
But any OPEC increase in output would deal only with the supply side of the equation. Worldwide demand for oil, driven by the robust American economy and strengthening recoveries in Asia and Europe, continues to grow and quickly absorb OPEC supply increases.
For example, United States refineries that distill crude, the first step in making gasoline, are operating at 94 percent of capacity, which is considered high. And despite persistent complaints about inflationary gasoline prices, Americans have yet to curtail their driving, AAA, the former American Automobile Association, has reported.
The relentless demand for petroleum in the United States may, in fact, be a principal reason for the rise in crude prices.
The Chicago area, where gasoline has risen to $2.50 a gallon at some stations in recent days, illustrates how prices and crude oil production are not directly related.
The stage for the run-up was set in late winter, when refineries typically acquire crude to meet high gasoline demand over the summer. A heating oil crisis compelled some United States refineries to keep producing heating oil rather than shifting to gasoline.
While crude was expensive at the time, market prices for oil to be delivered in later months was decreasing. So rather than replenishing their inventories at the higher prices, many refineries bought crude for delivery later at the lower prices, something of a "just in time" strategy.
Consequently, inventories of gasoline are now unusually low across the country, with stocks in the week ending June 9 totaling 202.7 million gallons, compared with 223.5 million last year, according to the American Petroleum Institute, an industry group.
Drawing on lower-than-usual inventories, Great Lakes refineries now must produce a reformulated gasoline that burns cleaner in adherence with the latest Environmental Protection Agency regulations. Because of how this gasoline is made, refineries produce less of it than they do of conventional gasoline.
Gasoline supplies in the Great Lakes fell even lower when a pipeline that feeds oil from the Gulf Coast to the region's refineries broke down in the spring. That pipeline is still operating at only 80 percent capacity, according to the American Petroleum Institute.
The E.P.A. contends that its requirements for reformulated gasoline do not contribute to higher fuel prices. But AAA has asked the agency to suspend reformulated gasoline requirements for parts of the country, including the Midwest, for most of the summer because the cleaner-burning fuel costs so much.
"Reformulated gasoline is a premium product and tighter requirements mean it will be more expensive," said George Beranek, an expert on refining at the Petroleum Finance Corporation. "You can't mandate improvement and expect it to be free."

SECTION: Section B; Page 1; Column 2; Metropolitan Desk

HEADLINE: THE OTHER ECONOMY: A Plan, a Canal Town;
A Canal Town's Existential Crisis

BYLINE: By LESLIE EATON 

DATELINE: CLYDE, N.Y.

 BODY:
Sitting in Pete's Diner, talking about his beloved hometown, Kenneth DiSanto makes the plan sounds plausible, even probable. Of course this forlorn little village will transform itself from plain old Clyde, smack in the middle of nowhere, to Clyde-on-the-Erie, historic site and tourist magnet.
Step outside onto Glasgow Street, however, and the obstacles to that plan become plain. 
 Just for starters, you cannot actually get to the Erie Canal from three-block-long downtown Clyde. Railroad tracks run between the water and the village; freight cars rumble through every 20 minutes or so. Nor can you get from the canal into Clyde; the only dock, on the far side of a big, ugly bridge, cannot accommodate anything much bigger than a rowboat.
Nevertheless, Clyde, halfway between Rochester and Syracuse, is pinning its hopes for the future on the canal that first gave it life back in the 1820's.
So are dozens of other communities in upstate New York. They are being egged on by the federal government, which since 1996 has been pushing a "canal corridor initiative" to redevelop the historic canal for tourism and recreation -- and has given out almost $240 million in grants and loans to help pay for the efforts.
"Nobody wants to live in a chapter in a history book," said Andrew Cuomo, the secretary of housing and urban development (and a possible future candidate for governor of New York). But, he said, remaking and marketing the canal will promote "tourism, jobs, energy and optimism, and the quality of life of the locale."
Across New York State, there are hundreds of villages and towns of 1,000 or 2,000 or 3,000 souls, stranded in history as well as geography. Places that once had a reason for being -- a railroad stop, a turnpike gate, a waterfall to drive a mill -- are struggling to survive in the age of the Internet.
In Clyde, "our game plan has been to find a reason for existence," said Mr. DiSanto, who is, among other things, chairman of the village's Industrial Development Corporation.
That makes Clyde similar to many upstate communities, said Susan Christopherson, a professor of urban planning at Cornell University who has studied the canal redevelopment program. So does its separation from the canal itself. "In many cases, it ran adjacent to the downtown business district," she said. "It wasn't directly connected to downtown."
Some communities along the canal are more prosperous than Clyde, and more urban; many in western Wayne County, for example, where Clyde is located, have become suburbs of Rochester. But "Clyde is fairly typical of most rural downtowns" in central New York, said Barbara Harper, director of the Wayne County Economic Development Authority.
Which means that there is not a whole lot here: Pete's, of course, and the Trackside Deli, a Key Bank branch, antiques shops and a cute little flower shop. For shopping there's a hardware store, the Clyde Bargain Center and Messinger's Variety Store, an old-fashioned five-and-dime that sells housedresses and hairnets when its 91-year-old proprietor can make it to the cash register.
Clyde has a leafy little town green, too, with a bandstand and fountain. You have to look closely to realize that the statue of George Washington has lost its nose, or that the fancy little roof on wooden supports labeled "Clyde's Famous Mineral Spring" covers only a pipe with a soda can smashed into it.
It's hard to say exactly how many people still live in Clyde. Locals put the population at 2,400, but last year's Census Bureau estimate is about half that. In any event, Clyde is so small it has only one telephone exchange, and people tend to identify themselves by the year they graduated from Clyde-Savannah High.
And for some of those people, the canal remains a real part of life, even today. Take Brian Howell, who worked on the last steam-powered vessel to ply the Erie. That was only 15 years ago -- and Mr. Howell, who works for the State Canal Corporation, is only 34 (class of 1984).
At one time, the canal was all the reason Clyde needed for being. When the canal opened in 1825, it provided for the first time transportation through the spine of mountains that runs down the eastern United States -- and that today seems such an insignificant barrier. Wheat could come east, widgets could go west, and people could move both ways, on barges drawn by mules.
Clyde was the first stop for westbound barges that had pushed for hours through the malaria-infested Montezuma Swamp. Not surprisingly, mule drivers got off to have a drink in one of Clyde's taverns.
There were shoe shops and clothing shops, and, in time, a fancy hotel, a racetrack, two newspapers, two train stations, three graveyards, at least four churches and a home-grown marching band. The biggest house in town belonged to the owner of the glass factory, which turned out handmade Mason jars.
The railroad brought Abraham Lincoln, who in 1861 spoke a few sentences to a crowd gathered in Clyde. In the 1880's, it brought the Italian workers whose names are now borne by almost everyone in town.
Throughout the first half of the 20th century, Clyde continued to prosper. "If I had to be transported back in time, it would be to the 1930's," said R. Hugh Miner, the town historian and publisher of the monthly Crossroads Advocate. In this agricultural area, even the Great Depression was not so bad, he said, "and this was a very close-knit community."
Just ask George L. Storto, who says he is related to everyone in town (his father owned an ice cream parlor). A member of the Clyde-Savannah High class of 1948, Mr. Storto left Clyde in 1957 and ended up in Arizona, working for a big insurance company. And he married a woman from Tennessee.
"She said, 'Someday you have to show me that little town you're from, because you talk about it and dream about it,' " Mr. Storto said. In 1995, he and his wife came back to Clyde. "And I know I'm staying here," he said, "because my wife said we need to buy a couple of plots at the cemetery."
Mr. Storto is part of what may be Clyde's secret weapon: a group of well-traveled, well-to-do retirees who are determined to save the place they still love. They include Mr. Di Santo and Richard DeVito, who both retired from Xerox, and Rudolph A. DeLisio, who retired from General Electric (classes of '56, '51 and '41, respectively).
They knew Clyde before the G.E. plant closed and eliminated 350 jobs in the early 1960's. Even though some other businesses have moved in -- Parker Hannifin, which makes industrial hydraulic equipment, and Thomas Electronics each employ well over 100 people -- Clyde seemed to lose something, they said.
Property values fell, absentee landlords moved in, and so did a lot of people receiving welfare or disability payments. There is not much for poor or young people to do in Clyde, especially if they don't have cars.
"They really do need to lighten this town up, put in a movie house or a skating rink," said Albert Austin, who lives on Glasgow Street and gets by on Social Security and the money he makes collecting cans and bottles for recycling.
Next door, Tammy Simcerbeaux, an 18-year-old with two small children, agreed. What does she do for fun? "Nothing, really," she said. "It's boring."
Over the years, drugs became a problem. The Chamber of Commerce and other civic organizations dwindled; in 1989, the village even stopped holding its Christmas decoration competition, a staple of small-town life.
But in 1996, things began to change. By a narrow margin, Clyde elected a new mayor, Steven J. Groat, a photographer, who shared many of the retirees' ideas and frustrations. Mr. DeLisio started to revive the Chamber of Commerce, in part by allowing anyone to join.
The retirees formed a sort of Save Clyde Committee, and with Mr. Groat they persuaded a class of landscape architecture students at Cornell to draw up a plan to renovate downtown Clyde. And it began to seem possible that Clyde could serve as an antiques center, a place where people floating down the canal or visiting Montezuma (now a wildlife refuge popular with bird watchers) could browse and buy.
Mr. Groat began applying for government grants and loans, and has brought more than $1 million into Clyde. Some of the money has gone to a new water system; some was to be spent on a new park and dock on the far side of the Erie, which have not yet been started because the bids came in too high.
Meanwhile, the residents of Clyde did a little boot-strapping; 75 of them kicked in $1,000 each toward a limited partnership. The money has gone to buy what the retirees describe as the three worst buildings in town, all on Glasgow Street, and now they are trying to find the cash to renovate the buildings.
Its buildings will help determine whether Clyde succeeds as a Cinderella -- and under all the layers of plastic and aluminum "improvements," they are beautiful. (And cheap.)
Fantastically ornate tin covers 14-foot ceilings in an old drugstore that Kevin Sipple is turning into an elegant antiques shop ("no junk," he said firmly). A 50-year-old retired police officer from outside Rochester, Mr. Sipple is pulling up the tile floor of his 1853 building to expose the tongue-and-groove maple. Upstairs, he has installed a new kitchen and bathroom in a one-bedroom apartment he hopes to rent out.
Down the block, in a building Mr. DiSanto owns, is a similar tin ceiling, as well as an elaborately paneled and mirrored wall dating to the days when the place was Wood's barbershop. For the past year, Darrell Marriott, a 35-year-old former quarterback at Clyde-Savannah High, has been running the Olde Erie Hair Shoppe there, giving $8 haircuts.
Mr. DiSanto owns another building, the old Stoetzel's bakery, and has restored the huge brick oven in the back room, hoping to turn the place into a restaurant. The upper two floors (which would make even Brooklyn brownstone dwellers envious) may someday become a bed and breakfast. Right now, Clyde lacks even a motel.
Another construction project may soon begin a few blocks away, where the town historical society plans to turn the old Baptist church facing the park into a new museum and meeting hall. (The old museum, a former feed mill by the railroad tracks, is open only two afternoons a week in July and August, and in any event looks like someone's attic).
These developments may seem minor, but they have not been embraced by everyone. Mr. Groat, 48,gave up the mayor's office to run for county legislator but lost; his efforts to enforce zoning and building codes made him unpopular in some quarters. And he admits that he and the retirees may have tried to change too much, too soon. "Trying to do something here is difficult," he said. "I don't want to say that I shoved it down their throats, but I did."
Thomas Caprilla, the new mayor -- who was also mayor before Mr. Groat -- said residents were not opposed to the redevelopment plan, but worried that it might increase their taxes, or change the nature of the village. "As much as people want to see the canal improved," he said, "they're afraid of a flock of tourists coming to Clyde."
That does not seem to be a looming problem. More pleasure boats are using the lock near Clyde -- traffic rose by 8 percent between 1997 and 1999 -- but fewer than 1,100 cruised through last year. And while Mr. DiSanto's Industrial Development Corporation has lured several small businesses -- and about 30 jobs -- to Clyde in the last four years, they are in manufacturing, not tourism.
But those job gains may not be unrelated to Clyde's improvements. Professor Christopherson is working on a new study for the federal government that suggests that improving amenities for tourists may also draw other kinds of businesses looking for good recreational opportunities for their employees.
In Clyde, anyway, jobs sometime seem beside the point. What people keep coming back to is the search for a reason for being. As Mr. Miner, the historian, puts it, "The whole idea of the Erie Canal for us is that we're hoping to regain some identity."

HEADLINE: Lung Cancer Test Is Much in Demand, But Benefit Is Murky

BYLINE: By GINA KOLATA 

 BODY:
When word got out recently that two radiology centers in Portland, Ore., were offering a new screening test for the early detection of lung cancer, the response was overwhelming. Smokers and former smokers jammed the centers' phones, demanding the simple, painless test that can find lung cancers so tiny that they can be snipped out and, doctors hope, the patients cured.
In a single day, more than 300 people called one of the centers, Epic Imaging. "I got in at 6:30 that morning and didn't get off the phone until 6:30 that night," said Melanie Haymond, a marketing director there. 
 Drawn by newspaper articles and Epic's brochures describing the test as "fast, inexpensive, lifesaving," patients readily agreed to Epic's $295 fee, even though the test is not covered by most health insurance policies because it is considered experimental. They even agreed to pay half of the money at the time of the test, as Epic required.
Such responses are being repeated throughout the country as more and more radiologists begin advertising the lung cancer screening test. The procedure is done with a powerful new X-ray machine, a spiral CT scanner, which can detect tumors many times smaller than those found with a conventional chest X-ray.
Cancer experts agree that there is an urgent need to improve the prospects for patients with lung cancer.
But it is unclear whether more people will be harmed than helped by the test because the scanner's effectiveness has never been rigorously tested. One early study has found that 9 of every 10 patients who have suspicious test findings will not have cancer -- but they will have to have additional expensive tests, and sometimes surgery, to find that out. For the rest there are three possibilities. Some may be cured when surgeons snip out their tumors. Others may have tumors that may turn out not to have been dangerous after all, but they still would have undergone treatments as though their lives were threatened. And still others may have tiny tumors that turn out to be incurable despite the treatments.
These are questions that researchers say are going to occur more often as science is rapidly making it possible to find a variety of diseases at earlier and earlier stages.
Lung cancer is the nation's leading cause of cancer deaths, killing about 157,000 Americans every year, more than colon, breast, prostate and uterine cancers combined. Lung cancer is diagnosed in about 164,000 people each year, but the five-year survival rate is just 14 percent -- virtually the same as it was 30 years ago.
The earlier that diseases are found, the less that is known about their likely course and the more difficult the questions. Molecular tests are being developed for bladder cancer and colon cancer, for example, that would look for individual genes that go awry, long before any tumors are evident. Scientists are working on scanning tests for early Alzheimer's disease and on ever more precise ways of finding very early breast cancer.
But seldom have the stakes been so high and the choices so stark as with the new lung cancer test. The cost of testing all current and former smokers with the lung scanner would be immense -- more than $39 billion, according to the National Cancer Institute. Yet if the test works, it could save hundreds of thousands of lives and alleviate terrible suffering.
"It has become a huge debate," said Dr. Jonathan Goldin, a radiologist at the University of California in Los Angeles. "There's an academic interest, there's a health policy interest, there's a highly emotional desire to do good for patients. And then there's an economic interest -- you can make a fair amount of money right now if you opened up a spiral scanner and said, 'Let's go for it.' "
 
Is Early Detection Good?
The idea of using the spiral CT scanners to find early lung cancers began with an iconoclast, Dr. Claudia L. Henschke, the division chief of chest imaging at Weill Cornell Medical Center of New York Presbyterian Hospital in Manhattan. She knew that most scientists dismissed lung cancer screening as useless. Doctors could find the cancer early with chest X-rays. But studies indicated that the lives of these patients had not been prolonged.
Dr. Henschke wondered whether advances in technology might have changed the prospects for lung cancer screening. A new generation of X-ray machines, the spiral CT, or computerized tomography, scanners, could show nodules as small as the diameter of a soda straw, compared with the the quarter-size tumors that were seen with chest X-rays. Could it be, Dr. Henschke asked, that the spiral scanners, already widely used by radiologists, could find lung cancers so early that they could be cured?
That was in 1991. "No one was willing to talk about it," Dr. Henschke said. "They said it's a dead issue."
Despite the skeptics, Dr. Henschke organized a study of 1,000 smokers and former smokers, examining each person's lungs with both spiral CT scans and with conventional chest X-rays and comparing what the two machines found. When the radiologists saw very small nodules, they asked the patients to come back in a few months to see if the nodules were growing. If a nodule grew, patients needed more tests, sometimes involving surgery, to see if it was cancerous.
With the spiral CT scans, 23 percent of the people had suspicious nodules but only 2.7 percent of them turned out to have cancer. Almost all the tumors were in Stage 1, meaning they had not yet spread. Chest X-rays found suspicious nodules in 7 percent of the people but only 0.7 percent of them had cancer. Half of the tumors were in Stage 1. The rest were more advanced.
Dr. Henschke's paper was published in a British medical journal, The Lancet, last July 10 and reported widely in the news media, setting off a groundswell of demand for the test because she showed that lung cancer could be detected early, and a rush by radiologists to offer it.
At Cornell, Dr. Henschke said, smokers and former smokers mobbed the hospital lobby, refusing to leave without spiral CT scanning tests. Over the next six months, radiologists across the country began advertising the scanning tests for lung cancer.
The University Radiology Group in New Brunswick, N.J., began advertising its $295 test on the radio and in newspapers in December, drawing 200 patients. "We already had the scanner, so it was not a big deal," said Dr. Judith Korek Amorosa, a radiologist there.
The Arizona Heart Institute in Phoenix began advertising its $500 test in December, bringing in 300 people so far, said Jeannie Swindle, the vice president for marketing there. The institute even offers specials, such as the one it had in May, when it reduced its price by more than $100, Ms. Swindle said.
Many who had the lung scans were delighted. Kenneth MacWilliams, a 63-year-old investment banker in Dumont, N.J., went to Dr. Henschke's office for a test last year because he had breathed other peoples' smoke at work. His scan showed no signs of tumors.
"There is absolutely no downside for me," Mr. MacWilliams said. "Why would I not want to do this?"
But as the lung scans are being promoted, one gap in the logic remains. Dr. Henschke's study had shown that spiral CT scanners could find tiny lung cancers. What it did not show was whether finding them saved lives. And that is fueling the bitter debate over how much evidence of that is necessary.
"It's the fundamental question," said Dr. David F. Yankelevitz, Dr. Henschke's colleague at Cornell. "These are critical issues, and it's a discussion that needs to happen."
 
A Questionable Study
Dr. Henschke cannot convince herself that there is much more to ask. She knows the hypothetical problems with early detection, but she does not believe they apply to lung cancer.
"Logically, we know you can cure cancer only when you get it at an early stage," Dr. Henschke said. "CT gets it much much earlier. The only thing that has to be documented is how many lives are saved."
The orthodox way to find out is to randomly assign patients to have the lung scanning test, or not, and then compare outcomes. If more people die in the unscreened group, it can be concluded that the test is saving lives.
But, Dr. Henschke asks, how many people are going to enroll in such a study? Who would forgo a simple, painless test that could find cancer early? And even if people did agree, would they hold off having a lung scan for more than a decade while the study wound its way to a conclusion?
"Down the line, more and more people are going to be convinced" of the effectiveness of the test, Dr. Henschke said. "What do you do when your neighbor has a CT scan and it detects a nodule and the nodule is cured?"
So what Dr. Henschke is planning is almost scientific apostasy -- a study in which everyone gets a CT scan.
The researchers will use statistical analyses to decide how much better people fared than they would have if they had not received the screening test.
Dr. Henschke said she could not conduct the study any other way. She said she had seen too many patients with tiny cancerous tumors that were removed and did not return, and too many who had no screening and whose tumors were found too late. She could not conceive of waiting well over a decade for a randomized clinical trial to enroll patients, screen them and follow them as the study wound to a close.
"How many lives will you be losing?" Dr. Henschke said. "If there are 160,000 people who die from lung cancer each year, you could save a lot of lives during that trial -- certainly over 100,000 from my best estimate," she said, calculating what she thought would be the number of lives saved over the course of the 10-year study.
 
Need for Answers
Dr. Barnett Kramer of the National Institutes of Health, knows the emotional pull of patients' stories, and he knows that when it comes to arguing about lung cancer scans, he is at a disadvantage. He does not do the scans and must rely instead on cold logic and reasoning. But he does look at data, and at recent medical history. And he is very worried about the rapid spread of spiral CT screening for lung cancer.
Dr. Kramer remembers the last time that doctors thought they had a way of preventing lung cancer deaths. During the 1960's and 1970's, many recommended that smokers and former smokers have regular X-rays, and some also ordered tests of their sputum to look for cancer.
Finally, researchers managed to do large clinical trials that asked whether such screenings saved lives. The results were eye-opening. Although more cancers were found in the screened group, and at earlier stages, the screenings did nothing to cut the death rate from lung cancer.
In 1989, Dr. David Eddy, who is an independent consultant and an adviser to Kaiser Permanente, Southern California, summed up the situation in a paper in the Annals of Internal Medicine. "It is important to emphasize that these conclusions are not based on a lack of evidence of an effect," Dr. Eddy wrote, "but are based on good evidence that there is no effect."
For Dr. Kramer, it was a valuable lesson.
"This is the classic case," Dr. Kramer said. "You were picking up cancers that would not have killed the patients, and you were curing people who did not need to be cured. In exchange you were doing a lot more surgery."
The cancer institute hopes to do a large definitive study involving at least 20,000 people who would be randomly assigned to have a CT scan or, for comparison, to forgo it.
Dr. Kramer is optimistic that once the uncertainties of the lung scan are explained, people will volunteer for the study.
For now, medical experts said, the nation is poised at a critical moment when a decision on how to proceed can reverberate for years to come.
"Certainly, there is no question that spiral CT is a promising technology," said Dr. Paul S. Frame, a family practitioner in Cohocton, N.Y., who is reviewing the scanner as a member of the United States Preventive Services Task Force, which makes recommendations on screenings. "But the fear and the caution is that our society is geared to like miracles. And when somebody mentions a miracle, nobody wants to wait around and see if it's true. That's the dilemma we're in."

SECTION: Section G; Page 16; Column 3; Circuits 

LENGTH: 998 words

HEADLINE: REVIEW;
Accusing Silicon Valley of a Heart of Coal

BYLINE: By LISA GUERNSEY 

 BODY:

CYBERSELFISH: A CRITICAL
ROMP THROUGH THE
TERRIBLY LIBERTARIAN
CULTURE OF HIGH-TECH
By Paulina Borsook
(Public Affairs, $24.)
PAULINA BORSOOK is fed up with Silicon Valley. But the area's instant millionaires and outrageously priced houses are not the reason for her fuming. It is the ideology behind the technology industry that really has her miffed.
Those emotions come screeching through in Ms. Borsook's book, "Cyberselfish: A Critical Romp Through the Terribly Libertarian Culture of High-Tech." 
 Ms. Borsook, a journalist and former contributing writer for Wired magazine, has written an irreverent (and sometimes incomprehensible) rant on what she sees as the hypocrisy of today's technology leaders. They don't like big government, they don't like regulation, and they wish that Uncle Sam would just leave them and their market-driven economy alone.
Yet, as Ms. Borsook points out over and over again, government money and federal regulations have made Silicon Valley what it is today. Federal grants sponsored university research that has been translated into scores of Internet and computer products. Regulations have ensured that the banking system is "relatively fraud free." And the defense industry, don't forget, brought the Internet into existence in the first place.
"Government," she writes, "has made Silicon Valley a fine and dandy, safe and regularized place to make scads of money." Internet moguls who do not realize this, Ms. Borsook writes, are nothing better than "privileged spoiled teenagers." To those who are tired of the hype emanating from Northern California in the past five years, the Bay Area bashing in "Cyberselfish" may be a welcome relief.
The book also presents an insider's view of how high-tech culture has evolved in the past decade. Ms. Borsook, who lives in Santa Cruz, has been observing and interacting for years with the area's computer programmers, software engineers, cryptographers and venture capitalists. One chapter focuses on Wired and the personalities that gave the magazine its libertarian bent. The chapter also reveals some of the frustration felt by women who wrote for Wired in the mid 1990's, women who bemoaned how a magazine that considered itself in the vanguard could in fact be nothing more than a geek's twist on the old boy network.
But if you plan to accompany Ms. Borsook on this 256-page romp, be prepared to take a deep breath. Reading the book is like charging blindly through an obstacle course. Paragraphs are filled with so many asides, hyphenated words, parenthetical clauses, dashes and asterisks that you are left virtually panting at the end of each sentence. That is, if you get to the end of the sentences at all.
Here, for example, is Ms. Borsook's argument against a free-market society in which feeble people are pushed aside without any consideration of their potential as creative human beings:
"The hypersensitive maladaptive no-commercial-potential individuals, the runts of the litter, and the defective members of the species can -- because as humans and not planaria we can value things not just of momentary food/shelter/mate-status-enhancing enticement -- create the best of what makes us remotely human."
Have you given up yet?
Her arguments, too, require some patience. The apparent selfishness of the technology community is at the heart of the book, so Ms. Borsook tries to paint a picture of dot-com billionaires keeping all their money to themselves. Yet in reviewing data on philanthropy in Silicon Valley, she leaves questions dangling and relies on what seems to be less-than-rigorous research.
For example, she writes that in the mid-1990's, the percentage of corporate profits devoted to corporate philanthropy in Silicon Valley dropped. But she quotes statistics collected in 1997 and earlier. What has happened in the past three years, when many companies became even more flush? If recent statistics were not available, surely an analysis of companies' annual reports could have helped fill in the blanks.
The drop also raises questions. Ms. Borsook writes that 1.14 percent of profits in 1993, and 0.92 percent in 1997, were used for philanthropy. That does not sound like a steep decline, but there is no way to imagine otherwise because readers are given no points of comparison in other industries.
It turns out, in fact, that corporate contributions, as a share of earnings, have been declining for a few decades among United States companies. Data from The Conference Board, a nonprofit research group, shows that the numbers dropped from 2.36 percent in 1986, the highest percentage in the past 50 years, to 1.1 percent in 1997. So, yes, Silicon Valley companies look slightly stingier, but the drop may be the result of larger national trends not related to libertarianism, like the research group's finding that companies are starting to give more non-cash gifts.
Ms. Borsook makes other arguments that sound more solid. The software industry, she writes, often congratulates itself for donating thousands of packages of software to schools and nonprofit groups. Yet the donations are often no more than marketing drives that come with a bonus: they provide companies with useful tax deductions.
Beyond the impossible sentences and undeveloped arguments, the book does raise broader questions that are worth asking about the libertarianism of the high-tech industry. If the ideology behind American corporations becomes more and more libertarian, if voters agree that Internet companies should be left alone and then decide to apply that concept to other corporate interests, what does that mean for the social institutions that make up our communities? Will people turn further and further away from schools, from hospitals, from less-than-computer-literate people who need a hand?
Ms. Borsook does not have the answers. But at least she raises the questions. "We can only marvel," she writes, "and be afraid."

HEADLINE: ONLINE SHOPPER;
A Place to Peek Into Lost Luggage

BYLINE: By Michelle Slatalla; E-mail address: Slatalla@nytimes.com

 BODY:
THE last time I was waiting for my luggage at the airport, I saw a cracked leather valise stuffed so full that it might have actually encased a live pig. The frenzied way someone had wrapped twine around the bulging case suggested a disturbing record of attempted escapes.
But then, as the valise traveled around the baggage carousel, I changed my mind. It must have contained something more valuable: otherwise why bother with those additional strips of electrical tape across the locks? After all the other suitcases had been claimed, I decided that it must have belonged to a smuggler apprehended at the gate before he could reclaim his uncut diamonds. Or ivory tusks. Or unpasteurized French cheese. 
 I am fascinated by the mystery of other people's luggage, especially their unclaimed luggage. The glamour tends to fade if the owner shows up and turns out to be the same man who sat a row ahead in economy and begged the flight attendant for extra salted nuts. But luggage that is never reunited with its owner always contains the thrill of the unknown.
So when I learned last week about an online shopping site called Unclaimedbaggage.com, where you can actually buy the contents of unclaimed suitcases, there was no way I could resist. This was something far more tantalizing than the usual discards at a garage sale or thrift store. Here was a rare legal opportunity to riffle through personal items that still had value to their owners at the time they were separated by chance.
"It's like an archaeological dig in the sense that you see a cross-section of the culture when you open up suitcases: the kinds of clothes people are wearing, the books they're reading, the keepsakes they bought on vacation," said Bryan Owens, the owner of the Unclaimed Baggage Center, which operates both the Web site (www.unclaimedbaggage.com) and a block-long retail store in the Appalachian foothills of Scottsboro, Ala. 'We've been doing this for 30 years, and we have long-term, exclusive contracts with many of the major carriers. It's anything you could imagine, although certain things we don't sell. We have an agreement with the F.D.A. to destroy prescription drugs, for instance."
Recovering from my disappointment over the prescription drugs, I went to the site's Click on the Suitcase feature to learn about some of the more unusual items that Unclaimed Baggage has collected over the years. The list included two that had once concealed rolls of money: a Barbie doll (luckily the buyer's daughter pulled off the head by accident, revealing $500 inside the torso) and a "perfectly ordinary soap on a rope" that had been hollowed out.
I was ready to buy. Judging from the home page, which announced "lost treasures from around the world," Mr. Owens is familiar with the psychology of shoppers like me. The site asked: "What do you imagine a wealthy retired couple might have packed to go to Hawaii? An expensive camera?" What would the finely tailored corporate executive flying back from Moscow have had in his suitcases? An elegant cashmere top coat? Gold cuff links?"
Yes, yes, I thought. That's exactly what I would expect! Forgetting for the moment that most suitcases are more likely to harbor items that fall into less savory categories -- like hair care, underwear and tweezers -- I eagerly clicked on Let's Shop. I arrived at 40 categories of merchandise, from Cigars to Jewelry to Women's Closet, in which a total of 344 different items were offered.
Somebody's used cigars? That brought me up short for the same reasons that are causing goose bumps on your arms right now.
But when I examined the nine items for sale in that category, they didn't look used at all. In fact, they were all new: an unopened five-pack of Muriel Air Tip regulars for $1, a new portable pouch called the Humi to keep cigars fresh for $3, a package of pipe filters for $1.
When I asked Mr. Owens, he acknowledged that most of the items online were new and in fact came from unclaimed shipments of cargo, things like unworn bedroom slippers, brand-new baby bottles and unused film that had been lost in transit. Nothing from that finely tailored corporate executive after all, no suits in the women's closet section and certainly no used Barbies or rope soaps.
Mr. Owens said he thought that it would be unfair to sell online shoppers many used items because it was difficult to examine them closely enough online to determine if they met standards of cleanliness. The FAQ section on the site did pose the pertinent question "Is it clean?" (Answer: the store launders or dry-cleans all applicable articles of clothing.) So while the Internet site does sell some mysteries -- like the 40.95-carat emerald offered for $14,750, which would easily enable you to meet the $25 minimum for Internet purchases -- most of the online offerings betrayed no hint of their owner's personality.
In the end, I decided that the online site was not really a place to shop, but more like one of those mystery bags with a question mark stamped on it that you used to get from a vending machine after you paid 50 cents to take a chance on finding treasure. It was a lot of fun, though, to click on the Peek in the Bag feature and see the receipt from a recent purchase: "Kenneth Cole women's shoes $59.40, novelty birthday candles $1, lefty scissors three at 25 cents each."
No pigs, though.

HEADLINE: Sydney Olympics Turns to DNA Ink to Mark Official Souvenirs

BYLINE: By DANIEL SORID 

 BODY:
HIGH technology is nothing new for the Olympics. From finish-line computers to drug tests, the Olympic committee has often been an early adopter. This summer, technology will come into play where it really matters: the sale of souvenirs.
To combat the sale of counterfeit items at the Olympics, the Sydney Olympics organizing committee is using ink containing DNA to mark official merchandise. DNA Technologies of Los Angeles developed the ink, which contains copies of DNA strands from an Australian athlete who has not been identified as well as a chemical that can be easily identified with an optical scanner. 
 DNA Technologies has developed inks, invisible or colored, for about a dozen companies; in some cases, the DNA strands used have come from celebrities.
For the Olympic souvenirs, the special ink is placed either directly on the goods or on a tag attached to them. If an Olympic official suspects that a product is not authentic, the product can be scanned on the spot as a preliminary check. To check the DNA, the product can be sent to the company for an analysis.
Unlike holograms, which can be copied, DNA ink is virtually counterfeit-proof, said Chris Outwater, chief executive of DNA Technologies, because DNA, which contains a person's genetic code, is so complex.
Making the DNA tags is straightforward. According to Mr. Outwater, a DNA sample is taken with either a blood sample or a swab of the mouth, and that DNA is copied many times. Some DNA is kept as an identifier, and some is mixed into the ink to be placed on the merchandise.
"We just need a small fragment," Mr. Outwater said, "to give us enough complexity to stop any counterfeiter or bad person from trying to copy it."
Mr. Outwater said there was one chance in a trillion that a counterfeiter would be able to duplicate a tag because each DNA string used is made up of at least 20 "beads"; each bead can be one of four molecules. Even if counterfeiters knew that the pieces of DNA in the ink were from a particular person's DNA, they would still have to figure out what part of the DNA had been used as a tag. Mr. Outwater gave this analogy: "You're standing out in front of the New York Public Library, and you say to the counterfeiter, 'I'm using one sentence out of one book in that library. You figure it out.' "
Or counterfeiters could presumably clone the DNA in the tags to make their own version of the real ink. But Dr. Rick Tullis, a consultant to the company, said that would not be feasible because the DNA can be treated to make it hard to copy and other pieces of DNA can be included in the solution to foil counterfeiters.
Why go to so much effort? The sale of official merchandise at the Sydney Olympics is expected to reach $36 million, according to the Sydney Olympics organizing committee.
In one example of the severity of the problem with counterfeit products, the Customs Service points out that counterfeit products cost the United States economy around $200 billion a year, more than the annual gross domestic product of Greece.
The technique used by Mr. Outwater's company, which received a contract with the Sydney Olympics organizers in 1998, is not perfected. While the company is making enough DNA tags to mark about 10 million souvenir items for the Olympics, it does not have a handheld device that can verify beyond a doubt that a product is authentic. Authorities doing spot checks of vending areas cannot test for the DNA itself, Mr. Outwater said. To do that, the inspector must send the item to DNA Technologies.
Mr. Outwater says the instant checks have been adequate for the company's customers in the last two years -- no customer has actually sent an item to DNA Technologies for a DNA analysis.
DNA Technologies has made DNA tags for more than just the Olympics. It used DNA tags to mark Mark McGwire's 70th-home-run ball and to protect movie props at Warner Brothers that "tend to walk off the lot," Mr. Outwater said. Warner Brothers hopes that the tags will help the company identify stolen items that are offered for sale.
As more companies turn to the Internet to sell consumer merchandise, there will be a greater push for anti-counterfeit measures like DNA tagging, Mr. Outwater said.
"It's a little more scary to be on the Internet in some virtual store and not know exactly what you're buying," he said. With DNA tags, he contended, "you're going to know that this is an authentic product."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Nations Cutting Aid to the Jobless, Study Says

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH OLSON 

DATELINE: GENEVA, June 21

 BODY:
Seventy-five percent of the world's estimated 150 million unemployed workers have no jobless benefits, and even the most generous countries have been cutting assistance to the unemployed, the International Labor Organization said today in its annual assessment of global working conditions.
The authors of the report said the cutbacks represented a significant threat to economic development because they undermined the financial security of employed workers. 
 Worker protection in today's insecure job environment is essential, said Roger Beattie, the report's chief author, "because people who are well protected are far more willing to accept such changes."
Juan Somavia, director general of the Geneva-based I.L.O., said that recalcitrant countries could "eventually suffer a destructive backlash."
The United Nations agency's World Labor Report 2000 said workers in Europe enjoy the most generous unemployment benefits, but even its wealthy countries reduced them in the 1990's.
The United States also trimmed benefits, and has slipped in a ranking of which countries offer the most generous worker protection, the study reported. Australia, Canada, Ireland, Japan, New Zealand and Britain also provide a lower level of benefits than countries in the top tier of the ranking.
Austria, Belgium, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Iceland, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden and Switzerland make up the top-tier countries with the most benefits for the greatest number of workers.
An entrenched system of benefits in much of Europe, and the resistance to efforts to pare it, have raised criticism that the European countries are too burdened with social costs to compete effectively with more free-wheeling economies.
Mr. Beattie rejected such criticism as "naive" and said that the study indicated that countries can put a secure floor under workers while still growing economically. The I.L.O. study showed that the most generous countries, like Spain, replace 63 percent to 77 percent of wages to the unemployed. New Zealand is among the lowest, at 23 percent wage replacement. Canada and the United States provide about 58 percent replacement of wages.
The two North American countries and Britain, however, also provide unemployment benefits for only 12 months, which is described as short in the report. Also, neither the United States or Canada provides a second layer of unemployment assistance when initial insurance benefits are exhausted.

HEADLINE: In America;
Keeping His Distance

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT 

 BODY:
Gov. George W. Bush chose to stay away from the state convention of the Texas Republican Party last week. If you were trying to sell yourself to American voters as a sane, moderately conservative candidate for president, you'd have stayed away, too.
The rest of the nation is not nearly ready for the zany extremism of the Republican Party in Mr. Bush's home state. The convention was held in Houston, and here are just a few of the items in the platform adopted by the delegates: 
 * The income tax and the Internal Revenue Service should be abolished.
* All minimum wage laws should be repealed.
* The Social Security system should be phased out entirely.
* All U.S. participation in the United Nations should come to an end.
* The North American Free Trade Agreement should be repealed and the United States should withdraw from the World Trade Organization.
* The federal monetary system should return to the gold standard.
They're serious. The hard right rides at a gallop in Texas.
Mr. Bush thought it would be prudent to steer clear of Houston while the convention was under way. He spent his time traveling and raising campaign cash in New England, Ohio, Kentucky and Florida.
It may be odd for a governor to skip the convention of his own state party but Republican politicians in Texas seemed to understand that the potential for embarrassment was great, and it was probably better for Mr. Bush to keep his distance.
For example, even as a national controversy was developing over the planned execution of Gary Graham, the Texas Republicans asserted in their platform that "capital punishment should be swift and unencumbered."
Another item in the platform declared that "homosexual behavior is contrary to the fundamental unchanging truths that have been ordained by God."
The delegates would not let the Texas Log Cabin Republicans set up an information booth inside the convention hall. So the group rented a 25-foot air-conditioned van and drove it around the convention center for three days.
"We got lots of claps and thumbs up," said Steve Labinski, the state president of the gay Republican group.
Governor Bush's wife, Laura, spoke at the convention, and Mr. Bush told the delegates, in a videotaped statement: "I really don't like missing my first Texas state Republican convention since 1990."
That may have been true. But he would have liked even less being badgered by reporters about whether he agreed with some of the wackier aspects of the convention and its platform -- and whether he would fight his party (in Texas or in Congress) whenever he held an opposing view.
Governor, do you agree that we should get rid of the minimum wage? Governor, what would happen to retirees if Social Security were phased out altogether? Governor, how would the federal government be financed if we scrapped the income tax? Governor, do you think we should go back on the gold standard? Isn't that, um, a half-baked idea?
Through a spokesman, the governor made it clear that he wanted nothing to do with the Texas Republican Party platform.
"Let me put it this way," said the spokesman. "Those interested in Governor Bush's positions and platforms should listen to Governor Bush on the campaign trail, or listen to him at the National Republican Convention this summer. He is running on his own positions and agenda items, on issues like improving education, economic opportunity and national defense.
"The state party platform, which the governor was not involved in drafting, was created by approximately 8,000 delegates and should be viewed as a broad statement of philosophy. But, again, for those interested in the Bush agenda, they should pay attention to Governor Bush."
Other high-profile Texan Republicans, including Senators Phil Gramm and Kay Bailey Hutchison, attended the convention and made speeches. But, of course, they're not running for president.
The Texas Republican who is running for president ran as far from the weirdness of his own party's convention as he could get.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Shares Rise as Microsoft Rallies on Delay in Restrictions

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Microsoft helped propel the Dow Jones industrial average and the Nasdaq composite index higher yesterday after a federal judge delayed business restrictions against the software company.
The Nasdaq rose for the fifth consecutive day, very nearly returning to where it began the year. The index, which has steadily recovered from steep losses in April and May, is now less than six points below its Dec. 31, 1999, close. At its low point on May 23, the Nasdaq was down 28.6 percent for the year. 
 "We're seeing the continued shift out of industrial and value companies and into growth companies," said Tom Galvin, chief equity strategist at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette in New York. Yet he pointed out that without Microsoft, market averages would have barely budged yesterday, suggesting that investors remained uncertain.
The Nasdaq composite index rose 50.65 points, or 1.3 percent, to 4,064.01. The index closed at 4,069.31 on Dec. 31. Even with the comeback, Nasdaq is still 19.5 percent below its record of 5,048.62 reached March 10.
The Dow Jones industrial average gained 62.58 points, or 0.6 percent, to 10,497.74 and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 3.18 points, to 1,479.13.
Microsoft climbed 5 3/4, to 80 11/16. In a surprise move late Tuesday afternoon, a federal judge said he would delay sanctions against the company while it appealed the antitrust decision that could force it to be broken in two. The judge's initial ruling called for certain business restraints to be in effect by Sept. 5. Also, the judge sent the case directly to the Supreme Court, but it is uncertain just how quickly the case could be resolved.
The Supreme Court is in the last two weeks of its 1999-2000 term, so the justices, if they accept the case, may not rule for some time.
The broader technology sector was mixed. Handspring, which makes the Visor hand-held electronic organizer, a competitor of the Palm Pilot, made a solid if unremarkable debut on the Nasdaq. Shares were priced at 20 and rose to 261 5/16.
Oracle was lower for most of the day before finishing with a gain of 9/64, closing at 86 3/16. After the close of trading Tuesday, the company announced fiscal fourth-quarter results that beat expectations.
Oracle shares have run up substantially in recent weeks, however, prompting some investors to take profits. Also, analysts said some investors may have been disappointed by the relatively slow growth of Oracle's core database business.
Investors are scouring corporate earnings reports for any signs of weakness and have proved themselves ready to punish any company that misses analysts' estimates or shows any sign of slowing growth.
"We're in a period where investors recognize that the economy is slowing, but they understand that there will be some potholes along the way," Mr. Galvin said.
Rising interest rates have begun hurting profits at a wide range of companies, and investors remain unsure whether the Federal Reserve has finished increasing rates.
The central bank, which has increased rates six times in the last year in a bid to contain inflation, will meet again next week, and anticipation of that meeting is keeping many investors on the sidelines, analysts said.

Treasury Prices Drop
 (By Bloomberg News) -- Treasury bond prices fell sharply as higher oil prices fanned concern that inflation would accelerate.
"Oil has got to be a concern," and will likely lead to more Federal Reserve interest rate increases, said John Poole, who manages $10 billion at Mellon Private Asset Management in Boston.
Longer-dated securities, among the most sensitive to inflation, led Treasuries lower. The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 1 1/32, to 1033 1/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 5.96 percent from 5.89 percent on Tuesday.
The price of the 10-year Treasury note fell 2 1/32, to 102 28/32. The note's yield rose to 6.10 percent from 6.01 percent on Tuesday.
Treasuries have fallen in recent days on speculation that the Fed's rate increases might not have done as much to slow growth and quell inflation as was shown in last month's economic reports.

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES;
Ronnie Spector, Just Walking in a Rainbow

BYLINE: By JAN HOFFMAN 

 BODY:
CAN you just stay focused, sweetheart?" Jonathan Greenfield says tersely to his wife as they settle into a hotel lobby in Danbury, Conn., near their home. "It's so important for you to listen to the question and not just open your guts." He apologizes for his wife, whom he manages professionally. "We always have this discussion!"
Ronnie Spector Greenfield is nervous and certainly scattered, but if her thoughts, rendered in a froggy smoker's voice, scamper off in exultation, why not? 
 After all, a 13-year-old lawsuit over royalties from songs she recorded when she was clambering out of her teens has just been resolved in her favor.
It turns out that for such ringing, glorious 60's hits like "Be My Baby," "Baby I Love You" and "Walking in the Rain," Ronnie and the Ronettes, the shimmying bad girls once so famous that their opening act was the Rolling Stones, received only a one-time check of $14,482.30 from Phil Spector, Mrs. Greenfield's former husband. Last week, a New York State Supreme Court justice ruled that Mr. Spector, who repackaged the Ronettes' songs for oldies collections, commercials and movies like "Dirty Dancing," owed Mrs. Greenfield and the Ronettes -- her sister and cousin -- $2.6 million.
"I'm amazed it's over," says Mrs. Greenfield, 56, who still wears her luxuriant dark hair long, as she did as a teenager, her eyes made up with liquid black liner, her much-imitated look. Even now, a mother of two teenagers, she has an irrepressible girlish eagerness that is endearing and, despite her flinty ambition, vulnerable. "I can have my career back!"
Getting her career back has pretty much been her goal since that morning in 1972 when Ronnie Spector finally got her husband's permission to take a sunlit stroll. She walked out of the gloomy, guarded Beverly Hills mansion barefoot so as not to arouse his suspicions and just kept going. Mr. Spector later paid her divorce lawyers in nickels and stamped her alimony checks with an expletive.
As Mrs. Greenfield wrote in her 1990 autobiography, "Be My Baby" (with a foreword by Cher, another comeback queen who knows from Svengalis), the brilliant Mr. Spector adored her voice and what she calls her "Spanish Harlem half-breedishness." Her mother, a hard-working waitress, was black and American Indian, her father, a happy-go-lucky drinker and unemployed drummer, was white.
IT all crested when the Fabulous Ronettes were touring England and "Be My Baby" was a worldwide hit. She was 20.
"This is what I was waiting for all my life," she says with a throaty laugh. "I was in love with the man I adored and he even flew over to England to see me. And Phil hates to fly.
"And there was my audience! The applause! We had girls who wanted to wear their hair like us, in beehives, the Chinese bangs, the long braid! The kids would be screaming and tearing your clothes off! I loved it! 'Want my shirt? Here! Want a shoe? Here!' "
In 1968, after the Ronettes dissolved, the couple married. She has often described her reclusive, gilded life. His gift of a Camaro came with a mannequin in the passenger seat wearing Mr. Spector's trademark cap, so it would always look as if he was accompanying her. Opera, which she hates, resounded through their home. He repeatedly made her sit through screenings of "Citizen Kane."
"That girl couldn't sing," Mrs. Greenfield says, hurt shadowing her face. "Was Phil trying to tell me something?"
Bored, isolated: "I'd get drunk so I could go to rehab, just to get out of the house." She adds brightly, "I got to hear Carole King's 'Tapestry' in rehab!"
After she left Mr. Spector, she asked the impresario Murray the K for work. "I'm only 29 but I'm an oldie but goodie? I just poured vodka into my soda."
Yet she was plucky and blessed with a much-admired sin-'n'-innocence tremolo. Billy Joel wrote "Say Goodbye to Hollywood" for her. She toured with oldies shows and Bruce Springsteen's E Street Band. Last fall she released a five-song collection, "She Talks to Rainbows," whose co-producer was Joey Ramone. She kept bobbing back up, even performing for President Clinton (who greeted her, arms wide, singing, "Be my little baby!").
In 1980, at 36, she met Mr. Greenfield, 15 years her junior, who had seen her show when he was a smoldering, smitten teenager. "He didn't pull on me right away like most guys," Mrs. Greenfield says. "So we were friends first. If I thought a date was trying to kiss me before we went out to dinner, I'd call up Jonathan and say, 'I need you to fix something!' And he would get rid of the guy for me."
When she credits Mr. Greenfield for the lawsuit, he erupts, excoriating her low self-esteem, but ending with a pep talk. "You were the trailblazer 35 years ago and after you filed the lawsuit, you wouldn't go away! That's what the Bad Girl is about!"
Ronnie, how have you changed?
"I'm my own person," she replies. "I was so controlled by Phil and now I have my own ideas. With this lawsuit over, I'm only looking forward: to my future, to singing rock 'n' roll."
"That's beautiful, sweetheart," her husband says.
Last month, along with singers like Mary Chapin Carpenter and Sheryl Crow, Mrs. Greenfield appeared at a House subcommittee hearing on a new copyright law. When she was introduced, she broke into "Wuh-uh-uh-oh, be my, be my baby," startling her buttoned-up audience. "I just felt the urge," she explains. Afterward, she was swarmed by autograph seekers. "I saw Mary Bono and said: 'Hi! How are the kids?' "

HEADLINE: A New Math: Fewer Airlines + Higher Profits = More Competition

BYLINE: By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

 BODY:
James E. Goodwin, the chief executive of the UAL Corporation, the parent of United Airlines, describes his proposed $4.3 billion purchase of US Airways as a "win-win for consumers" that will usher in a glorious new era of global air service.
But many passengers see the proposed merger rather differently. For them, air travel is already a grim reality of high fares, interminable check-in lines, overcrowded planes, endless delays and in-flight meals that are stingy when they are offered at all. "I look at fares now, especially for business trips, and they are outrageous," said Linda Kurz, an executive assistant in Manhattan. 
 Those two visions are on a collision course in Washington, where Mr. Goodwin and Stephen M. Wolf, the chairman of US Airways, have already faced a hostile Congress at several hearings. At issue is whether the airline industry, a generation after the 1978 deregulation law prompted a wave of industry consolidation, will best serve consumers if it is allowed to become even more concentrated.
The United-US Airways deal, if approved by regulators, would create a winged giant that would carry one quarter of the nation's air traffic. The proposal has set off a frenzy of merger talks that many are convinced could reduce the country's six largest carriers to three mega-airlines. That prospect alarms consumer advocates and lawmakers who already complain that there is too little competition.
"There will be no loss of competition if this merger goes through," Representative Leonard L. Boswell, Democrat of Iowa, said with more than a touch of irony, "because there is no competition now."
Representative Ray LaHood, Republican of Illinois, was even more disturbed. "I think the flying public is in for some real, real horror stories, worse than they have ever experienced," he said, adding that Congress does not have the power to stop the merger.
The Justice Department will decide whether the combination hinders competition. But opponents and backers of the deal agree that it may rise and fall on public opinion and election-year politics.
Several lawmakers have written to the Justice Department urging it to look carefully at the effect of the merger on the structure of the entire industry. A group of senators led by Ron Wyden, Democrat of Oregon, asked the Transportation Department's inspector general to investigate the degree to which airline mergers adversely affect customer service. And attorneys general from 20 states have joined forces to oppose the deal.
For its part, UAL, already the nation's largest airline, has enlisted a small army of lobbyists to make its case. Mr. Goodwin is now devoting nearly all his time to talking to anyone in Washington who will listen.
By any measure, this is a terrible moment to propose an airline merger. The major carriers have faced a growing chorus of critics and government challenges in the last six years.
As business fares rose to record highs in the mid-1990's, many cities and states came to resent the way large airlines dominated major metropolitan airports.
Studies show that fares are much higher at such hubs than at airports with more carriers. In Minneapolis, for example, where Northwest Airlines is the biggest airline by far, fares on average were 49 percent higher than at comparable airports with greater competition.
The major airlines were also accused of preying on new low-fare competitors. The Justice Department sued American Airlines in May 1999, accusing it of illegally driving a small competitor out of its Dallas-Fort Worth hub and then raising prices. American denies any wrongdoing and is fighting the government in court.
The Justice Department filed suit in 1998 to force Northwest to sell its controlling stake in Continental Airlines. It charged that the deal would lead to higher ticket prices and diminished service for millions of passengers. That case is scheduled to go to trial later this year.
Complaints about airlines rose to such a level last year that Congress came close to passing legislation mandating specific levels of service. The industry headed that off by submitting a voluntary set of standards, promising, among other things, to respond to complaints within 60 days and to allow consumers to hold reservations for 24 hours.
Nevertheless, complaints are at a high, rising over 130 percent in the 12 months that ended in April.
Both United and US Airways score at or near the bottom in industry measures of service compiled by the Transportation Department. United was ranked seventh and US Airways eighth in on-time arrivals for the 12 months that ended in April, according to the latest statistics.
"How they could come forward with this deal in an environment like this leaves you scratching your head," said Kevin P. Mitchell, chairman of the Business Travel Coalition, which represents corporate airline customers.
One explanation is that airline executives live in a world of statistics while passengers tend to remember individual flights. United flew 89 million passengers last year, so it is not surprising to Mr. Goodwin that some had problems. He acknowledged in an interview that United needs to improve its service, but he said that according to data compiled by the industry for internal use, United ranks at the top.
Mr. Goodwin and other airline executives point out that the number of passengers nearly tripled to 635 million last year compared with 240 million in 1977, before the industry was deregulated, but average fares, adjusted for inflation, declined 40 percent in the same period. Still, the complex way the industry sets fares, which seem to change by the minute, has fueled broad resentment among consumers.
"The problem with the airline industry," said Leo F. Mullin, the chief executive of Delta Air Lines, "is that it gets killed by anecdotes."
Most airline executives and industry analysts on Wall Street believe that consolidation is inevitable. Industry profit margins, even in the best years, are about 5 percent compared with an average at least twice that for the companies included in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index.
United argues that combining with US Airways will give it a strong presence along the East Coast, where it is weak. That will be a boon for consumers, the airline said, because the new United would be able to offer service on 560 city-to-city routes, like Sacramento to Erie, Pa., and Fargo, N.D., to Panama City, Fla., that neither it nor US Airways currently serves. Together with its international partners, United said it would also be able to offer "seamless" service to numerous destinations in Europe and Asia.
But critics say the deal will only force United's rivals to get bigger, too. Within days of United's announcement, the AMR Corporation, the parent of American Airlines, the country's second-largest airline, entered into merger discussions with both Northwest and Delta.
Many analysts believe that AMR will ultimately seek to merge with No. 4 Northwest, while No. 3 Delta will try to combine with No. 5 Continental Airlines. That would create three giants carrying 80 percent of all passengers.
Some airline executives argue that having three truly national carriers competing head to head in every city would be an improvement on the situation today, in which the six airlines have hegemony over so-called fortress hubs at major metropolitan airports.
But Samuel Buttrick, an airline analyst with PaineWebber in New York, called the notion that three big carriers would offer more competition than six independent airlines "borderline lunacy."
He said that "more competitors means more supply, means more choice at better prices."
Many consumers agree. "Right now all the airlines have to compete for the same dollar," said Wally Thompson, a salesman in Manhattan. "Once they don't have to compete, prices will go up."
To mute criticism, United has pledged not to lay off any of the 40,000 US Airways employees and has also vowed not to increase fares for two years after the deal is consummated. In addition, because a combined United-US Airways would dominate air travel in the Washington area, US Airways has agreed to sell most of its operations at Ronald Reagan National Airport to Robert L. Johnson, the founder of Black Entertainment Television and a US Airways director.
But many executives and analysts believe the fare freeze is meaningless because United has said it reserves the right to raise prices in response to inflation and fuel costs. Executives at rival airlines also said that United would ultimately be forced to abandon some of the US Airways hub airports to justify the expense of the deal.
DC Air, Mr. Johnson's new airline, has also been heavily criticized as a ploy to keep valuable assets at National Airport out of the hands of United's strongest competitors. There are also concerns that DC Air, which will depend on United for all its services from ticketing to maintenance, will not be a truly independent competitor. And even if it is, United would still be the clearly dominant airline in Washington.
And bigger is not necessarily better for frequent fliers, including some in Congress.
"I'm a two-million-mile customer of United," Representative Peter A. DeFazio, Democrat of Oregon, told Mr. Goodwin. "I want a reasonable price, and I want better service. I am not so concerned about the seamlessness of my international and national travel. That's what travel agents are for."

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Equality in hiring remains the key to civil rights goals.

BYLINE: By Alan B. Krueger; This column appears here every Thursday. Alan B. Krueger is the Bendheim Professor of Economics and Public Affairs at Princeton University and editor of The Journal of Economic Perspectives. Four economic analysts -- Professor Krueger, Hal R. Varian, Jeff Madrick and Virginia Postrel -- rotate as contributors.

 BODY:
WHEN he voted against the Civil Rights Act of 1964, Barry Goldwater declared, "The problems of discrimination cannot be cured by laws alone."
More than three decades of experience suggests that Goldwater was wrong, although not entirely. There is abundant evidence that the act did much to improve prospects for blacks, but as the continuing series in The New York Times on race in America makes clear, discrimination persists, taking on more subtle forms that are less amenable to correction by legislation. Still, existing laws could combat discrimination more effectively. 
 Title VII of the Civil Rights Act, which took effect 35 years ago next month, prohibited employment discrimination and established the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission. The first studies on the law's economic impact were conducted by Richard Freeman of Harvard and Orley Ashenfelter of Princeton in the early 1970's. They found that after 15 years of stagnation, black men's earnings increased relative to those of whites shortly after the act took effect, with the median earnings gap closing from 36 percent in 1965 to 26 percent in 1975. Gains were particularly large for black professionals. The timing suggests, but certainly does not prove, that the Civil Rights Act was responsible for the improvement.
Professors Freeman and Ashenfelter were quickly criticized by both the right and the left. From the right, critics argued that the narrowing gap was a mirage -- that low-wage workers, who were disproportionately black, were induced to drop out of the labor market by expanded income-transfer programs. The average wage of black workers rose, it was argued, because many who would have earned low wages left the labor force. Others argued that improvements in African-American education and Northern migration were responsible. Some left-wing critics argued that the strong economy, not civil rights legislation, had lifted the earnings of blacks.
Underlying these criticisms was the belief of the right that job discrimination could not persist in a competitive economy because employers would bid up the wages of minorities if they were equally productive but less well paid, and the left's belief that more government intervention was needed to make a real dent in discrimination.
The accumulating evidence has convinced most critics that the Civil Rights Act was a principal cause of black progress. The black-white earnings gap continued to narrow until the mid-1970's, in both strong and weak economic times. Several studies, including a recent working paper by Chinhui Juhn of the University of Houston, found that labor market dropouts accounted for only a small part of the narrowing. The gap shrank most impressively in the South, for workers in all age groups, suggesting that educational improvements and migration were not primarily responsible.
It is possible that the earnings gap shrank because of deeper changes in society -- the very forces that led to the enactment of the Civil Rights Act. But a 1998 study by Kenneth Chay of the University of California at Berkeley found that when smaller establishments became covered by the act in 1972, the employment and pay of black workers increased in them more than in establishments that were already covered. Because societal forces operated on both large and small employers, coverage by the Civil Rights Act made the difference.
The improvement in the relative economic status of African-Americans halted in the mid-1970's, especially for college graduates, and the earnings gap increased slightly in the 1980's. Strong economic growth in the late 1990's helped return the black-white wage gap for men to about where it was at the end of the 1970's. For black women, who have a smaller earnings gap than do black men, the gap has continued to widen slowly.
Progress in narrowing the gap slowed primarily as a byproduct of forces that caused rising wage dispersion throughout the American economy.
To some extent, the Civil Rights Act has also been a victim of its own success. The early cases brought under the law were predominantly class- action suits against employers who refused to hire African-Americans in higher-paying jobs and industries, like steel and aircraft manufacturing.
The nature of litigation has changed. Research by John Donohue III and Peter Siegelman published in the Stanford Law Review found that in 1966, charges of racial discrimination involving hiring outnumbered those involving firing by 50 percent. In 1999 firing cases outnumbered hiring cases by more than six to one. The number of class-action suits, though up in the last five years, declined from a peak of 1,100 in 1975 to 28 in 1999.
Antidiscrimination policy works best when it opens doors and gives people a chance to prove their mettle. Studies in which paired black and white job seekers apply for the same job routinely turn up evidence of bias in hiring. But cases involving individual discharges are easier and less costly for lawyers to pursue. This is unfortunate because "abuses of the system are greater on the firing side, and the potential for achieving the goals of the legislation are greater on the hiring side," Professor Donohue said.
Concerns about possible litigation over future discharges could also discourage employers from taking a chance on minority job applicants in the first place.
To make the Civil Rights Act more effective, Professor Donohue proposes doubling or tripling damages in discriminatory hiring cases, as is done in antitrust cases, and curtailing punitive damages on the discharge side.
But Paul Steven Miller, a commissioner with the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, said he was concerned that different penalties for hiring and firing cases would send a signal that some forms of employment discrimination are more offensive than others. Instead, he favors increased technical assistance for minority job applicants, greater use of programs to send matched-race testers to apply for jobs and affirmative action to identify and reduce racial bias in hiring.
Still, it is hard to argue with Professor Donohue when he says, "It would be a shame if Title VII of the Civil Rights Act, which embodies one of the most noble ideas of the 20th century, becomes used primarily as a way for less competent workers to hang on to their jobs or walk away with a sizable, undeserved severance package."
