HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES;
OPEC Agrees to 2.5% Increase in Output

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS and NEELA BANERJEE 

DATELINE: VIENNA, June 21

 BODY:
In a grudging move to rein in soaring oil prices, ministers at the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries decided today to increase their production limits by about 708,000 barrels a day, or 2.5 percent, beginning July 1.
The increase, OPEC's second in three months, is slightly higher than had been expected. But analysts said it remained too modest to bring down gasoline prices that have reached more than $2 a gallon in some parts of the United States. 
 Given that member countries are already overshooting their official production quotas, analysts said that today's move largely amounts to a ratification of existing practices.
As a practical matter, any increased production in crude oil will take at least two months to work its way through the refining system and will not reach gasoline pumps until after the summer driving season is largely over.
"They are officializing what they are already producing," said Roger Diwan, an analyst at the Petroleum Finance Corporation, an industry consulting firm in Washington. "It's the minimum that could have been done."
Indeed, oil ministers meeting here in Vienna went out of their way to place much of the blame for high gasoline prices on regulations and refining problems in the United States as well as extremely high gasoline taxes across much of Europe.
"People in consuming countries point their finger at OPEC," complained Rilwanu Lukman, the organization's secretary general. "These people should tackle their own countries."
But many oil ministers have themselves been baffled by the extent to which prices have remained high. One senior official here complained that buying and selling in the petroleum markets has caused unjustifiable price swings from as low as $24 to as high as $33 since OPEC raised production at the end of March.
Production has increased more than two million barrels a day since the end of March, yet crude oil prices have rebounded and inventories are still at their lowest levels in years.
For all their caution, oil ministers meeting here displayed far more solidarity than they did three months ago, when Iran angrily rebelled against Saudi Arabian pressure to raise production by about 7 percent, or a total of 1.7 million barrels a day.
Today, Iran signed on without any objections to the new increase while also formally accepting the last one as well. By avoiding a replay of the bitter rift in March, the OPEC ministers, who control about 40 percent of the global supply of oil, easily reached a consensus in one day.
"Today, everybody I think is of the opinion that an increase was necessary," said Khelil Chakib, Algeria's oil minister, who predicted that the price of crude oil would soon decline from more than $30 a barrel to less than $28.
"The question was how big the increase should be," Mr. Chakib added. "I think this is about the right volume because we have got to consider manufacturers, the supply-demand behavior and the growth of world consumption."
That attitude reflects a significant change in the mindset within OPEC. As recently as three months ago, many producer countries were still terrified that any increase in production would lead to a catastrophic decline in prices similar to one in 1998, when oil fell to the $10-a-barrel level at one point.
But when oil prices jumped back to more than $30 a barrel after the last production increase, exporting countries became increasingly more confident.
At the same time, more countries now agree with Saudi Arabian leaders that current prices are too high to be stable and would over time cause economic slowdowns in consuming countries that could hurt OPEC members by lowering global demand for their oil.
As one official from a non-OPEC producing country remarked today: "When the price of crude on the market is $33, everybody can afford to be friends."
World oil markets brushed off the production increase announced today, sending prices up. Crude oil prices on the New York Mercantile Exchange jumped about 2 percent, or 72 cents, to $31.37 a barrel.
OPEC ministers essentially conceded today that they had given up their plan for an "automatic" adjustment if oil prices ranged outside a band of $22 to $28 a barrel.
Member countries had agreed to the band in March, but when the 20-day average price of oil exceeded $28 a barrel two weeks ago, the organization did not impose any increase.
"Forget about bands," Mr. Lukman told reporters after the oil ministers adjourned their meeting. "Focus on the fact that OPEC wants a price of around $25 a barrel."
OPEC's influence on the global supply of oil is immense. It plays a crucial role as a swing producer that can pump or withhold additional oil. All other producers are already pumping at maximum capacity.
Indeed, many OPEC members are already at or near their own maximum capacity. But the countries that still have extra capacity are among its biggest producers: Saudi Arabia, which pumps about 8 million barrels a day; Kuwait, which pumps about 2 million barrels; and the United Arab Emirates, which pumps about 2.2 million barrels.
Iran, which produces about 3.6 million barrels a day, is believed to be near maximum capacity. But Iran's oil minister, Bijan Namdar Zangeneh, insisted this evening that his country could meet its new quotas.
"We have enough capacity," Mr. Sangeneh said at the start of the minister's meeting. "We can comply fully with our commitments within OPEC."
A few important non-OPEC producers, mainly Mexico and Norway, are expected to increase production as well. Both countries copied the production cuts that OPEC members adopted in March 1999, which helped prices more than triple to a high of $34, the highest in nearly a decade.
Further non-OPEC production could add another 300,000 barrels of oil a day, bringing the total supply of new oil to 600,000 or 700,000 barrels a day.
In Washington, the Clinton administration greeted OPEC's decision with cautious praise. The White House has kept a decidedly low profile in the last few weeks, in sharp contrast to the relentless and very public lobbying conducted by Secretary of Energy Bill Richardson before OPEC's meeting in March.
Mr. Richardson's lobbying campaign, which included telephone calls to OPEC ministers while they were meeting in Vienna, irritated many countries and provoked especially loud denunciations from Iran about "external pressure."
Mr. Richardson expressed a measured endorsement of OPEC's decision today, calling it "a positive, though modest step that we hope will lead to more stable oil markets and lower oil prices at the pump."
Gary N. Ross, head of PIRA Energy, an energy consulting firm in New York, was more skeptical and predicted that today's move would do little to minimize American motorist anger, particularly in the Midwest where gasoline prices have surpassed $2 a gallon.
"World demand will go up by 1.5 million barrels a day in the third quarter compared to the second quarter," Mr. Ross predicted here today. "So we are not going to get the supply to increase stock-building. This is not going to make Al Gore or the U.S. government very happy."

HEADLINE: Summit Glow Fades as Koreans Face Obstacles to Unity

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, June 21

 BODY:
The euphoria that followed the summit meeting between North and South Korea last week has started to fade as their leaders face the reality of trying to reunite two countries with a common ancestry and language but drastically different ideologies and fortunes.
Although foreign diplomats and political experts say the prospects of peace and reconciliation on the Korean Peninsula remain promising, antagonistic statements in both countries in recent days underscore the inevitable difficulties that North and South face in trying to overcome five decades as ideological enemies. 
 This week, the official North Korean news agency released numerous provocative declarations, some old and some new, by the country's leader, Kim Jong Il, admonishing North Koreans not to stray from the principles of the Communist revolution.
"We must create a self-sufficient and strong nation and not yield to economic reforms and market openings that would certainly lead to our destruction," Mr. Kim said in a rebroadcast of a 1999 speech on Tuesday, a day after the United States had removed sanctions on nonmilitary trade with North Korea.
In a broadcast today, the North Korean Foreign Ministry demanded that all sanctions be lifted and that the United States stop being "hostile."
On Sunday, North Korea said the United States, which has 37,000 troops in South Korea, had increased the likelihood of war on the peninsula.
The diatribe, which political experts said was intended to appease North Korean hard-liners and project an image of strength, was a sharp contrast to the conciliatory gestures that Kim Jong Il and President Kim Dae Jung of South Korea traded at their talks in Pyongyang.
The two leaders signed an accord that called for closer ties, economic cooperation and eventual reunification.
But the North's shift in tone has been no more caustic than a barrage of criticism that South Korea's main political opposition has levied against the Communist country and the agreement forged there.
While acknowledging the significance of the summit meeting, leaders of the opposition Grand National Party said that North Korea remained a dangerous state and that the talks had failed to address important issues like the North's nuclear and missile programs and the costs of reunification.
"Kim Jong Il is very good at putting on a show," Chung Hyung Keun, a legislator of the opposition Grand National Party, said. "But he is an old-line Communist leader who believes that he can make the South his own at any time, and that is very dangerous."
Foreign and Korean experts said the verbal jabs had provided a much-needed reality check to the mass euphoria after the summit sessions and pointed to some of the difficulties ahead.
"I think that both sides are working hard to achieve peace, but we can't expect them to abandon their political systems and party-line rhetoric overnight," said a European ambassador.
Indeed, no one expects reunification of the peninsula soon. The stark economic differences between the two Koreas and astronomical costs of merging them make reunification a distant prospect.
Fueled by foreign investment, open markets, advanced technology and entrepreneurial spirit, South Korea has become one of the world's most economically successful democracies.
But North Korea, by all accounts, is in dire straits. Inefficient agriculture and devastating floods have created severe food shortages. Most of its factories are dormant.
In most regions, there are virtually no paved roads, telephones or public transportation. Economists have estimated that it could cost hundreds of billions of dollars to integrate the two.
How fast the two countries unify would largely depend on what political changes occur in North Korea. Because North Korea remains closed to the outside world, little is known about what effects the summit meeting has had there.
South Korean envoys who attended the sessions said it was widely reported in newspapers and on radio and television in Pyongyang.
But political experts said because Kim Jong Il's government so tightly controlled what North Koreans see and think and the country has been isolated so long, the meetings were highly unlikely to have significant political effects soon.
"Kim Jong Il's power has never been stronger, despite his people's dismal economic situation," said Jo Dong Ho, an economist for the Korean Development Institute, a private think tank in Seoul. "For change to take place, North Koreans have to become aware that their difficulties arise from bad governance. But most of them still believe that Kim Jong Il is great and all people on this planet worship him."
But the meeting may have had some repercussions in the North.
"We support the notion that Kim Dae Jung's visit created a lot of excitement in North Korea and that the recent broadcasts reasserting revolutionary principles were designed to calm the excitement there that reunification was near," said Yoon Young Joong, who monitors North Korean broadcasts for the Unification Ministry in South Korea.
North Korea's propagandistic broadcasts are also being put forward by South Korea's political opposition as evidence that Kim Jong Il has not changed his ways.
The opposition has criticized Kim Dae Jung for not using the meetings to focus on the hundreds of thousands of North Koreans who international aid workers estimate have died because of famine and floods and the government's failure to adopt agricultural and market reforms.
Opposition politicians also accused South Korean media of presenting an unrealistically positive view of the summit meetings.
"Just recently," Mr. Chung said, "the South Korean media were filled with images of starving North Korean children eating worms from the ground just outside Pyongyang and elsewhere around the country. But now the media have stopped showing these atrocities, and the only thing they show are pretty images of Pyongyang."

HEADLINE: North Korea's Missile Pledge Paves the Way for New Talks

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Thursday, June 22

 BODY:
North Korea has reaffirmed its pledge to the United States to stop flight-testing its long-range missile, paving the way for talks very soon with the Clinton administration on further curbs on the missile program, a senior administration official said today.
The North Korean announcement came after the administration lifted some economic sanctions on Monday and was welcomed as a "positive statement of their commitment," the official said. 
 But the North Korean pledge did not alter the administration's resolve to move ahead with its missile defense program, which has been largely justified on the assumption that North Korea could have the ability to hit the United States with nuclear or chemical-tipped ballistic missiles by 2005, the official said.
Flight-testing is only one element of North Korea's missile development and such concerns as engine-testing and improving launching sites by the North Koreans will be addressed in the coming talks, the official said.
Speaking en route to China with Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright, the official said that in return for the reaffirmation, announced in Pyongyang, the North Korean capital, on Wednesday, the United States would announce specific dates for the resumption of talks between North Korea and Washington.
These talks could begin as soon as the end of the month, officials said. The first round of talks took place in March last year in Pyongyang.
In the coming session, the United States will deal with North Korea's "development, deployment, testing and export of missiles," as well as the country's nuclear program, the senior official said. One goal of the talks is to seek "verification" of North Korean pledges.
Since the summit meeting of North and South Korean leaders last week, Pentagon officials have emphasized that although North Korea agreed last fall to suspend the testing of the Taepodong 1 missile it fired over Japan in 1998 -- a suspension it reaffirmed on Wednesday -- the North Korean military has not suspended development of a new generation of missiles known as the Taepodong 2.
A National Intelligence Estimate last year concluded that by 2005 North Korea could complete development of the Taepodong 2, a missile capable of reaching the United States with a nuclear warhead.
A new estimate is being prepared for President Clinton, officials said last week, and is expected to reach similar conclusions.
As Dr. Albright landed here to meet with Chinese leaders on a range of issues, her aides sought to walk a fine line between lauding the outcome of the landmark summit meeting between the two Koreas last week and keeping a lid on what Washington sees as misplaced euphoria.
The officials were also anxious to make clear that the United States had its own lines of communication with North Korea, separate and apart from what went on at the summit meeting in Pyongyang.
Thus the senior official, who briefed reporters on Dr. Albright's plane, said that Wednesday's statement reaffirming the moratorium of flight tests was part of a choreographed script worked out between the United States and North Korea at talks in Rome at the end of May.
The agreement there, the official said, was that Mr. Clinton would formalize the easing of sanctions, the North Koreans would reconfirm their moratorium, and then the United States would move ahead with the dates of the missile talks.
Behind these steps lies the overall strategy worked out by Mr. Clinton's special envoy to North Korea, former Defense Secretary William J. Perry. That strategy revolves around a finely tuned series of moves to lift sanctions as North Korea begins to freeze its nuclear arsenal and end sales of missile technology to countries Washington suspects of sponsoring terrorism.
But the three days of amiability at the Korean summit meeting surprised the administration and left officials faced with uncomfortable diplomatic pressure to ease up on its missile defense program just as the American presidential election is about to get under way.
Some of Washington's NATO allies have questioned whether the North Korean missile threat was serious enough to deploy a missile defense shield that antagonizes Russia and China.
Despite the administration's unchanged position on North Korea's missile capacity, Dr. Albright's aides said they noted that the tone of the statement from Pyongyang was more generous than in the past. For example, the senior official said that the statement used the firmer word "moratorium" rather than "suspension," which was used by the North Koreans last fall.
The statement also said that the easing of sanctions would have "a positive effect" on plans for a senior North Korean official to visit the United States for talks with the administration. Such a meeting has been broached for some time but has yet to take place.
The statement concluded with an appeal to the United States to honor North Korea's sovereignty and improve bilateral relations so that North Korea could then "work to clear the United States of its worries." Asked what this phrase meant, a State Department official said, "It's nice, but we don't know." After her quick visit to China, which is scheduled to last less than 36 hours, Dr. Albright will fly to Seoul to learn firsthand details of the summit meeting from South Korea's President, Kim Dae Jung.

HEADLINE: METRO BRIEFING

BYLINE: Compiled by Anthony Ramirez

 BODY:

NEW YORK
 
MANHATTAN: LAZIO'S TAX RETURNS -- Calling reports of Representative Rick A. Lazio's stock profits "deeply troubling," the chairwoman of the New York State Democratic Committee, Judith Hope, challenged the Republican Senate candidate yesterday to release his income tax returns. The New York Times reported on Friday that Mr. Lazio had made a 600 percent profit on stock he bought in 1997 in Quick & Reilly, a brokerage controlled by some of his campaign contributors. A spokesman said Mr. Lazio would release his returns "as soon as possible." Eric Lipton (NYT)
 
MANHATTAN: GRAVANO ALLEGATION -- Salvatore Gravano, left, the Mafia turncoat who testified against John J. Gotti, plotted to kill Ronald L. Kuby, a lawyer who represents the survivors of some of Mr. Gravano's murder victims, according to court papers. Mr. Gravano, whose ferocity earned him the nickname Sammy the Bull and who left New York under the cloak of the federal witness protection program to start a new life, was arrested in Arizona in February on charges that he was running a multimillion-dollar drug ring. William K. Rashbaum (NYT) 

MANHATTAN: STEALING FROM THE DEAD -- Two attendants from the city morgue were arrested yesterday on charges that they pilfered sunglasses, a small cassette player, a flashlight, a fanny pack and $3 from the Sheepshead Bay apartment of a dead man they were to transport, the police said. The two men tried to hide the items in the mortuary bag with the body. A police officer guarding the dead man's residence said he saw Edward Rodriguez, 40, and Ruben Barrios, 50, both of Brooklyn, steal the items. William K. Rashbaum (NYT)
 
MANHATTAN: ORGAN DONATIONS -- To expand the availability of organs for transplants, the New York State Department of Health and the Department of Motor Vehicles have begun a computer registry of state residents who wish to be donors after death. Under state law, if no such instruction has been left, family permission is required for a dead person's organs and tissues to be used. Often, family members refuse because they do not know their relative's wishes. Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)
 
MANHATTAN: MUSEUM STRIKE -- With the union representing its administrative workers still on strike after six weeks, the Museum of Modern Art yesterday put into effect its latest contract offer for employees who have returned to work. Nearly half of the 250 workers in the bargaining unit have crossed the picket line, and yesterday's move gives them an immediate 3 percent raise and more generous retirement-plan contributions. Museum officials said it was unfair for those who returned to work to be left without a raise since November 1998. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)
 
AMITYVILLE: PARTNER BENEFITS -- Maxine S. Postal, a Suffolk county legislator, plans to introduce a resolution on Tuesday seeking health benefits for domestic partners of Suffolk county workers. Ms. Postal, a Democrat of Amityville, said that the resolution, although nonbinding, would indicate that the county executive and the county's unions could negotiate similar benefits during collective bargaining. Last week, such a bill was voted down. Stacy Albin (NYT)
 
ALBANY: DAMAGED APPLE CROP -- Hudson Valley apple growers say they will need federal aid because hailstorms on May 18 and June 2 damaged an estimated two million bushels of apples. Apples are the fourth most valuable crop in the state, generating $138 million in 1999. Loss estimates for the mid-Hudson alone run as high as $10 million. On Monday, Agriculture Commissioner Nathan L. Rudgers toured apple orchards to view the damage and heard from growers, some of whom said their economic survival was at stake. (AP)
 
BROOKLYN: WENDY'S KILLINGS -- Two men who the police say supplied the gun used in the killing of five Wendy's restaurant workers last month have been arrested, the United States attorney's office for the Eastern District of New York announced yesterday. The handgun was found in a belt pack on John B. Taylor, left, one of two men charged in the killings. Prosecutors said that Bernard Gardier, 23, of Cleveland, had stolen the legally purchased weapon from his girlfriend and that Jamal Gales, 27, of Berea, Ohio, arranged its sale for $250 to an unnamed person in Nassau County. (NYT)
 
NEW JERSEY
 
CAMDEN: RABBI MURDER CASE -- A rabbi charged with hiring two men to kill his wife in 1994 must await his trial in jail. Judge Linda G. Rosenzweig of Superior Court revoked the bail of Rabbi Fred J. Neulander yesterday, ruling that because Mr. Neulander now faced the death penalty, he would be more likely to flee. A grand jury returned a capital murder indictment against Mr. Neulander on Tuesday. (AP)
 
TRENTON: EMISSION TESTS IN DOUBT -- State officials said they might drop or delay part of the state automobile inspections scheduled to begin on July 1. One problem, they said, is that the so-called tank pressure test, which would discover leaks in a car's exhaust system not detected by tailpipe testing, could increase the waiting time for drivers. Waits of several hours because of problems with the new tailpipe emissions test angered motorists soon after the new system went into effect in December, resulting in the test's suspension. Steve Strunsky (NYT)
 
CONNECTICUT
 
BRIDGEPORT: DRUG RING SENTENCES -- Three people convicted of being part of Russell Peeler Jr.'s drug ring were sentenced to federal prison on Tuesday, the same day that Mr. Peeler escaped the death penalty for a double murder. Angelina Keene, 24, of Bridgeport, who has three children with Mr. Peeler and was accused of running the drug operation when he was away, received a three-year sentence in United States District Court. Cory King, 22, and Shawn Kennedy, 24, each received 10 years. Mr. Peeler will be sentenced to life because jurors in his case could not reach a unanimous decision on the death penalty. (AP)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Big Insurer to Compensate Blacks Who Paid Too Much
After decades of paying higher premiums for life insurance than white customers, nearly five million black customers and their families nationwide are going to be compensated in a settlement reached with American General, one of the nation's biggest insurers.
The company said that it was making restitution of $206 million, mainly to the black customers and their heirs who, until as recently as April, paid as much as 33 percent more than white customers for small policies intended to cover burial expenses. Page A1. 

Texas Instruments to Buy a Rival
Texas Instruments said it would acquire Burr-Brown, which is also a computer chip maker, for $7.6 billion in stock. C2.
 
Stock Prices Rally as Bonds Fall
Microsoft helped propel the Dow Jones industrial average and the Nasdaq composite index higher. The Nasdaq composite index rose 50.65 points, or 1.3 percent, to 4,064.01. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 62.58 points, or 0.6 percent, to 10,497.74, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index increased 3.18 points, to 1,479.13. Bond prices fell sharply, with the yield on the 30-year issue rising to 5.96 percent from 5.89 percent on Tuesday. C11.
 
Uranium Enrichment Plant to Close
The United States Enrichment Corporation, the private company that runs the nation's only two uranium enrichment plants, said it would close one of them in a year, in Portsmouth, Ohio, because of high costs and a depressed market for reactor fuel. C22.

Regulators have suspended and fined the former owner of Founders Asset Management, which manages more than $8 billion, for failing to disclose that some of the firm's clients paid excessive commissions on stock trades in the early 1990's. Market Place. C10.
 
A New Standard for Internet Privacy
Major Internet companies and the World Wide Web's standard-setting body introduced long-awaited technology that would alert computer users before they visited Web sites that collect more personal information than they are willing to share. The new standard was denounced by some privacy advocates. C6.

Protesters took control of the Nike Web site and redirected visitors to a site urging organizations to gather at and disrupt a world economic summit later this year. C2.

Fidelity Investments, which manages nearly $1 trillion, shuffled its top executives and reorganized into three units headed by three vice chairmen. James C. Curvey, 65, president and chief operating officer, is leaving both posts and returning to his previous job at the firm. He will remain a vice chairman. Robert L. Reynolds, 48, above, will replace Mr. Curvey as chief operating officer and will also be a vice chairman. Robert C. Pozen, 53, president of FMR, also will be a vice chairman. C8.
 
Frankel Is Sentenced in Germany
A German court sentenced Martin R. Frankel, the American financier, to three years in prison for failing to pay custom taxes on smuggled diamonds and carrying false passports. C4.
 
Handspring Shares Climb 35%
Shares of Handspring rose 35 percent in their first day of trading after raising $200 million in an initial offering that showed investors' enthusiasm for companies that make increasingly popular hand-held computers. C22.
 
35 Years Later, Hiring Bias Remains
More than three decades after the passage of the Civil Rights Act, there is abundant evidence that it did much to improve job prospects for blacks. But bias still persists, and policies aimed at reducing discrimination would be sharper if they concentrated more on opening opportunities than on redressing the grievances of dismissed workers. Alan B. Krueger: Economic Scene. C2.

HEADLINE: PRICE OF GASOLINE EMERGES AS ISSUE IN BUSH-GORE RACE

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: NASHVILLE, June 21

 BODY:
Worried that voters will blame the Clinton administration -- and Vice President Al Gore -- for the recent surge in gasoline prices, the Gore campaign has begun an effort to paint Gov. George W. Bush, a onetime oil company executive, as a tool of the oil interests it says are relentlessly gouging consumers.
Speaking today for the Gore campaign, Senator Tom Harkin, Democrat of Iowa, said Mr. Bush was "getting all his money" from the oil companies, a reference to the industry's substantial financial contributions to Mr. Bush's presidential campaign. 
 Mr. Harkin said he wanted oil executives to testify under oath on Capitol Hill about the price increases.
For his part, Mr. Bush and Republicans on Capitol Hill blame the gas-price increase on the Clinton administration, saying the administration has had no coherent domestic energy policy and, in imposing regulations to meet clean air standards, had allowed prices to drift as high as $2.39 a gallon in the Midwest. Mr. Bush also said the administration had failed to persuade the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to "open the spigots" to increase the supply.
The group did decide today to increase production by more than most experts had expected, but the increase remained too small to bring down gasoline prices.
Mr. Bush, who has been reluctant to discuss the issue publicly, broke his silence today and joined Mr. Gore in endorsing the investigation by the Federal Trade Commission that was announced on Tuesday.
"I do think it's fair to have the F.T.C. investigate," he told reporters in Los Angeles.
Mr. Bush's comment could undercut Mr. Gore's efforts to portray the governor as part of the problem. In any case, the issue has jumped to the top of the agenda in presidential politics as Americans begin their summer vacations and both sides are trying to exploit it.
The prices have hit hardest in the Midwest, the very states where the two campaigns are competing most fiercely for votes.
Gas prices in Illinois, Michigan and Wisconsin are substantially higher than in other parts of the country for several reasons, but chief among them, Republicans say, is the special kind of reformulated gas the area must use under Environmental Protection Agency regulations. Those regulations went into effect on June 1, which is when prices began to rise considerably. The Midwest is the first region, under the rules, to begin using this ethanol-laced reformulated gas to prevent pollution.
Democratic officials said that new polling shows that voters believe the price of gasoline is far and away the No. 1 problem in the country. The officials also say that voters blame American oil companies most, then the OPEC oil cartel.
Gore officials see the emergence of this issue as an opportunity to link Mr. Bush directly in the public mind with the oil companies and portray Mr. Gore as on the side of working families. This has been a longtime goal of the Gore campaign, but it has not succeeded so far.
Mark Fabiani, a spokesman for Mr. Gore, said: "It all comes down to who people think is on their side. People believe, and rightly so, that the oil companies are in large part responsible for the price of gasoline. They don't believe the government is responsible for the price of gas. So what average people are deciding is, 'Who do I want in the government when gas prices skyrocket?' We think the answer is clear: Vice President Gore is on their side, Governor Bush isn't."
Mr. Gore himself has ratcheted up his language on the price increases, last week saying in selective interviews with Midwest television stations that he wanted an investigation into possible collusion. Today, he said at the opening of a Social Security speech in Iowa, one of the states most affected, that he was concerned about the "conduct of the oil companies" and that they may have been price gouging.
Mr. Gore noted that OPEC had indicated today that it would increase oil production, a move that would presumably put downward pressure on gasoline prices in the United States. But he said the issue deserved thorough investigation by the Federal Trade Commission.
"I hope that it will be thorough and hard-hitting," Mr. Gore said of the investigation. "If there's evidence of what I suspect there's evidence of, it ought to be dealt with quickly and harshly. I think it's time to put our feet on the brakes of what may well be big oil's price gouging."
Senator Harkin, speaking on behalf of the Gore campaign on a conference call with reporters, accused the oil companies of "outright thievery." He went on to castigate Mr. Bush for his "silence" on the matter, saying, "What can you expect of someone who once claimed, and I quote, 'There's no such thing as being too closely aligned to the oil business in West Texas'?"
The quotation from Mr. Bush was made in a 1978 Congressional campaign. Acknowledging that the quotation was more than 20 years old, Mr. Harkin said: "The point is, the test of character and leadership is when you're willing to take on your friends when it's in the nation's best interest."
Mr. Bush signed an emergency tax bill in 1999 that gave state tax breaks to oil and gas companies. The Dallas Morning News reported that the bill saved Richard Rainwater, a former Bush business partner, $1 million. At least 14 of Mr. Bush's "Pioneers," his largest financial contributors, have ties to the oil industry.
Mr. Bush's campaign has received $1.5 million from energy interests as of April 30, while Mr. Gore had received less than $125,000 as of the same date.
But the Gore strategy of opening up fire on the oil front carries some dangers for the Gore campaign. For one thing, rising prices -- and being reminded of them -- could undermine consumer confidence in the economy at a time when Mr. Gore is boasting about the economy on his "progress and prosperity tour."
Representative Dick Armey, the majority leader and a Texan, told reporters in Washington today: "The vice president has a growing political problem because his administration has been asleep at the wheel when it comes to dealing with OPEC. Instead of acknowledging that his administration has no energy policy, which leaves our nation overly dependent on foreign oil, the vice president is looking for a scapegoat."
Republicans also said that Mr. Gore has obsessively lobbied for so-called "clean-air fuel," the kind that is now at the center of the Midwestern price increases, without worrying about the consequences. "He is the one who pushed this whole idea of a different type of gasoline," said Speaker J. Dennis Hastert of Illinois.
But Gore officials say the environmental standards leading to the reformulation of gasoline have added only four to eight cents a gallon to the cost of fuel and would not account for such a drastic price increase.
In his 1992 environmental treatise, "Earth in the Balance," Mr. Gore himself proposed the idea of higher fuel taxes on oil companies to help reduce pollution; as part of that, he suggested a corresponding cut in corporate income and payroll taxes.

HEADLINE: George Bush's 60's Were Real, Too

BYLINE: By David Frum; David Frum is the author of "How We Got Here," a history of the 1970's.

 BODY:
In the spring of 1968, the same season in which George W. Bush graduated from Yale, the university's blue-collar workers went on strike. Similar strikes would shut down the school's dining halls later on, but not this time, thanks to students who crossed the picket lines to keep the kitchens cooking. Remember those students the next time somebody suggests that there was something odd about George W. Bush's noninvolvement in the student militancy of the 1960's.
The 60's were indeed a time of radical ferment. But that ferment was the work of a relative minority, larger at Al Gore's Harvard, smaller at George Bush's Yale. Richard Nixon and George Wallace together won almost 60 percent of the vote in 1968. Astute Democrats likewise knew which way the wind was blowing: Jimmy Carter, the lone Democrat to reach the White House in the two decades between the presidencies of Lyndon Johnson and Bill Clinton, defended Lieut. William Calley when he was tried for the My Lai massacre, calling him a scapegoat. As governor of Georgia, Mr. Carter even asked motorists to drive with their headlights on in daylight hours to show sympathy. 
 Young people, too, were more conservative than they are usually depicted. Indeed, polls during the Vietnam War consistently showed that young men, 18 to 24 years old, were the most hawkish segment of the population.
College students, it's true, hewed further to the left than did their non-collegian peers. But even on campus, the radical explosion of the 1960's gathered steam later and ended more abruptly than is usually recalled. Pick up a yearbook from any of the Ivy League colleges and look at the photographs of the class of 1968. With rare exceptions, you will see row after row of neatly shaven, short-haired, necktied young men. When Tom Wolfe visited the Yale campus a year or so later, he was startled by the sudden proliferation of overalls and blue jeans. He later observed that the whole place looked like a mining camp circa 1934.
What happened between the taking of those yearbook photos, sometime in 1967, and the spring of 1969? A change in the draft law exposed undergraduate men to a heightened risk of being sent unwillingly into the military. Until 1969, an educated man could feel reasonably sure of avoiding service. The huge size of the baby boom cohort offered the military many more 18-year-olds than it needed. In fact, a man's odds of being drafted in 1968, the year of the Tet offensive, were actually lower than in 1959, a peacetime year. Abundant manpower in turn made possible a generous system of student deferments.
After Tet, however, President Johnson -- motivated either by populist outrage or by vindictiveness against what he saw as his pampered critics -- severely limited student deferments. Suddenly students faced a real prospect of being sent to war. They reacted with fury.
Their fury lasted only as long as their exposure did. By fall 1971, President Nixon had withdrawn most ground combat units from Indochina, and radicals on campus and off were already lamenting the deflation of their "movement." Within 18 months, a peace pact was signed with the North Vietnamese. By then, the student protests seemed as distant to the newest Yalies as the world of Dink Stover.
So George W. Bush, Yale '68, is not clueless when he tells interviewers that he didn't see much of the radicalism of the 1960's. He is accurately representing the experience of his micro-generation.
His answer is telling in a more profound way as well. As posed by most journalists, the question -- "How could you have been untouched by the campus activism of the 1960's?" -- has a disingenuous edge to it. It pretends to be asking for information, but it conceals a reproach. The question assumes that any thoughtful, decent student ought to have been caught up in that radicalism -- as were Hillary Clinton, Bill Clinton (albeit in his characteristically self-protective way) and, perhaps, the journalist himself or herself.
And what kind of assumption is that? The 1960's radicals were wrong about cutting off American arms and aid to South Vietnam, wrong about the larger struggle with the Soviet Union, wrong about the harmlessness of drugs, wrong about eliminating freshman composition from the college curriculum. Even Mr. Bush's rival for the presidency understands that, which may explain why he begins his Internet campaign biography with the arresting sentence, "Al Gore served in the U.S. Army in Vietnam."
Back in the 1970's, some French intellectual quipped that it was morally finer to have been wrong about the Soviet Union than to have been right. American politics, though, has less room for that kind of intellectual frivolity. It is not better to have been wrong than to have been right. Isn't it long past time that our memories of the 1960's accept that truth?

HEADLINE: Orbiter Spots Signs Of a Recent Flow Of Water on Mars

BYLINE: By WARREN E. LEARY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 21

 BODY:
A spacecraft orbiting Mars has sighted grooved surface features suggesting a relatively recent water flow on the planet, a finding that could redirect efforts to find evidence of past or present life there, experts said today.
NASA's Mars Global Surveyor, which has been conducting photographic surveys of the planet for more than two years, has spotted evidence of liquid water at, or near, the surface that could have flowed a few hundreds or thousands of years ago, a billion years later than previous estimates, the experts said. 
 The National Aeronautics and Space Administration scheduled a news conference for Thursday to discuss the findings after a day of speculation about the discovery in the news media. A paper describing the observations is to be published next week in the journal Science, but the journal's editors decided to release the information on Thursday because of the interest in the findings.
Neither NASA nor the authors of the report, including Dr. Michael C. Malin and Dr. Ken Edgett of Malin Space Science Systems of San Diego, would disclose details of the findings. But people familiar with the report said high resolution pictures from Global Surveyor clearly show channels and grooves on the steep, inside walls of craters that indicate the downward flow of liquid water.
These surface features appear to be evidence of water in the upper crust of Mars that has seeped through and run down the channels, said two experts familiar with the report who spoke on the condition that they not be named. Contrary to speculation about the findings, there is no clear evidence of standing pools of water or gushing springs on Mars, they said.
"The current climate of Mars would cause surface water to instantly freeze and vaporize into the atmosphere," one expert said.
Water is crucial to plans for exploring Mars with robot spacecraft to find evidence of life, and for possible visits by humans. The United States has ambitious Mars exploration plans that focus on finding water. Those plans are being revised after the failure of two spacecrafts last year.
Dr. Edward J. Weiler, NASA's chief scientist, said future orbiting and surface craft would search for water and the life it can sustain. "To find life on Mars, you have to follow the water," Dr. Weiler has said. "Without water, there was no life as we know it in the past, and there is no life now. It's all about the water."
Future spacecraft would be directed to areas where there is a high probability of finding water. Data from orbiters and landing craft would help researchers home in on those areas.
Water on Mars would also make human visits more likely and economical, experts said, because astronauts could drink it, and it could be broken down into oxygen to breathe and hydrogen to fuel rockets and generators.
Water has been detected on Mars in the form of ice trapped at the poles, but until now no evidence of it had been seen elsewhere. Because of the planet's extreme temperatures, with average surface temperatures of minus 60 degrees Fahrenheit, and an atmospheric pressure less than 1 percent that of Earth's, liquid water would not exist long on the surface before breaking down in the thin air and drifting into space.
But there is ample evidence of flowing water long ago on the planet, including channels and canyons formed by flowing rivers millions of years ago and indications of upswelling ground waters. And last year, scientists at Brown University said that they found evidence in Global Surveyor pictures, which are more than 20 times more detailed than any previous photographs, of a giant ocean that once existed in the northern lowlands.
An intriguing aspect of the newest findings is the possibility of water near the surface, instead of miles below as some have theorized. If water is a few feet below the surface, as early characterizations of the new data suggest, landing crafts could drill down to reach it, experts said.
Dr. Victor R. Baker, a hydrology expert and planetary scientist at the University of Arizona, said that if there was evidence of active water seepage in the new data, it would have wide implications. Dr. Baker, who had not seen the report, said that if water still flowed on Mars and escaped to the surface, it would need an underground heat source to keep it thawed and provide the energy necessary to force it to the surface. So far, no evidence of active volcanic or thermal activity has been found on the planet, he noted.
If water was flowing on Mars, he said, it would produce a cloud of vapor, as it dissipated under current surface conditions, that spacecraft instruments should be able to detect from orbit. "It should be fairly easy to confirm if there is major seepage going on now," Dr. Baker said.

HEADLINE: Zimbabwe's Campaign of Intimidation

 BODY:
In Zimbabwe's 20 years as an independent nation, one man has led it -- Robert Mugabe. He has never faced a serious challenge. But this weekend the country is to choose a new parliament, and polls show that the opposition would win a fair election. Zimbabweans may have decided that "Mugabe" and "Zimbabwe" should no longer be synonymous.
Mr. Mugabe has responded to the prospect of defeat with demagoguery, violence and intimidation. Gangs of his thugs roam the countryside, killing and beating opposition activists. The balloting and vote count may be flawed, as the government is limiting the number of election observers. The outside world, especially South Africa and Zimbabwe's smaller neighbors, must press Mr. Mugabe to end the violence, hold a clean vote and vote count and abide by the results. 
 Mr. Mugabe began his presidency by providing schools and health care to the poor, but over two decades he became an autocrat surrounded by corrupt and brutal men. One reason Zimbabwe has sent 11,000 troops to war in Congo, it is alleged, is that his generals profit from trading in Congo diamonds. The war costs Zimbabwe millions of dollars a month, while half the nation is unemployed.
Yet Mr. Mugabe has the support of all but 3 of Parliament's 150 members, and no strong opposition arose until last year, when the Movement for Democratic Change was born to take part in rewriting the Constitution. Mr. Mugabe's draft, which would have broadened his powers, lost in a popular referendum in February. Shaken by the defeat, he began exploiting the issue of land reform. All major parties endorse breaking up large farms, owned mainly by whites, and distributing the land to poor blacks. For 20 years Mr. Mugabe did little. Now, instead of beginning an orderly process with compensation for landowners, he has encouraged his supporters in the violent takeover of white-owned farms. They have killed one farmer and beaten dozens of black farm workers.
The bloodshed has spread. The opposition cannot campaign in much of the countryside. At least 29 of its candidates and backers have been killed, and many others raped or beaten, often as police stood by. Recently the government offered the opposition some air time and has begun to denounce violence, but has still made no real effort to stop the thugs.
It is now impossible for the election to be free. But the opposition is determined to participate and could win if Mr. Mugabe allowed the vote and vote count to proceed without fraud. This means calling off his thugs, sending out word not to meddle with ballots, and allowing all observers access to polling stations and the counting process.
The United States, Britain, the European Union and the Commonwealth nations should warn Mr. Mugabe that he and his cronies will lose visas for foreign travel and their overseas bank accounts if Zimbabwe's democracy dies. But Western nations are not trusted or beloved by most Zimbabweans. The most important voice is that of South Africa, which has been disappointingly silent. President Thabo Mbeki and the rest of southern Africa's presidents should speak out publicly, as Botswana has done. Southern African nations have a powerful interest in keeping Zimbabwe from political and economic collapse. 
http://www.nytimes.com

CORRECTION-DATE: June 28, 2000, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
An editorial last Thursday misstated the number of white farmers in Zimbabwe who have been killed by President Robert Mugabe's supporters. The number is five, not one. And an editorial yesterday gave the wrong location for next month's economic summit meeting in Japan. It will be in Okinawa, not Osaka.

HEADLINE: www.layoffs.com;
Internet Work Force Has Its First Brush With Downsizing

BYLINE: By MATT RICHTEL 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, June 21

 BODY:
Laura Schmidt took an Internet job 10 months ago packed with promise: a big raise, stocks she figured could some day be worth $5 million and the chance at early retirement. Unfortunately, her leisure time came way too soon.
Three weeks ago, Ms. Schmidt received a pink slip from ThirdAge Media, a Web site for baby boomers, laid off in the Internet industry's first significant shakeout. As quickly and aggressively as they filled their cubicles last year, dozens of dot-coms across the country are unloading employees in an effort to meet a seemingly obvious goal heretofore put on indefinite hold: make a profit. 
 The layoffs signal an end to the unbounded optimism of some dot-com employees who flocked to start-ups in hopes of developing sudden wealth, but who now say they are approaching new job offers with more caution. And the very stock market that once held the keys to new wealth may now be equally responsible not just for lowered expectations, but for lost jobs.
Indeed, analysts say the reversal of fortune for many companies, and their employees, can be traced in part to the stock market turmoil on April 14. When the Nasdaq plunged that day, investors signaled they no longer would finance dot-coms that sought to grow at all costs, ignoring, at least temporarily, the concept that successful businesses take in more than they spend.
While lots of Internet businesses with sound strategies and healthy finances are continuing to thrive, the challenge these days for a number of e-commerce companies is simply to keep from going broke.
"Call it old fashioned, but at some point, these companies had to start making money," said Douglas Henton, president of Collaborative Economics, an economic advisory group in Palo Alto, Calif., who called the phenomenon a healthy shakeout in which some companies fail and others refine themselves. "At some point, they run out of money and they have to start laying off."
Companies that have had to lay off workers include lesser-known and big-name Web sites, like the health care site drkoop.com Inc. (50 employees laid off, or 35 percent), carOrder.com Inc. (100 layoffs, or 33 percent), an insurance site called InsWeb (100 planned, or 40 percent), the home-furnishing site living.com (50, or 13 percent), the search engine Alta Vista (50, about 6 percent) and more than two dozens other sites for a total of more than 2,000 employees.
And that does not include a growing number of dot-coms that have been subsumed in mergers or simply gone broke, including DEN.com, an entertainment site in Los Angeles that employed 200; APBnews.com, a New York-based crime news site with 140 workers; and toysmart.com, a Disney-backed toy retailer in Waltham, Mass., with 170 employees that shut down in May.
Earlier this year, even Amazon.com made layoffs, but the 150 people involved represented just 2 percent of its work force and that move preceded the market downturn that seems to be driving the latest layoff trend.
Executives at many of the companies still in business say that layoffs do not suggest they are desperately low on cash, but that they must plan for a future in which new infusions of capital are not as easily obtained as they have been in the two previous years. They say they are rewriting business models that had been predicated on obtaining quick public offerings, meaning that some are being forced to cut costs by terminating employees, who are the chief expense of many Internet enterprises.
"It was really hard," said T. Paul Thomas, president and chief executive of TurboLinux, a Linux operating system vendor in San Francisco, which cut roughly 50 of 300 employees last month. "The people we had to let go had been here an average of two or three months. But investors, public and private, are saying you can't just spend and spend. You have to get to profitability."
The good news, economists say, is that the human toll appears limited to individual dot-coms, that the number of employees laid off represents a small fraction of the hundreds of thousands of people of the Internet work force, and that nearly all of those who lost their jobs have skills that should help them easily obtain jobs with other technology companies.
"There aren't any signals the economy is in trouble," said Stephen Levy, director of the Center for Continuing Study of the California Economy. "The industry is doing well by any economic measure. This is a company phenomenon, not an industry-wide or economy-wide phenomenon."
Indeed, most dot-com employees seem surprisingly sanguine.
"This is an auspicious time," said Ms. Schmidt, 33, who spent 10 months as director of brand design for Third-Age Media, which cut 35 of its 140 jobs. "I live in San Francisco. I'm just glad it happened now rather than in two months when a lot more people will be looking for jobs."
She said she saw the layoff as an opportunity for an extended vacation before she starts her next job. But she also said she was looking at prospective employers with new scrutiny to make sure their business plan seemed viable.
"I would imagine that if I want a job by the end of next week, I'd have one," she said. But, she added, "I'm doing a lot more research than I did before."
Many others who have been laid off say that no sooner did they receive the news than they began interviewing again, sifting through offers, taking new jobs.
But not all of those receiving a pink slip are feeling rosy about the experience. One 26-year-old woman hired in February by an entertainment dot-com said she felt the company had misled her by suggesting she could "be retired by age 30." Instead, she was out of a job three months later, having lost all her stock options because she was not yet vested.
In retrospect, she said the company had used her, then quickly dismissed her when it came to its financial senses, and she said she was concerned that other entrepreneurs would make similar mistakes.
"People are very hopeful -- investors, employees -- and married with greed, you've got a perfect formula for a lot of shady companies," she said, requesting anonymity because she said she had signed an agreement not to discuss the circumstances of her departure from the company.
The woman said she was being very cautious when considering new offers, hoping to avoid a repeat of the situation. And that is a theme echoed not just by others who have been laid off, but also by recruiters who are placing dot-com employees in new jobs.
Jodi M. Milam, who owns Career Wave, a human resources consulting company in Chandler, Ariz., that focuses on placing Internet employees around the country, said the layoff phenomenon had become "epidemic" because so many companies were started without sound business plans.
Ms. Milam said the companies recruited employees with the promise that the companies would soon attract a next round of private financing, or even go public. But, Ms. Milam said, the entrepreneurs either were naive about their own prospects, or misleading the hires. They also seemed, she said, to lay off employees -- even those who pulled up stakes or were lured from other good jobs -- with little compunction.
"Business ethics have gone down the toilet," she said, adding that she wakes up with a stomachache every day because "I'm afraid of sending people to companies" that will go under.
But the companies say the layoffs represent a bona fide realization that they must be mindful of the bottom line and of what it takes to succeed in a harsher business climate. A number of the companies said the layoffs signaled an effort to shift directions, typically away from Internet businesses that focus on selling to consumers and into ventures that sell to other businesses.
An example is Alta Vista, a search engine company in Palo Alto, Calif., that in early May reduced its staff by 50 people, or about 6 percent. Though the site processes a remarkable 50 million search queries a day, the company decided that its long-term survivability rested not just on being a destination site but also in licensing its technology to businesses.
"We have done a slight shift in strategic positioning following the market turmoil," said David Emanuel, a company spokesman.
In other cases, businesses are shedding ambitious plans and renewing the narrow focus with which they began operations. InsWeb, in Redwood City, Calif., in announcing plans to lay off 40 percent of its 240 workers in the next six months, said it would return to its roots, becoming a marketplace for consumers seeking insurance, and scrap a number of other projects, according to Greg Jones, company spokesman.
The new focus means the end of the line at InsWeb for Steve Foster, 43, who quit a job in Los Angeles and moved north to take a job in November as InsWeb's vice president for marketing research. At the time, he said, it was "literally the zenith of dot-com times" and he negotiated a healthy raise and 19,000 shares of stock.
In the short term, it looked as if his gamble would pay off in a big way. The company's stock, $14 when he was recruited, jumped to $36 in January, giving him a gain in personal value "worth a quarter of a million right off the bat."
But Mr. Foster was laid off with 30 colleagues two weeks ago. The company's stock, meanwhile, has fallen to $3, making his options worthless.
Still, he says he bears no ill will toward the company, which he said had treated employees well and had never misled anyone about the prospects. And as to his lost fortune -- the few brief shining moments when his stock options ballooned in value -- he seems philosophical about that, too.
"I've been thinking I'll keep a single share and frame it," he said. "Just to keep the memory alive."

 CORRECTION:
An article and chart in Business Day yesterday about recent layoffs at Internet companies misstated the status of one company, APBnews.com. Although it announced on June 5 that it was out of money and was laying off all 140 employees, it has continued operations, recently found new financing and hired back about 30 workers.
In addition, the chart misstated the number of employees laid off by Salon.com. It was 13, not 19.
A chart in Business Day on June 22 with an article about recent layoffs at Internet companies reversed the labels on the stock performance of two companies, Salon.com and Insweb.com. From Jan. 3 to June 21, shares of Salon.com fell to $1.375 from $4.875; Insweb.com dropped to $2.75 from $25.75.
