HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate;
Leading Lender Exits City Mortgage Business

BYLINE: By TRACIE ROZHON 

 BODY:
One of the leading sources of mortgage loans for buyers of high-priced Manhattan co-op apartments dropped out of the business two weeks ago, and the ramifications are already starting to be felt in the city's mortgage industry.
On June 7, Mellon Bank pulled the plug on new mortgages written through its subsidiary, the Boston Company. Since that date, said Ed Klotzbier, a spokesman for Mellon, the company's mortgage business throughout the country has been written through a new entity called Mellon Private Mortgage. The big difference: to get a mortgage now, a borrower must be a customer signed up with Mellon's asset management ($1 million in liquid assets required) or its private banking division ($1 million in net assets required). 
 Melissa Cohn, president of the Manhattan Mortgage Company, one of New York's largest mortgage brokerages, said that since Mellon's decision, "We're seeing a number of banks step up to the plate to take over the Boston Company's niche." Ms. Cohn said the move would have particular impact on customers seeking mortgages of $400,000 to $1 million. She named First Republic and Fleet as two banks that have been actively campaigning for the new business.
Janice DiMarino, managing director of lending for the New York office of First Republic, a San Francisco-based bank, said that the change was an opportunity for the bank, "not only in New York but on the West Coast." Ms. DiMarino said the bank specialized in the "super jumbo" mortgage, over $650,000. Last year, it wrote $1.9 billion in mortgages nationally; the New York office, which opened only in October, did $54 million. ("But this year, we expect to write a lot more," she said.)
While bankers said yesterday that the impact of the Mellon move was not yet fully understood, it seemed clear that it was getting more complex to take out a jumbo loan in today's banking marketplace. Ms. DiMarino said future mortgage-holders at First Republic would be pressured to establish the same kind of "relationship" that Mellon requires.
She said that borrowers with substantial accounts at the bank would receive favored interest rates: anywhere from a tenth to a quarter of a point less on their loan.
The Boston Company, which will continue its business in institutional asset management, wrote $1.9 billion in mortgages in 1998 and 1999 combined, Mr. Klotzbier said. Twenty-five percent of those loans were written for properties in New York, 30 percent in California, 25 percent in Boston, and the rest were scattered throughout the country.
Ms. Cohn of Manhattan Mortgage said that last year her company wrote about $50 million in loans with the Boston Company, which was purchased by Mellon in 1993. Of the loans, she said, more than half were in the $400,000 to $1 million range.
Both Ms. Cohn and Frederick W. Peters, president of Ashforth Warburg Real Estate, a Manhattan-based brokerage, said they were informed of the change abruptly. "One of my brokers heard from one of the loan officers they simply weren't able to do loans anymore," Mr. Peters said.
Both Ms. Cohn and Mr. Peters agreed that the Boston Company would be missed. "They were a player," Mr. Peters said.
The Boston Company was one of New York City's major writers of the so-called negative pledge loans, which have been called "the dirty little secret" of Manhattan co-op financing. The negative pledge loans are basically mortgages written for strict co-op buildings with policies that prohibit such loans.
As real estate and banking experts describe the practice, the would-be buyers who take out these loans keep them secret from the co-op board, which requires listing of all debts and financing details. This allows the buyers to free their own money, despite co-op rules for "all-cash" and "half-cash" purchases. Accountants, meanwhile, said the home buyers can and do deduct the payments as with any home mortgage.
The Boston Company, said Mr. Peters, was "the first big player with the negative pledge loans, and negative pledge loans became very significant in the last dozen years."
Mr. Klotzbier of Mellon and Ms. DiMarino of First Republic said they would continue to offer the negative pledge loans.
Mr. Klotzbier insisted that Mellon was not "jettisoning" or "divesting ourselves" of the luxury mortgage business. He said that Mellon had not closed down Boston's mortgage business because of lack of business, as some in the industry have speculated. "No, no, quite the contrary," he said. "It's because Mellon wants to focus on wealth management: asset management and trust accounts. The mode we're in today, we want to invest in high-growth, high-return business."
And writing residential mortgages for clients who don't have the rest of their sizable wealth on deposit is not a high-growth, high-return business, he said.

HEADLINE: AIDS Is Moving Into Rural Areas, U.N. Study Says

BYLINE: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr. 

DATELINE: PARIS, June 22

 BODY:
The global AIDS epidemic, long thought of as an urban phenomenon, is shifting strongly to rural areas in the third world, a report from Unaids and the Food and Agricultural Organization said today.
That shift has dire implications for people infected with H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, and the countries that are involved with the crisis. Although city dwellers can sometimes find social services to help them or can beg on the streets, a poor farm family often collapses when one adult is deathly ill. 
 "H.I.V. hits particularly young adults, and they are the core of the labor force, the keystone of the farm household," said Jacques du Guerny, an AIDS expert at the Food and Agricultural Organization.
When one family member cannot plow, weed or go to market and others have to cut their workloads to care for that person or have to sell the family ox or plow to buy medicine or pay for funerals, the farm may collapse. That in turn cuts food supply to city residents. Even if the family carries on, it may plant less or plant less labor-intensive and less nutritious crops, the report said.
The situation is particularly bad in Africa, where in many countries 10 to 25 percent of adults are infected; in India, with a low infection rate but more than four million cases; and in some Caribbean countries, including Haiti. American AIDS deaths receive more publicity, but Africa accounts for 83 percent of AIDS deaths worldwide, according to Unaids.
The disease spreads in rural areas in many ways. Particularly in southern Africa, rural people migrate to the cities or mines to look for work, become infected and return home once or twice a year. The disease also spreads along truck routes, where prostitution thrives, especially near borders where truckers can wait for days.
Rural poverty, too, creates vulnerability. In one example Mr. du Guerny cited, Cambodian farmers often go bankrupt in bad years and accept money from lenders who charge high interest rates. If the borrowers fall behind, Mr. du Guerny said, "traffickers come and say, 'Sell us your daughter, and we will help you repay the loan.' This creates tremendous vulnerability and risk of infection."
Preventive measures like sex education and condom distribution focus on cities. Traditional customs that can spread the disease like the central African practice of "cleansing" a widow through sex with a relative of the dead husband are stronger in the countryside.
The report was released in Rome, the Food and Agriculture Organization's base. It had no worldwide estimate of urban-rural prevalence, and it noted that rural H.I.V. rates "are harder to measure and more prone to underreporting and misdiagnosis." Instead, the study reached its conclusion by compiling case studies. In one Indian state, Tamil Nadu, the rate is growing faster in the countryside than in cities. In rural Buhera, Zimbabwe, the rate among pregnant women who visitprenatal clinics is 50.8 percent, well above the national average.
The chief epidemiologist for Unaids, Bernhard Schwartlander, said that there were no worldwide figures for the urban-rural shift but that one rule was that the disease spread faster from cities to countrysides with well-developed roads and bridges.
"In Botswana, a small country with very good infrastructure and a lot of people living near the roads," Mr. Schwartlander said, "there's no difference in infection rates between urban and rural areas. But in Tanzania, where it's a day's walk to get to a trading area to sell your stuff, people only do that once or twice a month."

HEADLINE: Updating Diplomacy's Language

 BODY:
It is easy to ridicule the State Department for replacing the evocative term "rogue nations" with the more diplomatic and touchy-feely "states of concern" when referring to trouble spots like North Korea, Iran, Iraq, Libya, Sudan and Cuba. But beyond the blurring of semantic clarity lies a welcome recognition that the world has changed in ways that make the "rogue" category a poor guide to intelligent foreign policy.
Secretary of State Madeleine Albright unveiled the new terminology in a radio interview Monday. Like rogue nations, states of concern have unpredictable, authoritarian leaders, histories of sponsoring terrorism and, Cuba excepted, programs for building biological, chemical or nuclear weapons. But as the department's new language recognizes, the strategy of lumping all these countries together as international rogues, unreachable through normal tools of diplomacy and fit only for isolation and military containment, has grown out of date. 
 North Korea is an obvious case in point. Its once-reclusive leader just held a successful meeting with his South Korean counterpart, and both sides now talk of national reconciliation and economic interchange. Pyongyang has honored its agreements with Washington to suspend nuclear weapons development and flight-testing of long-range missiles. In response, Washington has eased economic sanctions and made North Korea Asia's largest recipient of American assistance.
Other nations formerly known as rogues have not come that far. But for years Washington has been engaged in a delicate courtship with reform-minded elected officials in Iran. Indirect diplomacy with Libya, through the United Nations, helped bring the Lockerbie bombing suspects to trial. Many members of Congress have begun to recognize that a less restrictive policy toward Cuba could increase America's ability to influence political change there as the Castro era draws to a close.
Some states of concern still require ostracism, containment and military threats. One clear example is Saddam Hussein's Iraq, which defies United Nations Security Council resolutions, reneges on its diplomatic promises and would quickly divert any export revenues it could get its hands on into weapons programs. Every serious foreign problem facing America requires its own specific policy prescription. No longer talking about rogue states will make that easier to explain. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES

BYLINE: By JAMES BARRON with Joe Brescia 

 BODY:

Not in My Buffalo, Official Protests
REPRESENTATIVE JACK QUINN, Republican of New York, has two words for the playwright TERRENCE McNALLY, who is adapting the British film "The Full Monty" for Broadway: Why Buffalo? 
 Mr. Quinn is upset that the stage version of the 1997 film will use his hometown as the setting for the story of six unemployed factory workers who make ends meet by becoming striptease performers. Not wanting his constituents exposed to headlines like "Buffalo in the Buff" -- which The Associated Press used yesterday -- Mr. Quinn wrote to Mr. McNally, demanding that the town in the play be given a made-up name.
The film version of "The Full Monty" was set in Sheffield, England, which was depicted as a gritty industrial town whose once-mighty factories had been shut down. For the stage, the producers decided to Americanize the setting.
"Your current treatment of our city is both incorrect and irresponsible," Mr. Quinn said in his letter to Mr. McNally. He argued that Buffalo was on the rebound, "following in the footsteps of other cities like Baltimore and Cleveland" in redeveloping its waterfront.
Mr. McNally did not return a call for comment yesterday. But he told a reporter earlier in the year that he had checked with the playwright A. R. GURNEY, a Buffalo native, who assured him that he had Buffalo right.
"People ought to come and take a look at what's going on onstage before they jump to conclusions," said TOM HALL, a McNally producer. "Although it takes place in Buffalo, it in no way demeans the city or anyone in it. It's about a bunch of people who overcome adversity."
 
Praising Trump As Visionary
First ALEC BALDWIN hugged DONALD J. TRUMP. "I'm all for New York iconography," Mr. Baldwin said, "and Donald is a New York icon."
Then Mr. Trump, who dropped out as a potential Reform Party candidate for presidency, had his say about the conservative commentator PATRICK J. BUCHANAN. "Buchanan is not the right candidate," Mr. Trump said. "The concept of the Reform Party is great. But Buchanan does not represent what the Reform Party, or any other party for that matter, should be about."
Then he headed into the ballroom at the Pierre Hotel for the main event, a dinner honoring the "hotel and real estate visionary of the century" -- guess who -- sponsored by the UJA Federation. "I hope they mean the last century," Mr. Trump said. "If they mean the new century, it's only six months old. I couldn't have done much."
What followed was one part award ceremony, one part celebrity roast.
"This award proclaims Donald as a visionary," said the actor and radio personality JAY THOMAS. "Does it mean he looked into the future and saw huge buildings filled with people that paid him rent? I look into the future and I see one of his condo boards that's not going to let me into the building."
FRAN WEISSLER, who with her husband, Barry, has produced such Broadway hits as "Annie Get Your Gun," said that getting into a Trump building was not her problem -- she already lives in one. "Barry and I are thinking about producing a play about Donald's life," she said. "We're considering some working titles: 'Fiddling on the Roof,' 'A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Foreclosure' and 'Hair.' "
 
Mr. Ubiquitous, By the Numbers
DICK CLARK seemed to be everywhere yesterday: he had a morning meeting in Purchase, N.Y. ("It's unimportant," he said when asked the purpose. "Business.") That was followed by a noontime appearance at the CBS building on the Avenue of the Americas at 52nd Street. That was followed by a flight to Europe for a vacation.
But he keeps tabs on things. He said that he had flown 9 million miles, produced more than 7,000 hours of television programs, and signed more than 800,000 autographs. "That estimate was made three years ago," he said. "Thank God I have a short name." JAMES BARRON with Joe Brescia

HEADLINE: Herbalife's Afterlife Challenge;
Charismatic Leader Left an Image Problem and Other Issues

BYLINE: By BARBARA WHITAKER 

 BODY:
Herbalife International was built on Mark Hughes's story.
As a teenager who had spent time in a reform school, Mr. Hughes saw his mother die from an accidental overdose of prescription diet pills and set out to find a safer, better way to help people lose weight. At 23, with only a ninth-grade education and after stints with two direct-sales weight-loss companies that went out of business, he went out on his own. 
 He found a formula and started selling. His grandmother was his first success, and her example brought in friends as new customers. "Lose Weight Now, Ask Me How," became the mantra for Herbalife, which started in the trunk of Mr. Hughes's car in 1980. It found its footing in a small storefront in Beverly Hills, Calif., and grew into a weight-loss, nutrition and personal care products company with worldwide sales of nearly $1.7 billion last year.
But on May 21, the Hughes story came to a tragic, almost ironic end when Mr. Hughes was found dead in the bedroom of the $25 million Malibu beachfront house that he shared with his third wife, Darcy LaPier. The company said he had drunk alcohol at a birthday party for his 87-year-old grandmother at his home and later took the antidepressant Doxepin, which had been prescribed to help him sleep. Officials ruled the death an accident, noting that neither the drugs nor the alcohol in his system would have been fatal alone. But the combination was lethal.
The death of the handsome and charismatic Mr. Hughes at 44 is a serious blow for the company -- both because he was Herbalife's head cheerleader and because of the possibility that his message of a better life through herbal products might be diminished by the way he died.
"It's obviously an image problem," said Scott Hood, portfolio manager at First Wilshire Securities Management, which has owned Herbalife shares since late 1989. "But how bad is it? It's not like he was taking their own products."
Beyond image, though, a number of other issues face the executives who now run the company. A new team has taken up the challenge of motivating and expanding a vast network of distributors who buy the products from the company and in turn recruit new distributors. Other worries include a slumping domestic market for herbal products, a tight job market that could make it more difficult to draw in distributors, a damaged relationship with Wall Street after a failed attempt to take the company private, and stock transactions that left investors crying foul.
Nearly 58 percent of the stock is now held in a trust. The trustees are Christopher Pair, formerly the chief operating officer of Herbalife and now the president and chief executive; Conrad Klein, the chief business affairs officer and a longtime legal adviser to the company; and Jack Reynolds, Mr. Hughes's father. (As a young man, Mr. Hughes took his mother's maiden name.)
Mr. Pair, who was a counselor at the reform school that Mr. Hughes attended and later became a friend, said in an interview at company headquarters in Los Angeles that he had no intention of trying to substitute for Mr. Hughes, who at his death was chairman, president and chief executive of the company..
"I could never fill his shoes," he said, adding with a chuckle, "I don't have his looks."
That is not to say he does not have a story to share with distributors. When Mr. Pair was a young man, overweight and struggling with back problems, Mr. Hughes persuaded him to try his product, a weight-loss powder that was so new it came in plastic bags rather than cans.
He said he dropped 50 pounds in four months and became a distributor for a short period before returning to the University of Redlands in California to get his business degree. Though he says his experience as a distributor will help him in managing the company, he intends to focus more on operations and on mending the relationship with Wall Street.
To motivate distributors, he said, there are plenty of other stories to be told and thousands of hours of tapes of Mark Hughes selling his vision.
On Herbalife's Web site (www.herbalife.com), the voice of Mr. Hughes still tells how his mother "totally destroyed her life just trying to lose 30 pounds" as the company promotes its vision of realizing monetary dreams through selling its vast array of products. Beyond its core weight-loss and nutritional supplements, it features a wide variety of skin care items, vitamins, shampoos, even a natural sleep product. Among the company's competitors are Amway, Nature's Sunshine and Weider Nutrition International.
To keep Mr. Hughes's message fresh, Herbalife will rely more on the stories of its top sellers. Members of the Chairman's Club and the President's Team, who have networks bringing in hundreds of thousands of dollars a month, already train new distributors and conduct seminars, and those elite categories give distributors a goal to strive for.
"Our success is just a reflection of his power," said Paco Perez, who was a bellboy at an airport hotel in Los Angeles before becoming Mr. Hughes's first employee and is now a member of the President's Team. "He taught us all by example. We're committed to his dream."
To realize that dream, the network must keep growing. Despite setbacks, it has always done just that.
In the mid-1980's, the company came under intense scrutiny by regulators. The company paid $850,000 to settle a lawsuit by the state of California that accused it of having made false medical claims and having run an illegal marketing scheme. The Food and Drug Administration forced it to remove two products from the market for relabeling.
Business issues have been of more concern in recent years. Currency turmoil in Asia and Russia resulted in a steep drop in the stock price, and Wall Street developed concerns about how the company, which went public in 1986, was handling its stock and how it was preparing to go private again.
Though officials say the product and marketing issues of the 1980's did not amount to much and of are no concern now, Mr. Pair said he would focus on rebuilding the company's relationship with Wall Street.
Mike Crawford, an analyst with B. Riley & Company, a Los Angeles brokerage house, said, "There's one significant hurdle standing in the way of Herbalife regaining the trust of Wall Street, and that's showing management is there for shareholders and not for themselves."
Mr. Crawford, whose firm stopped covering Herbalife last year, noted that in 1998 management stock options with original strike prices of about $14 were reset between $6.63 and $8. Such a move is not uncommon when a company's stock price drops, as Herbalife's did then, but this adjustment would have meant large profits for executives had Mr. Hughes's buyback attempt gone through at $17.81 a share. That effort, which would have repurchased all the company's stock, was terminated because of bond market turmoil and increased interest rates.
Also of concern was a complex transaction in 1998 in which Mr. Hughes ultimately received $18 a share for five million shares. Add to that the buyback attempt, which led to a lawsuit by shareholders who felt the offer was too low, and Mr. Pair has plenty to talk about.
"While we've had some very valid issues internally," he said, referring to the legal fees and other costs of the buyback attempt, "the company is extraordinarily sound, the distributor base is absolutely committed to building the business, and we've got a management team in place that is going to continue to do what Mark started."
Mr. Pair said he would try to increase the price of the stock, which he says is greatly undervalued. It closed at $8 a share yesterday on Nasdaq, down from a 52-week high of $16.375 on Jan. 14.
Mr. Pair declined to offer specifics before sharing them with shareholders in July, but he said plans call for continuing overseas expansion and adding new products and new technology to aid distributors.
"There's over 130 countries in the world; we're in 49," Mr. Pair said. "We haven't even touched China yet, which is going to be potentially the biggest market in the world for direct selling."
He said at least a dozen products were being developed for the United States, probably six to eight of which will come on the market next year. Extensive new products are also to be introduced in Japan and Europe.
Some institutional investors agree that the stock is undervalued. They note that the company, with nearly $100 million in cash (over $3 a share) and no long-term debt, trades at 4.6 times earnings and pays a 7.8 percent dividend.
Mr. Crawford said Herbalife's new team could send Wall Street a strong message by buying back shares and returning the value to shareholders.
At such a low price, he said, the company is an attractive takeover target, particularly to a company looking for a strong distribution base. Herbalife has about 750,000 distributors throughout the world and recently began operations in Ireland and India. Though analysts say Herbalife has been able to maintain its domestic sales while sales have slid at other companies selling herbal products, there are concerns that with the job market tight Herbalife will have a hard time holding distributors and finding new ones.
Herbalife said that it had not found that to be a problem and that the strong economy was resulting in more sales.
Still, there are challenges.
Diane Boesenberg, a Los Angeles distributor who was called at random last week, said she would stop selling Herbalife in August after 24 years. She said her decision was made before Mark Hughes's death and was based on lack of sales.
"People are very fickle about vitamins, and I'm tired of having people order thousands of dollars of vitamins only to get stuck with them," she said. "There's too much other stuff out there to choose from."
She also cited an increase, to 7 percent, in shipping and handling charges, which she said she had to pay even if she drove to a warehouse to pick up supplies. In addition, she said, distributors who had brought her in, as well as those she had recruited, were gone.
"I've signed up a total of five or six distributors in the time I've done this, and they've all dropped out," she said.
As for Mr. Hughes's death, she did not expect that to have any negative effect "for the people who believe in Herbalife."
A conference in Philadelphia the weekend after the coroner's report about Mr. Hughes's death supported her speculation.
John Tartol, a Malibu-based distributor who is part of the Chairman's Club, said 3,500 distributors turned out. He said he had expected to get phone calls after the release of the coroner's report. Only one came. He also expected distributors at the conference in Philadelphia to have questions about it.
"They're not concerned," he said, adding that Mr. Hughes had struggled with pneumonia and asthma this year, perhaps coming back to work too quickly and weakening himself. "It's kind of interesting there's been a new commitment. We're going to go out there and do it for Mark."

HEADLINE: Bankrolling Colombia's War on Drugs: House and Senate Will Now Reconcile Bills

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER MARQUIS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 22

 BODY:
Nearly a year after President Andres Pastrana of Colombia asked the United States for emergency aid to battle narcotics traffickers and their rebel allies, the Senate cleared the way today for a package of $1.3 billion.
The American assistance, which is to include money for training special Colombian army battalions and for sophisticated attack and transport helicopters, advanced as senators approved a $13.4 billion foreign aid bill that included the money for the besieged South American nation. 
 The legislation also included about $1.5 billion to keep American troops in Kosovo and an undisclosed amount -- officials estimated about $500 million -- to pay for reconstruction in Los Alamos, N.M., after a devastating fire.
Congressional officials said today that they expect to reconcile the Senate aid package for Colombia with a more generous version approved by the House in March and then attach it to a popular bill to pay for military construction as early as next week.
While the legislation approved today would provide slightly under $1 billion to Colombia, senators said the figure would rise to $1.3 billion in the final compromise bill with the House.
The aid package will result in a vastly increased American commitment in Colombia, a country in the midst of a civil war that is the source of 90 percent of the cocaine reaching the United States. Working closely with American officials, Mr. Pastrana unveiled an ambitious plan last year to pay for a Colombian military drive into rebel-controlled territory in the south.
Included in the plan is a request for 30 highly sophisticated long-range Blackhawk helicopters and at least 35 Huey II helicopters for ferrying troops, Colombian officials said. The specific mix of the American aircraft remains in dispute as House lawmakers approved the more expensive Blackhawks, while senators favored sending Hueys.
President Clinton, whose aides have warned that Colombia's viability as a nation is at stake, said he was "grateful" for the Senate action.
"The quicker we can reach agreement and show that the United States is committed to a democracy and to fighting the drug wars in Colombia, and to strengthening the oldest democracy in America, the better off we're going to be," Mr. Clinton said.
With strong American backing, Colombian officials will now be able to seek additional support from European nations and international financial institutions, Mr. Clinton said.
But some lawmakers said that the United States risks increasingly being drawn into an unwinnable war -- reminiscent of Vietnam -- with Colombian military allies that have a poor human rights record.
"We have made a profound and dramatic shift in focus from supporting a police force in a friendly country to supporting an army engaged in a civil war," said Senator Slade Gorton, a Washington Republican. "I wonder how long it will be until we read the first news story of some of this equipment showing up in the hands of rebels."
President Pastrana's strategy, called the Plan Colombia, seeks at least $3.5 billion in international aid in the next three years. In addition to expanding law enforcement, the plan calls for public investments to stimulate the lagging economy.
Senator Paul Coverdell, a Georgia Republican, said that the move today signaled "a turning point in this whole struggle" against Colombian drug cartels by demonstrating a strong bipartisan resolve to step up American support and provide training to special anti-narcotics battalions.
Colombian officials applauded the Senate action, which came in a 95-4 vote for the overall foreign aid bill.
"We are definitely pleased," said Luis Alberto Moreno, Colombia's ambassador to Washington. "This means there is strong bipartisan support behind Plan Colombia at a critical moment in Colombian history."
Mr. Moreno said Colombia will insist on the House-approved Blackhawks because of their superior versatility.
But even some Colombians voiced misgivings about the widening of the military campaign to suppress drugs.
Gen. Rosso Jose Serrano, the national police chief whose anti-narcotics leadership has won praise from American lawmakers, said the battle would best be waged by curbing demand in the United States and other countries.
"We'd rather see drug consumption drop than get any of this aid," said Mr. Serrano, who is stepping down this week after more than five years in his post. If consumption were dramatically reduced, Colombia "could go back to what it once was, a place that grew coffee, where people worked hard and sweated for a paycheck," he said in an interview with the Associated Press.
The Senate foreign aid bill was $1.7 billion less than the Clinton administration had requested, but it has not drawn a veto threat.
Under pressure from the Pentagon, senators approved money to keep nearly 6,000 American troops in Kosovo. The Clinton administration has fought to maintain the American presence in the Balkans, despite growing uneasiness in Congress over the open-ended United States commitment in both Kosovo and Bosnia.
The Senate also increased spending by $30 million to $255 million for international efforts to fight AIDS, and added $10 million for a total of $66 million to battle the global spread of tuberculosis. But it provided only $75 million in assistance to the world's poorest countries, a reduction from the administration's $262 million request.

HEADLINE: Evidence of Water Invigorates Study of Mars

BYLINE: By WARREN E. LEARY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 22

 BODY:
The standard description of Mars as cold, desolate and dry may have to be revised slightly. It now appears that Mars may have reservoirs of liquid water hidden under parts of its icy surface, a finding that could profoundly affect the search for life there, scientists said today.
Pictures taken from orbit by NASA's Mars Global Surveyor spacecraft have disclosed features in numerous places that look like gullies formed by flowing water carrying rocks and debris to the bottom of craters, according to a study released today. 
 The report, by Dr. Michael C. Malin and Dr. Kenneth S. Edgett of Malin Space Science Systems in San Diego, said that evidence suggested that these water flows happened in recent geological time -- perhaps just a few hundreds, thousands or millions of years ago, instead of billions of years in the past. And the researchers said it might still be occurring.
"We see features that look like gullies formed by flowing water and the deposits of soil and rocks transported by these flows," said Dr. Malin, whose company built the spacecraft camera that made the images. "These features appear to be so young that they might be forming today."
At a news conference today at NASA headquarters, the researchers said there was ample evidence that water once flowed on Mars in abundance, leaving ancient river beds and the markings of huge oceans. One of the big questions about Mars, Dr. Edgett said, has been, "Where did the water go?"
"The new pictures from Global Surveyor tell us part of the answer," he said. "Some of that water went underground, and quite possibly it's still there."
The researchers, whose study will be published next week in the journal Science, said that they found evidence for the flow of liquid water in 150 of 65,000 photos taken by the Surveyor's high resolution camera over the last two years. The evidence of water movement, in the form of gullies and channels terminating in fan-like deltas, appears recent because surfaces around these features are smooth and relatively light in color. Older areas on the planet are pocked with craters and covered with a dark dust, they said.
Both researchers said that they were surprised by evidence of possible present-day water because the finding did not fit into current models of what Mars was like. Most of the spots that appear to be the source of flowing water are on slopes with exposed rock layers, they said, raising the possibility that liquid water is trapped below these layers and is freed by a surface shift.
A specialist in possible water on Mars who was not involved with the study, Dr. Michael H. Carr, a planetary geologist with the United States Geological Survey in Menlo Park, Calif., called the images "exciting," saying the gullies and channels looked like water-worn features seen from the air in the western United States. However, he said, he was skeptical about the researchers' theory that there was liquid water in layers 300 to 1,300 feet below the surface that occasionally burst out from the walls of certain craters and canyons.
Dr. Carr, author of "Water on Mars" (Oxford, 1996), said Mars was so cold, with an average temperature of 60 degrees below zero, that any water this near the surface should have been frozen solid. While the new pictures showed important, new Martian features, he said, he was skeptical of the explanations for the apparent flows. "Either this interpretation is wrong or there is some mechanism we don't know of to keep water liquid under these conditions," Dr. Carr said.
Dr. Edgett said a possible explanation for the features was that water, kept liquid by an unknown means, would freeze and form an ice dam as it flowed from an underground source. The ice dam would retard the flow until there was enough force to break through the barrier, sending the water in a rapid cascade down the slope, much like a flash flood. The water would quickly freeze as its motion slowed and then would quickly boil off into gas because of the planet's low atmospheric pressure, he said, but not before spreading rocks and mud down the slope.
Dr. Edward J. Weiler, NASA's chief scientist, said that if there were liquid water on Mars, it would have profound implications for the question of life on Mars, both in the past and today, and where to search for it. "If life ever did develop there, and if it survives to the present time, then these landforms would be great places to look," he said.
Dr. Weiler said the findings would have to be verified and explained if they were to become widely accepted. And he cautioned against exaggerating the discovery, alluding to some news reports on the find in recent days. "There is possible evidence of liquid water," he said. "They have not found lakes or rivers flowing on Mars. They have not found hot springs. They certainly have not found hot tubs with Martians in them."
If the presence of subsurface water was proved, Dr. Weiler said, it could fuel a desire to send humans to Mars. Water would make a human trip more feasible and economical because it could be used to make oxygen for astronauts to breathe and hydrogen for fuel for the return trip to Earth. But a human trip would only come after extensive robot missions to characterize the planet and find the best landing sites, he said, an effort that could take decades.
Dr. Bruce Jakosky, director of the Center for Astrobiology at Colorado University, said the key to finding life on Mars was liquid water. The new findings, possibly finding water where least expected, shows that Mars will be more difficult to understand than some scientists have believed and that any life that might be there could be in unexpected places.
"On Earth," Dr. Jakosky said, "wherever you find liquid water below the boiling temperature, then you find life." The latest discovery "doesn't tell us that life does exist on Mars, but it is the smoking gun that tells us Mars has all of the elements for life," he said.

HEADLINE: House Auctions Gain Favor in an eBay World

BYLINE: By DAVID W. CHEN 

DATELINE: IRVINGTON, N.Y., June 21

 BODY:
The auction was barely under way, but already, Thomas and Gloria Fatato were feeling out of place in the Tudor-style house they had built 20 years ago.
Strangers were nibbling on hors d'oeuvres and sipping on fume blanc. A ponytailed musician teased out "Puttin' on the Ritz" and "Cheek to Cheek" on a Yamaha synthesizer. A veritable army of auctioneers from the National Auction Group of Gadsden, Ala., all wearing matching American-flag ties, were doing their officious best to prod, prod, prod. 
 Then, when the bidding for the Fatatos' house stagnated at $975,000, one of the guys with the American-flag ties, Jack Ogle, rapped his knuckles on a glass shelf in the living room. In a Southern drawl, he bellowed: "That's opportunity knocking tonight like it's never knocked before in this area!"
So maybe the modus operandi was not pitch-perfect for the grizzled New York crowd. Still, for most people at the auction held here this month, this odd cocktail of one part culture clash, one part high-stakes poker, was their first taste of a national phenomenon that has proliferated in recent years: the sale of houses and apartments at auction.
These slickly promoted events with the trappings of a wedding or a fund-raiser are a far cry from the enduring image of a foreclosed house being sold on the courthouse steps. Instead, the auctions appeal to a faster-paced, time-pressed society accustomed to speculating on art, stocks and everything else, in person or over the Internet -- a society, in short, with an eBay mentality.
"We have a whole generation of Internet babies who love the auctions and are used to it," said Lee Mills, a lawyer, investment banker and powerboat racer from Key West, Fla., whose 13-acre estate in Woodstock, N.Y., was sold at auction for a higher-than-expected $2 million several years ago. "It's a lot of entertainment, a lot of theater, and I believe it's the trend of the future."
Auctioneers and real estate brokers estimate that there are now at least 1,000 auctions of residential properties around the country each year, compared with 200 five years ago and only a handful 10 years ago. Meanwhile, the value of all forms of real estate sold at auction increased from $21 billion in 1986 to $49 billion in 1998, according to the Gwent Group, an auction-research company in Bloomington, Ind.
On average the auctions can net 80 to 90 percent of the property's appraised value, which is a shade below what traditional sales can bring. But some traditional brokers dismiss the auctions as marketing ploys or annoying competition, said Jan Tarnow, manager of the auction department of the National Association of Realtors. "There's still some of that us-versus-them mentality," she said.
A few years ago, these auctions usually involved lavish estates of thousands of acres, owned by people like former Senator Lloyd Bentsen and the singer Kenny Rogers. On June 8, Christie's Realty International auctioned off a newly listed 2,800-square-foot brownstone on Manhattan's East Side designed by Philip Johnson and once owned by Blanchette Rockefeller. The winning bid was $11.16 million -- more than double the estimate -- and set a record for the highest sale price per square foot in Manhattan, according to Christie's. (The winning bidder was not disclosed; one of the nonwinners was Mr. Mills.)
Now, though, the auctions are also becoming less stratospheric. On Sunday, Sheldon Good & Company, a Chicago company, plans to auction off 50 condominiums in Battery Park City and Midtown Manhattan for $200,000 to $800,000 apiece, both in person and over the Internet, said Steven L. Good, the company's chief executive.
In other countries, particularly Australia, selling real estate at auction is considered the norm. But in the United States, the word "auction" still conjures up bad images, dating back to the Depression era, of fast-talking hucksters preying upon vulnerable people. And the recent fiasco involving a painting's price being manipulated on eBay doesn't help.
For some people, too, the packaging -- Want a mariachi band? A harpist? Some bacon-wrapped quail? -- is a distraction and a gimmick.
"It was a circus," grumbled John Aronian III, a retired surgeon in Westchester who attended the Fatatos' auction. "It was good ol' boys from down South. It was like a hog auction."
Then again, with prime real estate still in short supply in a good economy, more buyers and sellers are willing to gamble on an auction to create good prices.
For sellers, auctions may be appealing because they can greatly accelerate the sales process, reducing the costs of a mortgage, taxes, insurance and maintenance. Buyers, who must bring a certified check to the auction -- $50,000 in the Irvington sale -- are expected to do their own inspections or buy the house on an as-is basis. They then have a set period of time, usually 30 days, to arrange financing and set a closing date.
And a growing number of sellers are opting for auctions because their job or family situation has changed suddenly, or their property is unusual, said J. Craig King, president of the J. P. King Auction Company, in Gadsden, Ala.
People are naturally competitive, too. At an auction, it is not just a matter of keeping up with the Joneses, but eclipsing the Joneses, and in their presence.
"Watch the people sizing each other up: it's like, 'Hmm,' " said Barbara Corcoran, president of the Corcoran Group, a Manhattan real estate company, which plans to auction properties solely on the Internet. "It puts any French cafe to shame."
Or, as William R. Bone, president of the National Auction Group, put it: "It reaches a point where egos take over. It's not dollars and cents; it's egos."
On a recent Tuesday, it was the Fatatos' turn. The owner of a beer distribution company in the Bronx, Mr. Fatato, 58, and his wife, 52, had tried unsuccessfully for more than a year to sell their house to move to a smaller one in Rockland County. The original price was $1.7 million, but the house was too opulent for the neighborhood, with glass-and-mirror decor that had not changed since it was designed 20 years ago.
Unfortunately, rain forced the event indoors. Still, there were 10 bidders, an unusually high number, most of whom did not want to give their names.
Some were young professionals from Manhattan. At least two people were considering auctions for their own properties, one on the Hudson River, the other in Litchfield, Conn. Everyone was itching with expectation.
Then, shortly after 8 p.m., show time. The auctioneer, Eddie Haynes, a member of the Oklahoma Auctioneers Hall of Fame, tried to oil the crowd with folksy charm. First, he auctioned off a bottle of Dom Perignon to Mr. Fatato for $125 for charity. Then he asked loudly: "We having fun yet?"
"I'm having fun!" blurted another auctioneer, Wayne Thorn.
The Fatatos chose perhaps the riskiest method: an absolute auction, without reserve and without a minimum bid, where the final price is the final price, even if it is $1. The Fatatos did have the option to cancel at the last minute, but they did not, and soon, Mr. Haynes started the bidding at $750,000.
It was a loud and chaotic scene, with people spilling into the living, dining, kitchen and foyer areas. And slowly, tentatively, the price climbed; past $800,000, past $900,000.
When the bidding halted at $975,000, Mr. Haynes tried repeatedly to whip the crowd into a frenzy, to no avail. The hammer price was $975,000, bid by a young Russian immigrant family in Manhattan, said their broker, Neil Singh.
The final price, actually, was almost $1.1 million, because of the additional 10 percent charged by the auction company.
The Fatatos were overwhelmed and exhausted by the experience. "You put your whole life into their hands, and whatever they say, you believe," Mr. Fatato said, a few days after the auction. "Who knows, it could have gone higher. But it happened so quick. I'm still trying to figure it out."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Shares Fall as Investors Speculate About Rate Increase

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Stocks declined yesterday as investors cashed in on recent gains, particularly in technology shares, amid speculation that the Federal Reserve might increase interest rates again this year.
Stoking the sell-off were fears that rising oil prices, which have topped $2 for a gallon of gasoline in the Midwest, could intensify a slowdown in the economy and possibly lead to an uptick in inflation. 
 "We are witnessing what could be a bad combination -- higher interest rates when higher oil prices are in place," said Alan Ackerman, market strategist at Fahnestock & Company. "We are in a period of what I call interest rate paralysis. Until we know what the Fed is going to do, there are unlikely to be any heroes in the market."
A majority of Wall Street traders say they believe that the central bank will leave interest rates unchanged at its policy-setting meeting on Tuesday and Wednesday, but a growing number see an increase at the Fed's Aug. 22 meeting. The Fed wants to strike a balance between a too-hot economy that leads to inflation and a too-slow economy that creates unemployment and hurts corporate profits.
The technology-laden Nasdaq composite index tumbled 127.17 points, or 3.1 percent, to 3,936.84, after racking up its fifth consecutive higher close on Wednesday. The drag came from Nasdaq stars like the computer networking giant Cisco Systems Inc., which was down 2 7/8, to 64 9/16.
The downward pressure also got the best of Microsoft, which had been trading higher most of the session after the company disclosed a plan to integrate its software with the Internet. Microsoft fell 13/16, to 79 7/8.
Microsoft, a component of the Dow Jones industrial average, added to the woes of the blue-chip index. The Dow declined 121.62 points, or 1.2 percent, to 10,376.12.
Broader market measures also weakened. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was off 26.95 points, or 1.8 percent, to 1,452.18.
The market had slid early and then recovered before falling back again. But analysts downplayed the impact of rumors that the chairman of the Fed, Alan Greenspan, was involved in a traffic accident in Chicago, which was later denied by the Fed.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 1/32, to 104, while the bond's yield remained unchanged at 5.96 percent. The price of the 10-year Treasury note was unchanged at 102 28/32, and its yield remained at 6.10 percent.
The Dow's financial services components were mixed, but technology and pharmaceutical names all sank. Among the drug stocks yielding ground were Johnson & Johnson, off 15/16, to 88 9/16, and Merck & Company, down 13/16, to 71 1/4.
Traders said it would be hard for the market to regain its footing before the Fed announces its decision on interest rates on Wednesday.
In a recent Reuters poll, all 29 primary dealers of Treasuries said they expected the Fed to leave short-term rates unchanged after an aggressive increase of half a percentage point on May 16.
But the survey also found that 26 dealers thought that the Fed planned at least one more quarter-point increase, probably at its Aug. 22 meeting.

HEADLINE: Senate Democrats Rebuffed on a Drugs Bill

BYLINE: By LIZETTE ALVAREZ 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 22

 BODY:
Senate Democrats tonight abruptly forced the first vote of the year on their prescription drug plan, a politically potent issue on the campaign trail, but the measure was swiftly defeated by Republicans.
The bill, which would lower drug prices for all Medicare beneficiaries, was rejected by a vote of 53 to 44. Two Republicans voted in favor of the measure; one Democrat voted against it. 
 At a time when public opinion polls show the rising prices for prescription drugs as a priority among voters, Senate Democrats seized on a parliamentary trick today to force a vote on their bill. In so doing, they accomplished two political goals: They got the chance to talk about their plan for making prescription drugs more affordable to senior citizens and they forced Republicans to cast a difficult vote, perhaps the only one of the year, on the issue.
"When Medicare was passed, there was a fundamental commitment by the government to senior citizens," said Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, who accused Senate Republicans of stalling on a bipartisan plan. "Every day we fail to pass a prescription drug program, we are violating that commitment."
Republicans scoffed at the maneuver, calling it an unadulterated political stunt that was rushed, short-sighted and counterproductive. The prescription drug bill was brought up as part of a larger appropriations bill to provide money for the departments of Labor and Health and Human Services, and was allowed on the floor with no notice and with less than one hour of debate.
"This is a politics-first amendment," said an outraged Senator Phil Gramm, Republican of Texas. "Nobody knows what it costs, how it works, what it does to the solvency of Medicare. This is politics at its worst. This body is offended by it. I'm offended by it. I don't think voters will be impressed by circumventing the process."
The Senate also voted to approve a contentious and heavily lobbied amendment to delay by one year federal regulations that would require employers to take steps to prevent repetitive motion injuries. The House already approved the measure.
The amendment, which was bitterly contested by labor unions who want these worker protections as soon as possible, passed by a vote of 57 to 41, after Democrats spent the day filibustering the measuring.
The Clinton administration said it would recommend a veto of the spending bill if the measure is not removed. Business groups vigorously pushed to delay the regulations, which would make the workplace ergonomically correct -- rules they say are too broad and too expensive and could cost employers, by their estimate, $60 billion a year.
"This will have the most dramatic effect upon business and the economy ever promulgated by a federal agency," said Senator Tim Hutchinson, Republican of Arkansas. "We are talking about $60 billion a year imposed upon the business community."
But the most surprising turn of events involved prescription drugs, which descended on the Senate seemingly out of the blue.
For months, Democrats have accused Senate Republicans of stalling on the issue of prescription drugs, and some predicted today's vote could be the only Senate vote of the year on the matter.
The Senate Finance Committee, whose chairman is Senator William V. Roth Jr., Republican of Delaware, is working on a bipartisan bill that would address concerns about prescription drug prices. But Democrats say the committee is inching along and is unlikely to move at all on the issue this year.
"Prescription drugs is a matter before the finance committee," Mr. Roth told Democrats on the floor. "It is undoubtedly the most important domestic legislation that will be considered this year. Nothing will happen if we permit this legislation to become partisan."
House Republicans voted their own drug plan out of committee on Wednesday, but Democrats called it faulty, saying it should be better integrated into the Medicare system.
Under today's Democratic bill, written by Senator Bob Graham, Democrat of Florida, drug insurance companies' premiums for Medicare beneficiaries would be $35 to $40 a month, the same as under the House Republican measure.
The beneficiary would have to pay the first $250 a year in prescription drug expenses. The government would share costs beyond that amount, paying a larger proportion as drug expenses increased.
Liberal Democrats signed on to the bill once Mr. Graham agreed to drop a provision that would have forced people with high incomes to pay higher premiums. Now, premiums will not be dictated by income.
This is significantly different from the proposal offered by House Republicans. Under that plan, Medicare would pay half of drug costs from $250 to $2,100, but the patient would then be solely responsible for several thousand dollars of drug costs, and the insurer would not step in again until the beneficiary had incurred $6,000 of costs.
"It is clearly a part of modern medicine today," said Senator Charles S. Robb, Democrat of Virginia, referring to the drug plan. "It is not a luxury."

HEADLINE: Lawmakers Step Up Scrutiny Of Price Increases for Gasoline

BYLINE: By RICHARD A. OPPEL Jr. with EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: DALLAS, June 22

 BODY:
Oil prices showed no sign of retreating a day after OPEC decided to increase production, and lawmakers stepped up calls for investigations into "price gouging" in the gasoline market.
Lawmakers are especially concerned about the Midwest. While pump prices are at record levels in much of the nation, they have had an astounding rise in the Midwest. Retail prices in Milwaukee and Chicago have soared as much as 70 cents a gallon in the last two months because of pipeline disruptions and a federally mandated switch to a new cleaner-burning fuel that incorporates ethanol. 
 Despite the 2.6 percent rise in crude oil prices yesterday, the price of gasoline in the Midwest may have finally leveled off, some officials said. New supplies are coming on the market, refiners have increased production of the new gas and wholesale prices have fallen.
The Federal Trade Commission, which is investigating whether the soaring prices could be a result of industry collusion, expects to report its findings to Congress by the third week of July, said Robert Pitofsky, the agency's chairman. The F.T.C. is expected to begin issuing subpoenas within days, and some lawmakers want industry chief executives to be required to testify on the matter.
President Clinton, facing a political firestorm over the issue, said he believed there was "no economic explanation" for the high Midwest prices. Vice President Al Gore, the presumed Democratic presidential candidate, reiterated his belief that industry collusion may be stoking the problem.
But industry officials blame supply problems, low inventories of gasoline and the June 1 switch to the cleaner fuel, and they point to a recent Congressional Research Service report suggesting that the cleaner-gas mandate and pipeline problems had added 50 cents to the price of a gallon of gas in some parts of the Midwest.
Gasoline prices have been high this year, after OPEC's move in March 1999 to reduce oil production. But since the beginning of May, average pump prices for regular gasoline have soared almost 30 cents nationally, while Chicago and Milwaukee, two of the cities required to use the new cleaner-burning fuel as of June 1, have had far higher increases.
In futures trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange today, crude oil for August delivery rose 82 cents, to $32.19 a barrel. And gasoline for July delivery, which reflects wholesale prices, soared more than 4 cents, to $1.0813 a gallon.
The runup has become a major political issue, as Mr. Gore and officials at the Environmental Protection Agency have sought to deflect criticism that the high prices are because of the mandate for cleaner-burning reformulated gas. They have suggested some companies may be making too much money at the expense of drivers.
For certain, industry profits are soaring. About three months ago, Wall Street analysts were predicting second-quarter profits of $5.5 billion for the seven major United States oil companies, according to First Call/Thomson Financial, which tracks corporate earnings. Now analysts are predicting combined profits will be about $6.5 billion. That compares with about $3 billion during last year's second quarter.
But many analysts are skeptical that federal officials will find evidence of illegal behavior. "This is a political sop," said Philip K. Verleger, who has served as a consultant to the F.T.C. and the State of California on past investigations into high gas prices and is now a senior adviser at the Brattle Group, an economic consulting firm in Cambridge, Mass. "They aren't going to find anything."
Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, the presumed Republican presidential nominee and a former oilman who has taken almost $1.5 million in political contributions from the oil and gas industry, according to the Center for Responsive Politics, has said he welcomes the investigation into possible industry collusion. But he blames the Clinton administration for not doing a better job in cajoling OPEC to increase production. Some lawmakers in Congress also took a swipe at OPEC today, saying they would introduce a bill to allow the Justice Department to look into possible antitrust violations by the cartel.
But OPEC ministers in Vienna, who met this week and agreed to raise production by 708,000 barrels a day, complain that the United States is at fault for the high prices. They blame the new cleaner-burning gas rules, which affect about one-third of the nation, and they also contend that American refiners cut back purchases drastically last year to avoid buying oil at prices they considered temporarily high.
"It is not an OPEC problem," said Ali Rodriguez, Venezuela's oil minister and the current president of OPEC. "In the last year, refinery runs have been very low and we saw a great decline in" inventories.
Sheik Saud Nasser Al-Sabah, Kuwait's oil minister, said: "This is also a responsibility of the major consuming countries. They should get their own houses in order."
Top Saudi officials, who have been the leading advocates of production increases, are genuinely alarmed about what they view as prices that are too high to be stable. But they argue that the supply of crude oil is only a peripheral part of the problem.
One Saudi official contended that United States oil companies refused to invest in added capacity even when refining margins were high, and though the Saudis do not want to be drawn into the political debate about the mandate for the new cleaner fuel, this official asserted that the rules were imposed without paying attention to the situation of United States refiners.
Since their initial decision to increase production three months ago, OPEC ministers have said they want to keep oil trading roughly within a band of $22 to $28. But Saudi officials believe the price band is being constantly tested by the markets, and they now say they should not be held hostage by short-term price movements, especially if those are being driven by speculation.
But Iran's oil minister, Bijan Namdar Zanganeh, was more conciliatory. Having angrily denounced Energy Secretary Bill Richardson in March, Mr. Zanganeh went out of his way today to note that there was no external pressure on OPEC this time, and that was the reason that Iran had no difficulty in joining the OPEC action.
"You and me and Mr. Richardson have all learned a lesson," Mr. Zanganeh told reporters. "It was a very good test for the market. Many sources expected the volume of production would decrease the price of oil significantly, but it hasn't happened. It means we have some new factors in the market."
Asked what he thought the biggest culprit behind high oil prices is, he said, "RFG," referring to the new cleaner-burning reformulated gasoline.

HEADLINE: President Offers Criticism Of 'Bush-Lazio Tax Plan'

BYLINE: By MARC LACEY 

 BODY:
President Clinton has sought to boost the political fortunes of his wife and his vice president by condemning Republican tax cut proposals -- the "Bush-Lazio tax plan," in his words -- as dangerous to the country's prosperity.
At a fund-raiser in Washington on Wednesday night that raised $200,000 for Hillary Rodham Clinton's bid for a Senate seat from New York, Mr. Clinton lashed out at Representative Rick A. Lazio for the first time since he replaced New York City Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani on the Republican side of the race for the Senate. 
 Mr. Lazio has yet to endorse Texas Gov. George W. Bush's proposed tax cut. "The first casualty of any Clinton campaign has historically been the truth," said Dan McLagan, a spokesman for Mr. Lazio.
The president said he was confident his wife would, in time, overcome questions from critics about why she was running for office in New York. He portrayed her pursuit of the Senate seat as a sacrifice -- a decision to put public service ahead of getting "real rich" after life in the White House.
"For 30 years, she's worked for me and worked on the side. The whole time we were in Arkansas, she gave away lots of potential income every year just to do public service, because it's what she wanted to do," he said. "And I can just tell you that in a lot of ways, she's better than I am on a lot of this stuff, and she knows things I don't know."
Mr. Clinton said he was amused that Republicans have circulated statements he has made praising Mr. Lazio for supporting various legislation.
"It was a gas that he would try to give the people of New York the impression that I'd prefer him to my wife in the Senate," Mr. Clinton said, "because she would have voted for my economic plan, not against it. And she would have voted against the contract on America, not for it. She wouldn't vote to shut the government down and get rid of the Department of Education, or get rid of the 100,000 police that lowered the crime rate in New York and other places."
Even as he jabbed at Mr. Lazio, the president made the case that Mrs. Clinton's Senate race and Vice President Al Gore's bid for the presidency should be decided on issues, not attacks.
"It's no longer necessary to have one of these sort of mudslinging campaigns where everybody tries to convince everybody else that their opponent is just one step above a car thief," he said.
Mr. Clinton said Republican proposals to grant large tax cuts would go so far that they would endanger the economy.
"I believe if you have a Bush-Lazio tax plan, and it passed, you'd all be better off the day after because all of you can afford to come here today," Mr. Clinton told the 25 donors gathered at a Georgetown home for seafood canneloni, veal medallions and lemon souffle. "But you wouldn't be better off if it led to an increase in interest rates. In two years, the impact it would have on the markets, on the overall economy, on the unemployment rate: you'd be worse off. And the overall economy would be worse off, and we wouldn't have the money to do things."
Mr. Clinton, who made a fund-raising trip yesterday that took him from Washington to Phoenix to San Diego, said the outcome of the presidential election, and the Senate race in New York State, would hinge on whether voters realized how much was at stake.
"People ask me all the time, 'Well, who's going to win?' " Mr. Clinton said. " 'Do you think the vice president is going to win?' I say yes. 'Do you think Hillary is going to win?' I say yes. And I do -- on both counts. 'Do you think the Democrats will win back the Congress?' Of course, I say, yes. But here's the real truth -- who will win this election depends upon, more than anything else, what the people of America think the election is about. The question you ask may determine the answer you get."
That question, Mr. Clinton said, ought to be: Who is best suited to keep the prosperity going?

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE DEMOCRATS;
New Chairman Makes Debut As Gore Camp Gets Bad News

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: NASHVILLE, June 22

 BODY:
William M. Daley, the new chairman of Vice President Al Gore's presidential campaign, acknowledged today that one of the biggest challenges facing Mr. Gore was that Gov. George W. Bush was getting credit for the economy, the issue on which Mr. Gore had been basing his hopes.
But, Mr. Daley said, that was a "knee jerk" reaction and he hoped to counter it by recruiting supporters from big business and labor to come to Nashville, where Mr. Gore's campaign is based. 
 "He is right now," Mr. Daley said of Mr. Bush's receiving credit. "I don't know if it's just kind of a gut thing, but Republicans have always historically got more credit for running the economy, and being good for the economy, even at the height of the deficit.
"So I think we've got a challenge to remind people what things were like in 1992, and we've got a challenge to remind them that, fine, you may take this eight years of economic expansion for granted, but tough decisions were made."
Still, Mr. Daley hastened to add that he understood the size of the task ahead of him. "I'm not being Pollyannish about how difficult a presidential campaign is," he said.
Mr. Daley, the secretary of commerce, spoke in an interview here as he made his debut in Mr. Gore's headquarters as chairman on a day when the Gore camp had to absorb another round of bad news.
A Justice Department official has recommended that an independent counsel be named to investigate Mr. Gore's role in the Democrats' questionable fund-raising activities of 1996. Two new national polls showed Mr. Gore slipping further behind Mr. Bush. And James P. Hoffa, the powerful labor leader, appeared with Ralph Nader, the Green Party candidate who could siphon enough votes from Mr. Gore to cost him a few key states.
A new Wall Street Journal/NBC News poll, taken during the start of Mr. Gore's "prosperity and progress tour," which was intended to showcase the booming economy, put Mr. Bush ahead of Mr. Gore 49 percent to 41 percent. A bipartisan Battleground 2000/Voter.com poll showed Mr. Bush ahead by 12 percentage points.
Mr. Daley said that part of his task would be to bring business and labor interests together and urge officials to move to Nashville to dedicate themselves to Mr. Gore's candidacy. The Wall Street Journal poll showed that voters give Mr. Gore an advantage of only a single percentage point -- statistically meaningless -- on his ability to handle the economy.
"We want to get people from labor and business down here," Mr. Daley said in an interview in his office, which will serve as his command post until the November election. "I'm asking people, 'You want to help? Fine. When are you going to leave your job and come to Nashville?' "
Mr. Daley takes the reins officially on July 15, when he leaves his cabinet post. He succeeds Tony Coelho, the campaign's former chairman, who resigned last week for health reasons.
Mr. Coelho said in an interview with Bloomberg.com that his health was worse than he had indicated last week. In addition to his epilepsy and inflammation of the colon, he told the news service, he has a brain cyst, though he does not know whether it is malignant.
"My seizures were getting worse," Mr. Coelho said of his epilepsy. "I was having stomach cramps, but I would work my way through them. I just had too much to do. Then, my sinuses above my eyes got infected and they became inflamed and shut down, basically."
After arriving from Washington, Mr. Daley met with Tennessee Democrats this morning. He then shook hands with all the campaign staff, including about 80 paid workers and 70 interns and volunteers, at their desks, and spoke to them collectively for about 15 minutes. Listeners described his comments in the meeting, which was closed to reporters, as welcoming and inspirational.
Mr. Daley described his message to the staff as being "all about grinding it out for four and a half months."
He said in the interview that it was too soon to discuss any changes he had in mind, but he cautioned that the campaign would "not lurch this way and that."
"You just lay out a strategy and go for it, and you don't jump around," he said. "It's really easy for someone who's not following the ebb and flow every day to be criticizing it. You've got to really get into it to understand what the hell's going on, and that takes a while."

HEADLINE: Amid Protest, Rent Increases Are Approved

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT 

 BODY:
Adopting the highest increases since 1996, the New York City Rent Guidelines Board last night approved 4 percent for one-year leases and 6 for two-year leases.
The increases cover the city's one million rent-stabilized apartments and apply to leases renewed between Oct. 1, 2000, and Sept. 30, 2001. 
 The board also adopted a $15-a-month surcharge on all apartments renting for less than $500. Tenant advocates, who had hoped to see that provision dropped, called it a "poor tax" on the people least able to pay. But landlords said it was needed to help them meet the basic overhead costs of operation.
For lofts, the board approved increases of 3 percent for one-year leases and 5 percent for two-year leases. It also adopted a 2 percent increase for one-year leases for residents of hotels, rooming and lodging houses and single-room-occupancy apartments.
Although the board went through its ritual series of failed motions for bigger and smaller increases, in the end the adopted resolutions closely followed the preliminary proposals the board issued last month.
A tenant-dominated crowd of about 300 booed and jeered the board's actions, which were taken in the auditorium of Cooper Union. But tensions were much reduced compared with last week's public hearing, when board officials ordered the police to eject several people for outbursts, and four were arrested.
"Freeze our rents, freeze our rents," the crowd began chanting last night. Overpowered in decibels, the board decided to take a strategic recess. Then 15 or 20 demonstrators occupied the stage and even commandeered the board's chairs and microphones. Some carried signs saying: "Rudy don't raise our rent."
The board chairman, Edward S. Hochman, took the protest in stride and even posed briefly with some demonstrators for news photographers. After a few minutes, plainclothes police officers gently ushered the protesters off the stage, and eventually the board members reappeared and resumed the meeting.
Landlord groups had sought far bigger increases -- 9 percent for one year and 15 percent for two -- citing soaring fuel oil prices and other costs.
"We tried to convince some board members that the soaring oil prices that some say is a temporary spike is not a temporary spike," said Joseph Strasburg, president of the Rent Stabilization Association, which represents apartment-building owners.
But tenant advocates had called for no rent increases, contending that rising landlord profits meant that owners were already overcompensated.
"Disgraceful -- the whole process was disgraceful," said Michael McKee, the associate director of the New York Tenants and Neighbors Coalition. "Tenants can't get a break from the Giuliani administration."
Before the voting began, Mr. Hochman said, "This has obviously been a difficult year for the board." Anticipating both the board's decision and the reactions to it, he said, "If we upset both sides, we have probably done the best job we can."
For five of the last six years, the board has echoed the economy's low-inflation trends by approving modest increases of 2 percent for one-year leases and 4 percent for two-year leases.
The one exception came in 1996, when the board approved increases of 5 percent and 7 percent. The major issue this year -- as in 1996 -- was soaring prices for fuel oil for heat and hot water.
Tenant advocates contended that oil costs fluctuate and complained that although the 1996 rise in prices proved to be temporary, rents were never lowered to make up for it. Landlords countered that they had already suffered this year by paying high oil prices not covered by the last rent increase. They also cited predictions of continued high prices.
Over the years, the board's increases have tended to moderate the swings in operating costs, restraining rent increases during high inflation and making up for that with modest increases during low inflation, Mr. Hochman said.
"Hopefully, things have worked out in the long term as fairly as possible," Mr. Hochman said.
Studies by the rent board's staff showed that operating prices experienced virtually zero increases in 1997 and 1998, although the board raised rents anyway. But the latest study showed that operating prices had jumped by 7.8 percent.
Another issue is profits. Board studies showed that landlords had reaped record income coupled with the smallest increase in expenses in nearly a decade, based on tax department data for 1998, the most recent available.
Net operating income rose by 11.8 percent, which exceeded the previous year's record of 11.4 percent. The board has been tracking net income for nine years.
Tenants said that the statistics showed that any increase was unwarranted. But owner representatives said the numbers were misleading because their industry was still recovering from a collapse in the real estate market in the late 1980's.
Mr. Hochman caused fear in tenants earlier this year when he proposed adopting formula calculations that could have produced increases of 8.5 percent for one-year leases and 12 percent for two-year leases.
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who appoints the board, immediately distanced himself from that proposal, calling such increases "very, very high."
