HEADLINE: Metro Briefing

BYLINE: Compiled by Anthony Ramirez

 BODY:

NEW YORK
 
MANHATTAN: MORE PARK ARRESTS
Five more suspects in the Central Park attacks were arrested yesterday, bringing to 25 the number accused of sexually abusing women after the National Puerto Rican Day Parade on June 11. One man, Aerial Boxill, 28, of New Haven, surrendered to detectives, while Darrell Jamison, 18, of Queens and Abel Ortiz, 23, of the Bronx were apprehended by detectives. All three were charged with one count of sexual abuse and one count of riot. Detective Robert Samuel, a police spokesman, said that two others, Juan Miranda, 22, of Paterson, N.J., and Felix Collazo, 22, of the Lower East Side, were charged with sexual abuse. The Police Department is still seeking 17 suspects. C.J. Chivers (NYT) 

ALBANY: WEST NILE TESTS
The State Health Department said yesterday that two more birds from Rockland County had tested positive for West Nile virus. An infected crow was found in Clarkstown and an infected blue jay was found in Orangetown. Earlier this month, the virus was found in three crows from Rockland County and New Jersey. Last year, dead birds, especially crows, were present in areas where people were found carrying the West Nile virus. Officials said Rockland County residents should use mosquito repellent outdoors at night. Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)
 
ALBANY: PATAKI'S BALKANS TRIP
Gov. George E. Pataki will lead a four-day, fact-finding delegation to Kosovo, Montenegro and Bosnia next week, his office announced yesterday. Others in the delegation will include members of policy-study groups, journalists, academics and business people. The group will meet with government and other leaders in the Balkans to assess security and economic concerns. The trip is being organized by the American Enterprise Institute, a policy group.Richard Perez-Pena (NYT)
 
MANHATTAN: MUSLIM FIREFIGHTERS SUE
A group representing Islamic firefighters filed a lawsuit against the city in federal court in Manhattan yesterday, asserting the Fire Department discriminated against Muslim firefighters. The Fire Department's Islamic Society said the department ignored requests to add an Islamic representative to the staff of six departmental chaplains. The society also said that the department inspected mosques on Fridays, the Muslim sabbath, and that other religions were provided with prayer rooms at headquarters. A Fire Department spokesman declined to comment. John Sullivan (NYT)
 
SYRACUSE: ONEIDA RULING
A federal judge ruled yesterday that attempts to reach a settlement in the land-claim lawsuit filed by the Oneida nation against two counties in upstate New York had failed, forcing a trial. Judge Neal McCurn of Federal District Court in Syracuse handed down the written ruling but did not set a trial date. In their suit, the Oneidas are seeking sovereignty over 250,000 acres of land in Oneida and Madison Counties, while the counties said they would cede only 25,000 acres. As part of a deal, the state sought a quarter of revenues of an Oneida casino, which the Oneidas refused. The Oneidas have asked the court to add 20,000 landowners as defendants. Edward Wong (NYT)
 
YONKERS: SCHOOL PROTEST
The police arrested nine people in front of Yonkers City Hall on Wednesday as about 30 people protested the firing of the city's first black schools superintendent, Andre J. Hornsby. Singing "We Shall Overcome," the protesters criticized what they called the racist policies of Mayor John Spencer, left, who appointed the school board that fired Dr. Hornsby on Friday. Nine protesters lay down on the street, snarling traffic for about 10 minutes. Kate Zernike (NYT)
 
NEW JERSEY
 
PATERSON: BABY DEATH
The Passaic County prosecutor's office said yesterday that it would seek an adult murder trial for a 17-year-old Paterson woman charged with throwing her 16-month-old son into the Passaic River on June 3. If a judge eventually transfers the case from New Jersey Family Court to Superior Court and the woman is convicted of murder, she will face a sentence of 30 years to life instead of the Family Court maximum of 20 years. Robert Hanley (NYT)
 
NEWARK: WHITE SUPREMACISTS
Morris County can deny a white supremacist group permission to use the courthouse steps and lawn for a July 4 rally in Morristown, a federal judge ruled yesterday. But if the group uses another location, the county cannot force it to take out liability insurance or pay to police the event. The Nationalist Movement, based in Forsyth County, Miss., wants to protest the firing last year of Carl Williams as superintendent of the State Police after he linked drug crimes with minority groups. Steve Strunsky (NYT)
 
TRENTON: 2001 BUDGET DUE
With the fiscal year ending next week, legislative leaders announced yesterday that the 2001 budget would amount to $21.5 billion, up about $500 million from the current budget. The new budget will be released early today, said Leonard Lance, vice chairman of the Assembly Appropriations Committee. He said it would be up to $300 million more than Gov. Christine Todd Whitman had sought. Iver Peterson (NYT)
 
ROCKAWAY: WILDLIFE PRESERVE
Conservationists paid a developer $7 million yesterday for 295 wooded acres, expanding a wildlife preserve and preventing the planned construction of 108 houses. The Trust for Public Land, a conservation group, paid $1 million of the purchase price. The state paid $3.1 million and will own the property, which will be part of the Wildcat Ridge Wildlife Management Area. Steve Strunsky (NYT)
 
CONNECTICUT
 
BRIDGEPORT: CATHOLIC APPOINTMENT
Msgr. Laurence R. Bronkiewicz, chancellor of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Bridgeport, was elected Wednesday the diocese administrator until Pope John Paul II selects a permanent replacement for Edward M. Egan, who left Bridgeport to become archbishop of New York. As chancellor, Monsignor Bronkiewicz had been second in command of the diocese, which includes 360,000 Catholics in Fairfield County. David Herszenhorn (NYT)

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Blue Chips Rise, but Some Technology Issues Take a Hit

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Stocks were mixed yesterday, with blue-chip shares rising and technology stocks coming under selling pressure for the second consecutive day as investors locked in profits after a weeks-long run-up. Amazon.com plummeted 19 percent after an influential analyst warned of risks facing the online retailer.
The Dow Jones industrial average finished up 28.63 points, to 10,404.75. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was down 10.70 points, to 1,441.48, while the technology-laden Nasdaq composite index fell 91.50 points, or 2.3 percent, to 3,845.34. 
 Among the hardest hit of the technology stocks was Amazon.com, which plunged 8 1/8, to 33 7/8, after a Lehman Brothers' fixed-income analyst, Ravi Suria, released a research note describing "extremely weak and deteriorating" credit.
Other technology stocks that declined included Yahoo, which was off 6 3/8, to 125 5/16.
The losses in the technology sector were somewhat offset by gains in the semiconductor shares. Shares of Rambus rose 17 9/16 , to 114 11/16, after the memory chip maker said that it had ended its patent infringement lawsuit against Hitachi Ltd. Hitachi agreed to a worldwide licensing agreement on a variety of Rambus products.
Trading was light yesterday as investors watched their moves ahead of the Federal Reserve's regular meeting Tuesday and Wednesday. While there have been signs that the economy has been slowing in response to the Fed's six interest rate increases in the last year, traders are hesitant to make investment commitments when the Fed may still move to tighten credit further to keep inflation in check.
"The market hates uncertainty, and we have a big uncertainty in front of us," said Alfred E. Goldman, director of market analysis at A. G. Edwards & Sons Inc. in St. Louis. "When people are confused on Wall Street, they often keep their hands in their pockets."
Investors also worry that the slowing United States economy will eat away at corporate profits.
Treasury bond prices fell as investors await the outcome of the Federal Reserve policy meeting. A fresh corporate bond supply and robust oil prices also encouraged selling.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 1 2/32, to 102 31/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 6.03 percent from 5.96 percent on Thursday.
The price of the 10-year Treasury note fell 18/32, to 102 10/32. The note's yield rose to 6.18 percent from 6.10 percent on Thursday.

HEADLINE: Auto Sales May Be Feeling First Pinch of Higher Rates

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, June 23

 BODY:
Automakers say that despite recent deep discounts, auto sales have not picked up in June from the relatively subdued pace of May, providing evidence to the Federal Reserve that recent interest-rate increases may be slowing the American economy.
Auto executives and dealers say sales of luxury cars and luxury sport utility vehicles remain extremely strong. 
 But the mass market for more affordable cars, minivans, sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks has clearly softened as middle-class families have become leery of borrowing money at ever steeper rates, they said.
"Our Cadillacs are outselling our Pontiacs, and that has never happened to us before," said Michael Coy, the general manager of a dealership in Vancouver, Wash. The Cadillac buyers are frequently paying cash with their stock market profits, while traditional Pontiac customers are beginning to buy late-model used cars instead, he added.
Frank Ursomarso, a dealer in Wilmington, Del., said on Thursday that his seven dealerships had sold 159 vehicles in June, compared with 166 in the period last year, because less-prosperous buyers were shifting to used cars. "In my Jaguar, BMW and Volvo businesses, the pace is still very, very good -- those consumers who are more educated and more affluent are still buying," he said.
Automakers, especially DaimlerChrysler A.G., have been stepping up their rebates, with Dodge now offering discounts on every model except the Viper sports car. But the manufacturers have also been quietly raising the subsidized interest rates they offer on car loans. They have concluded that it has become too costly to continue offering loans at 1.9 percent and subsidizing the difference compared with market rates on auto loans, which are approaching 10 percent for a three-year loan.
Kevin Woods, the retail finance manager at Ford's lending unit, Ford Credit, said the discounted rates offered by Ford Credit were likely to rise another full percentage point when Ford adjusts rates in early July, even if Fed officials leave short-term rates unchanged next week as expected.
High gasoline prices appear to have had surprisingly little effect so far on the types of vehicles being sold, industry officials said. Even in the Midwest, where gasoline prices are highest, the biggest gas-guzzlers, mainly large sport utilities, are selling well because they are being purchased by households so affluent that they are not especially worried about the cost of fuel, they noted.
The auto industry sold cars and light trucks at a torrid seasonally adjusted annual rate of 18 million vehicles in the six-month period that ended on April 30. That pace cooled to a rate of 17.1 million vehicles in May, and both Ford and General Motors are predicting virtually the same rate -- 17 million -- for June.
The auto industry sold 17 million vehicles in all of last year, its best year ever, so the pace in the last two months does not represent a significant slowdown. But it still shows a contrast with the brisk pace last winter, as small and midsize cars, sport utility vehicles, minivans and pickup trucks are now beginning to clog some dealerships' lots.
Most automakers will be announcing their June sales on July 3, but DaimlerChrysler plans to wait until July 5. It will be very hard to judge the overall strength of sales in June until DaimlerChrysler reports because the company has become very aggressive in offering rebates after its sales plunged 16.8 percent in May. DaimlerChrysler had temporarily renounced most discounts in May in an unsuccessful attempt to persuade the industry to wean itself of its dependence on discounts.

HEADLINE: Mass Transit Fare Raised in Atlanta To Expand System

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: ATLANTA, June 23

 BODY:
After a long struggle to balance the need for expansion into suburban areas with the goal of keeping mass transit fares low for city residents, a $12 million deficit has forced public transit officials to make a choice, and they moved clearly in the direction of expansion.
On Monday, the board of directors of the Metropolitan Atlanta Rapid Transit Authority agreed to raise fares by 25 cents to finance the system's growth into the largely white northern suburbs. Marta officials say the $1.75 fare, which takes effect on Jan. 1, is needed to pay for two new rail stations opening in suburban north Fulton County. The increase is the first since 1995, and puts the cost of a flat fare at the upper end of urban transit systems around the country. 
 The expanded rail and bus service is intended to relieve some of the region's notorious traffic congestion, along with a smog problem that has become one of the worst of any major metropolitan area.
The addition of five new stations since 1995, special buses for the disabled, and the expansion of Marta's police force and station staff have forced the agency into the red in recent years, a Marta spokeswoman, Dee Baker, said.
Though half the construction cost of the new stations was paid with federal funds, Marta relies for the rest of its money on fare revenue and a 1-cent sales tax from the city of Atlanta and the two counties where Marta service is concentrated. Marta receives no money from the state.
"We are probably one of the only regions in the country that does not have a state transportation fund," Ms. Baker said, adding that this is unlikely to change in the near future. "In the short term, the only real alternative to the fare increase would be a decrease in service."
The agency has considered cutting back on bus service instead of a fare rise but is not expected to change its decision before Jan. 1.
Many riders and transit advocates in Atlanta argue that the fare increase unjustly targets the poorest residents of the city, who are the heaviest users of the system.
Robert Bullard, head of an urban policy research group at Clark Atlanta University, says the fare increase favors the suburban, predominantly white ridership over low-income minorities in the city.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE CONVENTION PLANS;
Los Angeles City Council Approves $4 Million to Bail Out a Host Group

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, June 23

 BODY:
By a one-vote majority, the Los Angeles City Council approved $4 million today to bail out the local host committee for the Democratic National Convention here, assuring enough cash to begin building the stage at the Staples Center next month and avoiding a big political embarrassment for Mayor Richard J. Riordan.
But Mr. Riordan's victory came at a personal price: $1 million, to be exact. 
 That is because the Council required that several million-dollar letters of credit held by the Democratic National Committee from a group of wealthy civic leaders backing the convention must be cashed before any of the new city money is spent.
One of those letters has Mr. Riordan's signature.
In an even more bitter twist, the bailout could not muster a majority from the 15-member Council's 12 Democrats, and Mr. Riordan, a Republican who helped to lure the convention in the first place, had to rely on a liberal Democrat, Jackie Goldberg, a frequent antagonist in the Council, to pass it.
Ms. Goldberg, who represents Hollywood, called the vote the hardest of her career and agreed to support the grant only after the Council accepted her amendments on the letters of credit, as well as a requirement that Pershing Square in the heart of downtown Los Angeles be available for public protests.
Civil liberties groups have criticized a plan to limit protests to a fenced-off area set aside near the Staples Center.
Ms. Goldberg's amendments also required the Police Department to meet with an ad hoc Council committee before and during the convention to avoid any police overreaction to protests.
"Jackie made it really clear she would vote no," said her chief of staff, Sharon Delugach, who expressed surprise that the councilwoman's conditions had been met, especially those involving the police and protesters.
From the beginning, the convention has been dogged by fund-raising difficulties, chiefly because the local organizers agreed to finance the $35 million cost almost entirely from private money, as organizers of the 1984 Olympics here did.
The city originally agreed to provide transportation and security services amounting to about $7 million, but estimates of those costs have risen and earlier this week the Council approved $2 million more.
But it balked at a request for an additional $4 million to jump-start construction work, with members insisting that would violate their original promise to taxpayers.
Today, the measure passed 8 to 5, the bare majority needed in the 15-member body; two members were absent.
Ben Austin, a spokesman for the local host committee, said the group was "thankful that the Council expanded its partnership." Mr. Austin said the investment would help reap $135 million in economic activity for the city.
Despite the troubles, the host group has raised a record amount in private cash and services, $25 million, and hopes a Sunday morning fund-raiser at Mr. Riordan's house, featuring President Clinton, will raise more than $1 million toward about $3 million in cash that is still needed.

HEADLINE: After Defeat, Campaigner for 'Free Burma' Begins Anew

BYLINE: By CAREY GOLDBERG 

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
SO sanguine is Simon Billenness that he seems not the least bit downcast by this week's United States Supreme Court decision overturning the Massachusetts "Burma Law," which he co-wrote.
There are, after all, so many other economic tools to use against companies that support the totalitarian regime of Myanmar, formerly Burma. And as a super-specialist in just this kind of battle, using financial pressure to fight foreign oppression, he knows all of them: divestment campaigns, consumer boycotts, shareholder resolutions, the whole gamut. 
 Mr. Billenness enumerated them as he sat surrounded by two-foot-high stacks of paper ("Here I am working to topple a military dictatorship, and I have trouble finding things on my desk!" he lamented in the cheery clip of his native Britain) and books with titles like "The Anguish of Tibet" and "Corporate Crime and Violence."
The desk belongs to Trillium Asset Management, a Boston concern that, with $675 million in client money, labels itself the nation's largest and oldest independent investment firm dedicated totally to "socially responsible" investment.
Most of Trillium's employees actually work investing money, but Mr. Billenness, 35, a senior research analyst, has the particular luxury of spending virtually all his time on social advocacy, like figuring out how best to support the democracy movement in Myanmar, whose leaders are accused of torture, forced labor and brutal repression.
To wit: With nary a pause after the Supreme Court decision, Mr. Billenness and other members of the Free Burma Coalition, a national umbrella group, plan to begin a push this summer to get cities and states to pass new laws penalizing companies that do business with Myanmar, he said.
The Supreme Court's ruling against the Massachusetts law, which largely barred the state government from doing business with companies that trade with Myanmar, was narrow enough that it left room for states and cities to pass such home-grown foreign policy measures, Mr. Billenness said. Provided, that is, they are not pre-empted by federal law, as the Massachusetts measure was.
So there is room for a continued local-global campaign that is, not coincidentally, highly reminiscent of the movement to fight South African apartheid using economic means like divestment.
Here is the Massachusetts link: In 1993, Mr. Billenness, a freshly minted M.B.A. from Boston College, went to watch a news conference about the end of economic sanctions against South Africa. There he met Byron Rushing, a prominent legislator who had written the state's law on anti-apartheid sanctions. And he suggested that Mr. Rushing do something similar for Myanmar.
Mr. Rushing said he would need more information on the country. Mr. Billenness provided it, including a statement by Nobel Peace Prize laureates calling for sanctions.
Mr. Rushing eventually gave Mr. Billenness a copy of the bill he wrote on South Africa sanctions and asked him to adapt it for Myanmar. So Mr. Billenness went home, he said, "and typed it out word for word, except that whenever I came to 'South Africa,' I put in 'Burma.' Then I gave it back to him on a disk, and that's how I 'co-authored' the law on Burma."
Mr. Rushing introduced the bill in 1994, and it passed in 1996. Citing the Massachusetts law, a number of companies pulled out of Myanmar, among them Apple Computers and Hewlett-Packard, Mr. Billenness said. But by 1997, a backlash began as well. There was, he said, "quite a kerfuffle."
The European Commission formally protested, and in 1998, the National Foreign Trade Council, a Washington-based association, brought suit. The law's opponents said it violated international trade agreements and interfered with the federal government's function of making foreign policy. They won in federal court. And now again in the Supreme Court.
Why was the Myanmar law challenged, while the South Africa laws never were? The economy has become so globalized, Mr. Billenness said, that more than ever, "if you pass a selective purchasing law in any city in the world, it will have import far beyond its borders."
That brought trouble for the Massachusetts law, but "it shows how we as consumers, as investors, can use our freedom in the marketplace to effect political and social change."
Mr. Billenness said he believed "the battle has been more important than the result" in that the Massachusetts law helped bring talk about Myanmar to the forefront. Seventy-eight members of Congress expressed support for the law, as did 22 state attorneys general.
The movement is growing, as reflected in the thousands of names on his e-mail lists, all collected over the last few years.

 M R. BILLENNESS himself came to the "Free Burma" cause in a rather researched, though by no means cold-hearted, way. A native Londoner, he is the second son of parents who met at a Young Liberals conference and who both remain very active in Britain's Liberal Party. He became actively Liberal himself by the age of 14, even resuscitating a local Young Liberals chapter.
When he finished Loughborough University in 1985, he married an American -- he has since divorced -- came to the United States and began working in finance from the ground up, as a bank teller. He quickly overcame his initial confusion between the American dime and the nickel, he said.
He gravitated toward "socially responsible" investing (to this day, he has a Working Assets Visa card -- "plastic with purpose" that contributes a percentage of purchases to causes) and ultimately worked his way up to his job as one of two employees at Trillium who devote all their time to social advocacy. In 1992, when he was still an intern at the firm, he wrote a report on which human rights issues most needed attention from concerned investors, and Myanmar was one of them, along with sweatshops and China. So it began.
And so it continues. Last year, Mr. Billenness noted, Hootie & the Blowfish, a rock band and client of Trillium Asset Management, was playing at a San Diego concert sponsored by Suzuki, which is the target of a consumer boycott for investing in Myanmar. Guess who provided the T-shirts that some of the band members wore reading "Suzuki Out of Burma"?

HEADLINE: Polls Show Virtual Tie in the Crucial Presidential Race in Mexico

BYLINE: By SAM DILLON 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, June 23

 BODY:
Public opinion surveys show the two leading presidential candidates in a virtual tie before the election on July 2, with as many as one-fourth of the voters undecided.
Three polls show the candidate of the governing party, Francisco Labastida Ochoa, leading by a slender margin. A fourth survey showed Vicente Fox Quesada of the center-right National Action Party slightly ahead. 
 The half-dozen polls were issued on Wednesday and Thursday. A law prohibits publishing polling information from midnight tonight until 8 p.m. on Election Day.
The polls show that the race in which Mr. Labastida enjoyed an overwhelming advantage over Mr. Fox has continued to narrow.
And they have intensified the extraordinary uncertainty and tension about the outcome of an election that has become a plebiscite on whether the Institutional Revolutionary Party, known as the PRI, should continue to govern after 71 years in power.
"Either candidate, Labastida or Fox, could win this election," Alejandro Moreno, chief pollster at Reforma, a newspaper here, said in an interview.
In the survey that Reforma published on Thursday, Mr. Labastida was favored by 34 percent, Mr. Fox by 32 and Cuauhtemoc Cardenas, a leftist, by 13. Three percent said they would vote for minor candidates or no candidate, and 19 percent said they were undecided or refused to respond. The margin of sampling error was plus or minus 3 percentage points.
Another poll, commissioned by Reuters and conducted by Zogby International, a research concern in New York, showed Mr. Labastida supported by 31 percent of voters, Mr. Fox by 29 percent and Mr. Cardenas by 10 percent. The margin of sampling error was plus or minus 3 percentage points.
About 3 percent of those surveyed said they supported minor candidates, and 27 percent said they were undecided or declined to respond, the president of the business, John Zogby, said in an interview.
In a third survey, conducted by Grupo de Economistas Asociados, a research concern here, Mr. Fox was supported by 32 percent, Mr. Labastida 31 percent and Mr. Cardenas by 15 percent. Twenty percent were undecided. Two percent supported minor candidates. The margin of sampling error was plus or minus 4 percentage points.
"It's really a tie," said the director of the organization, Mauricio Gonzalez Gomez.
The polls started a debate about how to interpret the high number of uncommitted voters. Some experts said the undecided and nonresponsive voters, whose numbers ranged from 18 to 27 percent, represented the percentage of eligible voters who were highly unlikely to cast ballots.
Other experts said the high percentage reflected the high level of fear in the electorate after an extraordinarily bitter campaign.
Complaints have been heard across Mexico that officials of the government and the PRI have threatened that voters would lose access to welfare and farm programs if Mr. Fox won.
As a result, some experts said, many people who express indecision are reluctant to acknowledge their intentions to vote for the opposition.
Most surveys before the last presidential election, in 1994, predicted that the PRI would earn 2 to 3 percentage points more than the party eventually received.
Several new surveys showed that when voters were asked to leave aside their preferences and to say whom they expected to win, significantly more Mexicans said they believed that Mr. Labastida would win.
In 1994, the PRI won votes from many Mexicans by portraying itself as the party that could offer stability in a dangerous world.
This year, as Mr. Fox has campaigned as the candidate of change, Mr. Labastida has again been playing on voters' fears.
A survey by another group, Consultores y Marketing Politico, suggested that the tactic could be effective. Asked to choose between social peace and having a new party in power, nearly 8 in 10 voters said they preferred stability.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Deep Discounts Fail to Lift Sales of Affordable Vehicles
Automakers say that despite recent deep discounts, auto sales have not picked up in June from the relatively subdued pace of May, providing evidence to the Federal Reserve that recent interest-rate increases may be slowing the American economy.
 Auto executives and dealers say sales of luxury cars and sport utility vehicles remain extremely strong. But the mass market for more affordable cars, minivans, sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks has softened as middle-class families have become leery of borrowing money at ever steeper rates. Page C2. 

AOL and Time Warner Clear a Hurdle
Shareholders of America Online and Time Warner voted to approve the merger of the two companies. But the concerns do not expect to complete the $165 billion deal until late fall because it must still gain the approval of a number of regulatory bodies, including the Federal Trade Commission, the Federal Communications Commission, the European Union and the authorities in many cities where Time Warner owns cable television systems. The F.C.C. is expected to hold a hearing in late July. C4.
 
S.& P. Off Slightly in Mixed Trading
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was down 10.70 points, to 1,441.48, in mixed trading. Blue-chip shares rose and technology stocks came under selling pressure for the second consecutive day as investors locked in profits after a weeks-long run-up. The Dow Jones industrial average finished up 28.63 points, to 10,404.75, while the Nasdaq composite index fell 91.50 points, or 2.3 percent, to 3,845.34. The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond rose to 6.03 percent from 5.96 percent on Thursday. C3.
 
DoCoMo May Establish British Link
Responding to press reports that NTT DoCoMo was on the verge of acquiring a 15 percent stake in Telesystem International Wireless, a Canadian company that is heavily invested in the British market, a senior DoCoMo executive acknowledged that a link with Telesystem was an attractive option. Officially, DoCoMo declined to confirm the reports, but dropped hints that it might soon establish a presence in Britain. C2.
 
ConAgra to Buy International Home
ConAgra said it had agreed to buy International Home Foods for about $1.6 billion in cash and stock in a deal that would put Chef Boyardee pasta, Gulden's mustard and PAM cooking spray into ConAgra's corporate pantry. Shareholders of International Home will receive $22 a share, half in cash and half in ConAgra stock. ConAgra, with brands like Orville Redenbacher popcorn, Swiss Miss hot chocolate and Healthy Choice prepared meals, will also assume $1.3 billion in debt. C3.
 
Aventis in Alliance With a Start-Up
Millennium Pharmaceuticals will receive up to $450 million in financing from Aventis Pharma, the big European drug company, as part of a wide-ranging drug development and technology alliance. C2.
 
China Toughens Talk on W.T.O. Entry
A top Chinese trade negotiator warned that his country would not make any more concessions to open up markets for goods and services in its bid to join the World Trade Organization. The negotiator, Long Yongtu, said some countries had raised "unreasonable requests," apparently referring to an insistence by developing countries that they receive the same trade privileges that China had negotiated with the European Union and the United States. C2.

HEADLINE: The Big City;
Urban Menace Stalks Streets In Diapers

BYLINE: By JOHN TIERNEY 

 BODY:
ANY journalist who covers the Upper West Side quickly becomes combat-hardened, but even the veterans at The West Side Spirit have never seen anything like the current war. It was set off by their front-page headline: "Your Kids Are Driving Me Crazy!"
The battle cry came from Gail Bryce, a nonparent appalled at the children running amok in her Starbucks. The Upper West Side has become "a giant day care center," she complained, while a populace famed for kvetching remained silent. 
 "We let baby carriages and strollers steamroll over us on crowded sidewalks and in stores, as if it's a papal edict that they have the right of way," she wrote in an article last month. "We let brats terrorize us in restaurants. We stand passively on public transportation, looking down at the tops of the heads of kids who are riding for free in the seats that should go to us fare-paying adults."
She announced a new campaign for adult rights, prompting a deluge of letters for and against children -- mostly against. "We've never gotten so much mail on any issue," said Tom Allon, the publisher and editor in chief, who bravely stood by the article despite having three children of his own. "I was the prototype parent she had in mind."
So am I, and I'm tempted to fire back at the child-bashers. Whom do these self-absorbed Manhattanites expect to support them in their old age? They should be thanking us for providing their Social Security. And why are they living on the Upper West Side if they can't stand children? There are plenty of child-unfriendly neighborhoods out there.
But I can't help sympathizing with Ms. Bryce's band of activists. In a place as congested and cramped as Manhattan, other people's children are a special burden. Until my own perfect child arrived, I shared their belief that this island should operate like the one on "Survivor." When parenthood hits, a voice should announce, "It's time for you to go."
IF parents insist on staying, they have to make peace with the childless majority. Here, to start negotiations, are a couple of olive branches:
Demilitarized zones. Any peace process begins by separating the combatants. Already, there are informal child-free refuges: cafes with tables too closely packed for strollers, restaurants with menus too pricey for families.
But some New Yorkers refuse to take a hint. They need to see the equivalent of a no-smoking sign clearly posted at the door: a baby with a red slash across it.
Baby-occupied territories are already easy to recognize by the stroller gridlock at the door. Even the most obtuse babyphobe knows to avoid a restaurant with crayons at the table. But just to be clear, there could be a universal baby-friendly symbol at the door -- a waiter smiling as a child in a high chair pelts him with Cheerios.
The brat tax. Children shorter than 44 inches are allowed to ride free on subways and buses, and they infuriate some adults when they take up a seat. In the old days, as the adult-rights activists point out, there were signs telling parents: "Little enough to ride for free. Little enough to ride your knee."
Parents could assuage some of the activists by giving up the seats, but it may be better to reconsider the whole question. If you think of a screaming child as an environmental disturbance, then giving a child a discount is like offering a subsidy to a polluter.
A child should pay at least full fare, and the fairest policy would be to impose a surcharge, as The Economist magazine once explained in analyzing the "negative externalities" created by children in another cramped, congested environment.
The Economist proposed that airlines segregate families at the back of the plane and charge children more than adults. The surcharge could be used to subsidize a buffer zone: a row of seats in front of the children for adults willing to endure noise in return for a special discount.
It would be complicated to set up subsidized buffer zones and special children's fares in the subway, but a brave restaurateur could certainly try the experiment. Parents wouldn't like paying extra for kiddie meals, of course, but in one way they too would benefit -- or at least the ones who now sit mortified when their kids turn into monsters.
With a brat tax, they could hold their heads high as their little darlings rampaged. If any nearby diners glared, if any adult-rights activists tried to complain, the parent could smile and calmly reply, "I paid for that tantrum."

HEADLINE: Editorial Observer;
In Korea, an Embrace That Shook the World

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN 

 BODY:
Tomorrow marks the 50th anniversary of the start of the Korean War. As all schoolchildren in North Korea know, the war began when South Korea invaded its peaceful neighbor to the north. Since then the government in Seoul has remained enslaved to a clique of generals, spies and capitalists who are puppets of the United States.
Old attitudes die hard, as is obvious from the twisted propaganda along these lines that keeps flowing from Pyongyang even after the extraordinary meeting between leaders of the North and South last week. A visitor who met with President Kim Dae Jung in Seoul after the meeting says that despite all the euphoria in his country, the South Korean president cautions that it will take decades, perhaps generations, to achieve reunification. 
 Still, anyone following recent events on the Korean Peninsula cannot help but find them amazing.
On one side is President Kim of South Korea, a former dissident once rescued from a ship -- where he was about to be tossed overboard wrapped in heavy chains by government goons -- only after intervention by the United States.
On the other is Kim Jong Il of the North, often described as a murderous megalomaniac surrounded by concubines. Among other things, in the course of his despotic career he is said to have ordered the blowing up of a civilian airliner, a bombing attack on the South Korean Cabinet and the kidnapping of a movie star and director who were forced to help build up the North Korean film industry. No wonder that The Economist features the oddly coiffed and reclusive Mr. Kim on its cover with the caption "Greetings, Earthlings."
The handful of Western visitors who have been in North Korea all liken it to another planet. When I was in Pyongyang in 1991, revolutionary slogans were everywhere, and loudspeakers at construction sites exhorted workers with picks and shovels to toil for the glory of the state. The 105-story hotel then under construction, proudly described as the tallest hotel in the world, was already sagging visibly. It still has not opened. Everyone I met recited slogans about North Korea as paradise on earth. Some admitted to meat shortages, but not to the truth of reports of starvation in the countryside.
Even if reconciliation remains a distant dream, the significance of the two Mr. Kims meeting is tremendous. It shakes the equation in East Asia and could even alter the political scene in the United States. For one thing, the meeting puts South Korea in an unaccustomed place -- the driver's seat of the policies being worked out to deal with the danger posed by the North.
For years the United States has taken the lead in negotiating with North Korea, offering a combination of threats and incentives to get it to stop building nuclear weapons. Now after negotiating a deal on nuclear and missile restraint with Pyongyang, the Clinton administration must defend its approach against charges of naivete by hawkish Republicans, including advisers to Gov. George W. Bush.
The meeting of the two Korean leaders is unlikely to soften their criticism. Indeed, some Republicans talk of "taking out" the North Korean nuclear installations. But they overlook the reality that, aside from the difficulty of destroying facilities hundreds of feet below ground, any such attempt would lead to the destruction of Seoul with a barrage of mortar, artillery and poison gas counterattacks.
In years past, the United States has served as a brake on confrontation-minded generals in Seoul. Today, with hawkish Americans calling for a tough stance toward North Korea and plans for an antimissile defense system, South Korea may be the one arguing for military restraint and political engagement.
In regional terms, the irony is that for all the yearning for reunification of the Korean Peninsula, almost no one close to the situation wants it to happen anytime soon. The South Koreans fear that a rapid absorption of the North will wreck their economy in the way Germany was weakened when it was reunified a decade ago. Russia, China and Japan -- which for centuries jockeyed for supremacy on the peninsula -- are hardly enthusiastic today about the possibility of a newly powerful rival in the neighborhood. Many American experts have no such concerns but nonetheless fear the day -- regarded by some experts as inevitable -- that Koreans ask for the United States to withdraw its troops.
Why has North Korea decided to reach out to the people it still regards as implacable foes? The answers lie in the overwhelming economic incentives and in apparent pressure from China to defuse the situation in hopes of speeding the withdrawal of the American presence. President Kim of South Korea has also done a masterly job of assuring the North that he really does not want to absorb it or destroy its system.
Finally, it appears that the unpredictable Mr. Kim of the North may be looking for legitimacy. Few doubt that North Korea remains capable of a clandestine nuclear program, missile exports or other dangerous behavior. Yet the North may be willing to keep its aggressive impulses in check in return for help from its wary adversaries. As for South Korea, for now it has taken the lead, and the rest of the world will have to respond. Who knows? The latest in North Korean movies may soon be on their way to the outside world.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: POLITICAL MEMO;
Gore Raises Millions for 2000 While an Inquiry Takes Him Back to 1996

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE with JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 23

 BODY:
Within hours of ordering his lawyers to release the transcript of his interview into his 1996 fund-raising activities, Vice President Al Gore was back to business as usual today -- trolling for money.
In an affluent Silicon Valley neighborhood, Mr. Gore raised $500,000 over lunch. In Denver on Thursday, Mr. Gore headlined two events that raised a total of $1.1 million. Today, after the Silicon Valley lunch, he attended a dinner on the San Francisco waterfront where the singers David Crosby and Steven Stills serenaded several hundred people. 
 Then came a reception at a private home. The day's total take: $2 million. On Saturday, he was scheduled to attend a fund-raiser in Miami that was expected to bring his three-day total to more than $3.5 million.
The fund-raising events were broken up by the news on Thursday that, based on an April 18 deposition of Mr. Gore, a Justice Department official was asking Attorney General Janet Reno for an investigation into the vice president's money-raising activities in 1996. On Thursday night, Gore advisers read the transcripts of the deposition and on Friday, released copies to news organizations.
Concerns about Mr. Gore's overzealous money-raising, coming in the midst of a fund-raising swing, put an especially fine point on what Mr. Gore likes to call the "irony" of his situation.
Here is how Mr. Gore, who has tried to deflect criticism of his links to the fund-raising problems by calling himself "an imperfect messenger" for overhauling the campaign finance system, dealt with this uncomfortable topic at lunch today:
In a sun-splashed dining room, where paintings by Miro and Chagall decorated the stucco walls, he talked confidently about the nation's powerhouse economy, borrowing a line from Ronald Reagan: Did Americans feel they were better off today than they were eight years ago?
There was a soft murmur of assent. And then, perhaps in a nod to the issue that had dominated today's news reports, Mr. Gore briefly made a pitch for tossing out the entire campaign finance system that has caused him so much grief.
"It's an irony to talk about this issue at a fund-raising event, I realize," Mr. Gore told the dozen or so people who had paid $25,000 each to lunch on grilled salmon and vegetables. "But the first bill I will present to Congress will be the McCain-Feingold campaign finance bill."
Mr. Gore has struggled to focus attention on the upside of the Clinton administration: the economic expansion and his ideas for using the nation's growing budget surplus to improve education, health care and the environment. This forms the basis of his "prosperity and progress tour" and the underpinning of his candidacy.
But he is being pulled away from sketching out a rosy future to explaining the past. And in doing so, he is being pulled inexorably into the downside of the administration -- not just the questionable fund-raising of 1996 but the specter of the next president spending his time being questioned under oath about whether he has told the truth.
In the transcript released today, Mr. Gore gives a startling similar answer to the now-infamous answer given by President Clinton as he quibbled over the meaning of the word "is." When Mr. Gore was asked what role the coffees would play in raising money, he said: "Let me define the term 'raising,' " adding, "If you mean by it, would they be events at which money was raised, the answer is no."
For the last year, Mr. Gore has been working furiously to separate himself from an administration that has been accused repeatedly of not telling the truth even as his opponent, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, has offered himself as an alternative. And Mr. Bush clearly hoped that the call for an investigation into Mr. Gore's truthfulness would signal to voters that a Gore administration would not be that much different from Bill Clinton's. "If America is tired of scandals and investigations, let's elect somebody different, other than the people of the Clinton/Gore administration," Mr. Bush said in Alabama today.
At the time, the Gore campaign was employing a durable Clinton tactic made familiar during the Monica S. Lewinsky investigation -- pre-emptively releasing hundreds of pages of documents in an effort to defuse the controversy and dispatch it quickly.
Mr. Gore and his advisers moved in an uncharacteristically aggressive fashion to dispel any suggestion of wrongdoing and, employing another Clinton tactic, suggested that the re-emergence of the issue was, if not a vast right-wing conspiracy, at least an orchestrated smear by the Bush campaign.
The vice president hinted broadly that Thursday's disclosure of the request for an investigation was politically motivated.
"I think the timing of this whole thing speaks for itself," Mr. Gore told reporters.
"I have told the truth," he added. "I have cooperated fully. And I don't want people to have the impression that I am trying to hide something. I am not. I want you to see it all."
Mark Fabiani, a spokesman for Mr. Gore and a veteran of the Clinton White House damage-control operation, said the release of documents was the best way for the Gore campaign to fight what he described as "Republican dirty tricks."
Mr. Fabiani said the Republicans, through Senator Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania, had leaked the information because "Bush was having a bad day."
Mr. Fabiani noted that the governor had been presiding over an execution and pointed to reports that Mr. Bush's financial ties to the oil industry would render him useless in the battle against high gasoline prices.
"What the Republicans tried to do yesterday was to kick up dust and say, 'No one really knows what the issue is, but it's an issue, it's significant and it comes out of this April 18 deposition,' " Mr. Fabiani said.
Rachel Gorlin, a Democratic consultant, said the Gore campaign was probably smart to release the transcripts.
"The Clinton lesson is to show that it's worth it to engage in the discussion, partly because the public doesn't care that much and partly because this gives Gore standing" to make his case and challenge the Republicans, Ms. Gorlin said. "The thinking is, let's take the hit now and move on, that they won't find anything they can use in the fall and by then it will be old news anyway."
She also said the possible investigation illustrated the age-old problem for vice presidents seeking to become president: "Is this election about what's gone on during the previous administration or is it about what he can do in the future?"
Allies of Mr. Gore saw another possible advantage in releasing the transcripts. Although Mr. Gore uses the word "hell," apparently reinforcing reports that he was angry and confrontational during the deposition, Mr. Fabiani suggested that this showed passion, a quality that he has been accused of lacking.
Spokesmen for the Bush campaign and for Mr. Specter said there was no collusion between them.

HEADLINE: Pentagon Sees China's Forces as No Foreseeable Threat to U.S.

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 23

 BODY:
China is modernizing its armed forces to counter military threats from technologically superior enemies, but "significant shortcomings" in its weapons and training will leave it unable to challenge the United States for "an indefinite period of time," according to a Pentagon study released today.
The Pentagon's report said China's military modernization efforts are also increasing its ability to threaten Taiwan, especially with long-range missiles. But the study concluded that the People's Liberation Army, hobbled by limitations in fighter aircraft and amphibious ships, would not fare well if ordered to invade Taiwan in the near future. 
 "In the short term (2000-2005), the P.L.A. will have only a limited capability to conduct integrated operations against Taiwan," the unclassified version of a longer classified study said.
The study, one of a series mandated by Congress, will almost certainly fuel the debate over the future of China's military and focus new attention on the diplomatically perilous issue of arms sales to Taiwan.
Because the study analyzed both strengths and weaknesses in the Chinese military, its findings amounted to a Rorschach test, providing critics and supporters of the Clinton administration's policies toward China evidence to support their views.
"You can get whatever you want out of this report," one Pentagon official said today.
Representative Christopher Cox, a California Republican and one of Capitol Hill's most ardent hawks on China, said the study highlighted President Clinton's failed efforts to engage China and the need "to view the People's Republic of China as a strategic competitor, rather than a strategic ally."
At the same time, the analysis concluded that China's leadership, headed by President Jiang Zemin, remained "largely preoccupied by domestic concerns," more than military and national security issues.
It said that in the aftermath of NATO's air war against Yugoslavia and the bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade, some Chinese officials "seriously considered" giving defense a higher priority, but that the leadership "reaffirmed its priority emphasis" on economic growth during its annual retreat last August.
Even so, a potential conflict with Taiwan involving the United States has become "the dominant scenario" guiding the Chinese military's planning and weapons development, it said. The military, while lagging technologically, has been pouring resources into devising strategies and weapons to exploit American weaknesses, it found.
The Chinese have also devoted enormous efforts to developing means of "electromagnetic warfare" and attacks on computer and communications networks. And they have an "aggressive program" to buy weapons from Russia, including missiles, attack submarines and, most recently, two destroyers.
The report, which relied on intelligence findings as well as writings of China's military strategists, said the Chinese had carefully studied the 1991 Persian Gulf war and NATO's air war against Yugoslavia, where American-led forces used overwhelming force and technological superiority to crush the enemy. The analysis found that much of China's research and training now centers on countering just such an attack, by developing or buying missiles and other weapons that could threaten advanced aircraft.
Still, while China is restructuring its armed forces, its air force and navy remain too antiquated and ill-equipped to launch a serious invasion of Taiwan or other countries in the region. The navy's amphibious transport ships could carry only one infantry division across the Taiwan Strait, leaving other troops dependent on trawlers and fishing boats.
The report's findings are likely to intensify pressure on the United States to sell more and more advanced weapons to Taiwan to counter the Chinese buildup. China has strongly opposed sales to Taiwan, which it considers a renegade province. In April, the administration approved a sale of upgraded missiles and a long-range radar system, but refused Taiwan's request for four of the most advanced American destroyers.
Despite tensions, the report plays down the likelihood of open conflict between China and Taiwan, arguing that Beijing would avoid anything that risked its economic growth and access to foreign markets.
"In initiating a military conflict with Taiwan, Beijing would run the risk of jeopardizing both its continued economic development and its political standing," the report concluded. "China's resolve to employ military force, however, should not be discounted."

HEADLINE: WORLD BRIEFING

BYLINE: Compiled by Terence Neilan

 BODY:

THE AMERICAS
 
COLOMBIA: KIDNAP VICTIMS FREED
The victims of a pair of politically emblematic kidnappings that deeply offended the Colombian public were both released. A right-wing paramilitary group freed Guillermo Valencia, left, a member of Congress who is the brother of one of the government's chief negotiators in peace talks with leftist guerrillas. He was seized Monday in an effort to torpedo the talks, while a 5-year-old girl whose parents said she was being held by the country's main left-wing guerrilla group was released after 70 days in captivity, but only after a ransom was paid. Larry Rohter (NYT) 

VENEZUELA: VOTE SET
The presidential election scheduled for May 28 but postponed when the National Electoral Council acknowledged that its vote-counting system was hopelessly flawed has been rescheduled for July 30. Governors, members of Congress and mayors are to be elected the same day, but voting for regional and local councils has been pushed back to Oct. 1.
 Larry Rohter (NYT)
 
ARGENTINA: PRESIDENT OVERRULED
A labor court ruled to overturn a recent act of President Fernando de la Rua to cut public service salaries by 12 to 15 percent as an austerity move to reduce the deficit and cut interest rates. The ruling came after recent labor strikes but is expected to be overturned by higher courts.
 Clifford Krauss (NYT)
 
EUROPE
 
IRELAND: MAD COW FRAUD
An Irish farmer was sentenced to five years in prison after pleading guilty to importing a cow with mad cow disease into his herd in 1996. James Sutton, 49, faced debts of $833,000 and stood to gain $89,000 from a government compensation program when his herd was destroyed to prevent the spread of the disease. Later investigations revealed that a smuggling operation brought in infected cattle from Northern Ireland. Brian Lavery (NYT)
 
KOSOVO: A U.N. PULLOUT
The United Nations refugee agency said it was suspending operations in the Serbian area of the divided town of Mitrovica after rioting injured aid workers. A spokeswoman, Paula Ghedini, said 5 United Nations vehicles had been destroyed in the rioting, and more than 20 damaged, while one aid worker was beaten and the homes of six aid workers attacked.
 (Agence France-Presse)
 
KOSOVO: ALBANIAN TOLL
An estimated 12,000 Kosovar Albanians died in the conflict between February 1998 and June 1999, and most of the victims were civilians, American researchers say. The death rate was two to three times higher than normal and reached its peak in the months of the NATO airstrikes and the increased Serbian ethnic cleansing, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta. It said its figures, published in The Lancet in London, are consistent with other estimates. (Reuters)
 
GERMANY: KOHL ATTACKED
The governing Social Democrats urged former Chancellor Helmut Kohl to resign from Parliament a day after he made comments comparing their recent treatment of him over illegal campaign funds with Nazi persecution of the Jews. A leading Social Democrat, Wilhelm Schmidt, said Mr. Kohl had become an "unacceptable liability for the entire German people." Mr. Kohl rejected the demand, saying he "requires no history lessons" from his political foes. Alan Maimon (NYT)
 
AFRICA
 
NIGERIA: UNION UNREST
Public-sector pay talks have broken down, threatening a new round of unrest two weeks after a general strike over fuel prices, unions said. The Nigeria Labor Congress ordered workers to "cripple any government that refuses to comply" with monthly minimum demands of $75 a month in oil-producing states and $65 in states that do not produce oil.
 (Agence France-Presse)
 
ASIA
 
INDONESIA: TRAVEL BAN
President Abdurrahman Wahid banned travel to the Spice Islands, where Muslim fighters have been arriving to stoke communal violence that has taken thousands of lives. Eighteen more people were reported killed.
 Seth Mydans (NYT)
 
AFGHANISTAN: AID PLEA
The United Nations refugee agency called for more aid for Afghanistan, warning that drought conditions may force Afghans to flee to Pakistan and Iran. Afghanistan has been hit by its worst drought in 30 years, raising the specter of mass starvation, the agency said. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)
 
SRI LANKA: TAMIL PLAN
President Chandrika Kumaratunga and the main opposition United National Party have agreed to form an interim council to administer Sri Lanka's northeast in an attempt to end Tamil separatist violence. Tamil Tiger rebels will not be a part of the council unless they renounce violence, officials said.
 P. J. Anthony (NYT)
 
SINGAPORE: CELL PHONE CURBS
Singapore, known for its strict anti-littering, anti-chewing-gum laws, now plans to jail motorists who hold mobile phones to their ears while driving. They face a six-month jail term for a first offense or a $588 fine, or both, as well as a driving ban, a police spokesman said. A second offense would double the fine and jail term. (Reuters)
 
MIDDLE EAST
 
IRAN: KHATAMI PLEA
President Mohammad Khatami, on the second day of a five-day visit to China, called for an "Asian convergence" aimed at standing up to Western dominance and globalization. Mr. Khatami called China and Iran two of the world's greatest civilizations, saying they needed to work together to forge the world of tomorrow, "hampering the domination of the world's unipolar system."
 (Agence France-Presse)
 
IRAN: SPY VERDICT SEEN
The judge in the trial of 13 Iranian Jews accused of spying for Israel will issue a verdict in the case on July 1, a court official said. Eight of the 13 Jewish defendants have pleaded guilty, four have pleaded innocent and one has said he passed information to Israel but did not think his action constituted espionage. Israel has said none of the 13 were spies.
 (AP)
 
UNITED NATIONS
 
RUSSIAN WALKOUT
Russia's ambassador, Sergey Lavrov, walked out of the Security Council after members voted not to allow Yugoslavia's delegate to speak in a session on the European Union's peace efforts in the Balkans. Richard C. Holbrooke, the American delegate, said the vote was based on President Slobodan Milosevic's refusal to change Yugoslavia's nomenclature and flag, saying it was unacceptable that the "flag of Tito" still flies on First Avenue.
 Barbara Crossette (NYT)

HEADLINE: National News Briefs;
Man Convicted of Setting Pipe Bombs at University

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: PENSACOLA, Fla., June 23

 BODY:
A federal jury today convicted a white man of setting off two pipe bombs that terrorized the predominantly black Florida A&M University.
The defendant, Lawrence M. Lombardi, 42, was convicted of possessing and using bombs, causing destruction with bombs and using bombs to cause harm and intimidation because of race or color. 
 Mr. Lombardi, an unemployed embalmer who once stocked vending machines at the university, faces up to life in prison when he is sentenced on Sept. 15.
The bombings on Aug. 31 and Sept. 22 caused only minor damage to restrooms in administration and classroom buildings, and no one was hurt.

SECTION: Section 15; Page 13; Column 1; Women's Health 

LENGTH: 1378 words

HEADLINE: NEW MOTHERHOOD;
A Racial Gap in Infant Deaths, and a Search for Reasons

BYLINE: By LESLIE BERGER; Leslie Berger contributes articles about health to Science Times.

 BODY:
ETHELYN BOWERS had a master's degree, an executive-level job and a husband who was a doctor with access to some of the best medical care available. But her accomplishments and connections seemed to make little difference when she endured the premature births and subsequent deaths of three babies, two of whom were in a set of triplets.
A competitive businesswoman who is immersed in her career and the hectic schedules of her surviving children, now 9 and 11, Ms. Bowers is candid about her losses but does not dwell on their possible causes. "I just chalked it up to bad luck, mainly," said Ms. Bowers, a sales director for Lucent Technologies who lives with her family in Livingston, N.J. 
 But her husband is haunted by the notion that somehow, in a way experts have yet to fully grasp, the fact that he and his wife are African-American was a factor in their children's deaths.
"At the time of the loss, you really don't dissect out the reasons; all you really think about is the tremendous sorrow," said her husband, Dr. Charles H. Bowers, chief of obstetrics and gynecology at Kings County Hospital Center in Brooklyn. "In retrospect, I think you need to look at psychosocial causes -- the euphemism I use for racism. If in fact my counterpart, a white physician making six figures, had a wife the same age and her likelihood of losing their child was less than half of my wife's chances of losing my child, why should that be?"
It is a mystery that consumes not only Dr. Bowers but a growing field of researchers struggling to explain a persistent racial gap in American infant mortality rates. For years, the number of babies who die before their first birthday has been a source of shame for public health advocates; in international comparisons of infant mortality, the World Health Organization has ranked the United States 25th, below Japan, Israel and Western Europe. But even as infant mortality rates improve -- to a record low national average of 7.2 deaths per 1,000 live births -- the disparity between blacks and whites has grown, from 2 to nearly 2.4 times the number of infant deaths.
Especially troubling is evidence that this is not simply a function of poverty. While college-educated black women do better than impoverished, they are still twice as likely to bury their babies as their white counterparts. And immigrants have better pregnancy outcomes than assimilated minorities. What happens to their health once they settle here, and And why haven't education, better jobs and prenatal care made a bigger difference in closing the infant mortality gap?
"There's no single answer," said Dr. Solomon Iyasu, an epidemiologist at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta. "Infant mortality is such a complex issue because it's driven both by medical issues as well as by social issues."
Because premature deliveries and low birth weights account for two-thirds of infant deaths, much recent research has focused on the causes of early labor. Medical complications from diabetes and high blood pressure, more prevalent illnesses in African-Americans, can be blamed for some of the cases but do not account for the huge disparity. So researchers have begun exploring more subtle factors, like crime, pollution and family support. Another hypothesis is that chronic stress caused by racial discrimination can elevate hormones that set off premature labor.
"We're starting to think it's something about lifelong minority status," said Dr. James W. Collins Jr., a neonatologist in Chicago who teaches pediatrics at Northwestern University Medical School.
Dr. Collins has compared the newborns of black women born in the United States to those of mothers who came directly from Africa, and found that the immigrants' babies were bigger, with birth weights more comparable to whites than to African-Americans. Another study involving interracial couples indicated that the mother's race was crucial: babies born to black mothers and white fathers had higher rates of low birth weight.
The intergenerational effects of poverty and discrimination are also being explored amid concerns that a woman's health and personal experiences -- even before she becomes pregnant -- can affect her children's health.
"It's not clear that if you have a woman who's first-generation college-educated that she's still not carrying the risks of generations of poverty," said Dr. Marie McCormick, a pediatrician and professor of child and maternal health at the Harvard School of Public Health. "There is also increasing evidence that having been born with a low birth weight yourself, you're more likely to have a low-birth-weight child."
Stress-fueled hormones can also lower resistance to infection, Dr. Collins said, and black women have higher rates of vaginal infection, which can spread to the uterus and induce early labor. In locating the source of those infections, which are not sexually transmitted, some researchers have begun looking at douching, a more common practice among black women than white, according to Dr. Dawn Misra, an epidemiologist at Johns Hopkins University.
After premature births, the second leading cause of infant deaths is SIDS, or sudden infant death syndrome. SIDS rates have dropped about 40 percent since 1992, when the American Academy of Pediatrics began a campaign to put babies on their backs or sides to sleep instead of on their stomachs. But African-American infants continue to die of SIDS at twice the rate of other babies, leading researchers to wonder whether the message is reaching black parents.
As the head obstetrician for Bronx clinics run by Montefiore Medical Center, Dr. Nereida Correa gives all her patients a booklet on SIDS and arranges for a pediatrician to attend at least one prenatal session to review infant safety and care. Because most of her patients are poor black and Hispanic women whose Medicaid coverage ends six weeks after giving birth, Dr. Correa tries to pack in as much advice as she can.
On a recent morning at the Williamsbridge clinic, Dr. Correa's patients included Monica Lightbourne, who had been fired from her job as a Kmart sales manager and was fighting the store and the state unemployment board as she entered her 36th week of pregnancy. Another patient, Beverly Roman, who was not pregnant, recalled the death of her first child, a month-old daughter, in Jamaica nearly 20 years ago, after a malnourished teenage pregnancy.
Dr. Correa, who grew up poor in Manhattan, listens patiently to all their concerns and still manages to see three to four women an hour on a slow day. Despite their risks, her patients generally deliver healthy babies, and Dr. Correa remains a believer in the power of prenatal care. The problem, she said, is her patients' lack of health insurance when they are not pregnant.
Dr. McCormick also considers insurance an important piece of the infant mortality puzzle. "Over all, I don't think we take care of our mothers and children very well," she said. "We have a patchwork system of health care. Other countries have financial support for child care and young families and longer maternity leaves and some sort of national health insurance coverage, and I think over time all this adds up." Still, insurance and quality care were not issues for the Bowers.
Dr. Bowers was on staff at Mount Sinai when his wife's preterm deliveries occurred; her own doctor was the chairman of obstetrics. Their first son, Russell, was stillborn at 23 weeks in 1986. Two years later, Ms. Bowers was pregnant with triplets when a checkup revealed that a fetus had died in utero at 28 weeks. She eventually delivered two girls, each weighing about a pound and a half. One, Erin, died a month later after developing a bowel infection. The second daughter, Charlynn, survived. In 1991, Ms. Bowers delivered a full-term boy, Carlton, who weighed 8 pounds, 6 ounces.
Today, Dr. Bowers is part of a committee that investigates local fetal and infant deaths and was set up by the Northern New Jersey Maternal Child Health Consortium. He also raises money for research.
"The hardest thing in my life has been losing my babies," he said. "I've had a very good life. I've got three great kids, but I should have had six."

SECTION: Section 7; Page 20; Column 2; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1499 words

HEADLINE: Boys to Men

BYLINE: By Robert Coles; Robert Coles is a child psychiatrist who teaches at Harvard University.

 BODY:

 The War Against Boys
 How Misguided Feminism Is Harming
 Our Young Men.
 By Christina Hoff Sommers.
 251 pp. New York:
 Simon & Schuster. $25.
 
 Real Boys' Voices
 By William S. Pollack with Todd Shuster.
 392 pp. New York:
 Random House. $25.95. 
 We are asked now by two writers, one a philosopher, the other a psychologist, to consider the contemporary fate of America's boys -- how they have been faring in recent years. The philosopher, Christina Hoff Sommers, tells us right off, through the wording of her title, that we ought be concerned, even alarmed: there is a "War Against Boys"; then in a subtitle we learn that "Misguided Feminism Is Harming Our Young Men." The psychologist, William S. Pollack, offers, with Todd Shuster, "Real Boys' Voices" and immediately summons "the Boy Code," defined as "old rules that favor male stoicism and make boys feel ashamed about expressing weakness or vulnerability." Indeed, before any of the boys' voices are given ample presentation, the writing listener makes this insistent and conclusive summary: "Although our boys urgently want to talk about who they really are, they fear that they will be teased, bullied, humiliated, beaten up and even murdered if they give voice to their truest feelings." This in a democracy -- but the author is not a sociologist or a political scientist, so he quietly calls upon his own profession: "Thus, our nation is home to millions of boys who feel they are navigating life alone -- who on an emotional level are alone -- and who are cast out to sea in separate lifeboats, and feel they are drowning in isolation, depression, loneliness and despair."
What is one to make of such portentous propositions, if not outright prognostications? Sommers once taught at Clark University, but these days she is the W. H. Brady fellow at the American Enterprise Institute in Washington. She is no stranger to polemics, and is not reluctant to declare herself an adversary. Her previous book was titled "Who Stole Feminism? How Women Have Betrayed Women." Pollack works at McLean Hospital outside Boston and teaches at Harvard Medical School, and this new book of his is an obvious continuation of a longstanding interest and commitment, first declared two years ago with the publication of "Real Boys." That book's subtitle also pointed to worrying news: "Rescuing Our Sons From the Myths of Boyhood."
Pollack is still comfortable with the suggestion that there is enough trouble for American boys to justify such an attempt; he is quick in both books to spell out the social and emotional hazards our young men must endure. And in both books, he spots evidence of youthful trembling, of persistent worries that life will turn bad: "Many boys are still telling us that when they walk the streets of their neighborhoods or the hallways of their schools, they have to watch everything they do to make sure they will not be taunted and attacked." But he can go further, refer to "constant fear and anxiety," turn all too rhetorical, present himself to the reader as a psychiatric claimant for an entire nation's boys: "They need to form meaningful friendships and relationships in which they can be openly caring, loving and affectionate without fear of being seen as 'weak' or 'feminine.' "Some pages earlier, we are warned that "a majority of America's boys experiment with drugs and alcohol, many slipping precipitously toward addiction," though nowhere is evidence offered for such a sweeping assertion. Then comes this psychological escalation -- again unsupported: "Still others fill the social and emotional void with their fascination with television (more than 80 percent of boys tune in every day), the Internet, video games and the whole gamut of electronic media. There's a broad dilemma of disconnection that is infecting our culture."
The boys Pollack calls as personal witnesses can be persuasively introspective and socially discerning. They speak compellingly, sometimes with winning earnestness and candor. Antonio, 17 and from the Northeast, confides that "my pen and paper are my shelter." Gordon, 18 and from the South, quotes pointedly from Sherwood Anderson's "Winesburg, Ohio," and with a wry shrewdness from J. D. Salinger's "Catcher in the Rye" -- Holden Caulfield lives in this young man's mind, as he has for so many of us, still, long after we met him. "God is the person who is there when nobody else is," Cedric, 14, a city boy from the Northeast, announces, and his religious musings are shared by many of the boys whose voices are put forth in this book. These self-portraits are conveyed with disarming innocence one moment, with knowing bluntness the next, and altogether, from boy after boy, with a great deal of savvy that in its sum might give pause to those who worry about this generation's capacity to take accurate measure of what is happening (socially, economically, culturally) and why.
No question, such forthright testimonies are not to be met in Christina Sommers's pages. She speaks of our children, yet hasn't sought them out; instead she attends those who have, in fact, worked with boys and girls -- and in so doing is quick to look askance at Carol Gilligan's ideas about girls, Pollack's about boys. Much of "The War Against Boys" comes across as Sommers's strongly felt war against those two prominent psychologists, who have spent years trying to learn how young men and women grow to adulthood in the United States. Pollack, we are informed, "is attributing pathology to normal boys, and his conclusions are expansive and alarming." The same charge is directed at Gilligan, at her well-known book "In a Different Voice," and at her more recent effort to understand how boys as well as girls come to sometimes difficult terms with our country's social conventions and values. At moments, a lengthy, disapproving attention to Gilligan becomes argumentatively strained, raised to a high, hectoring pitch: "I find Gilligan's sentimental, celebratory, valorizing description of adolescent girls implausible and inaccurate. Her study of 'unfairness and not listening' -- despite its charts, graphs and tables -- is a caricature of research. Most of the girls' comments are entirely ordinary. Gilligan inflates their significance by reading profound meanings into them." As for Gilligan's recent work, she "appears to be making the same mistake with boys that she made with girls" -- that is, "she observes a few children and interprets their problems as indicative of a deep and general malaise caused by the way our society imposes sex-role stereotypes on them."
Sommers wants to examine Gilligan's working research files, makes bold to ask whether "the data actually exist." She tells us, intending a put-down, that Gilligan's "methods have remained anecdotal and impressionistic -- with increasingly heavy doses of psychoanalytical theorizing." Such a description, of course (if meant to be friendly and appreciative), might aptly be applied to the work of Freud himself, and to that of Erik H. Erikson, Gilligan's deservedly esteemed teacher -- whereas Sommers shows little interest in exploring with favor the manner in which an attentive psychologist or psychiatrist can learn from people, then describe them in a way (clinical storytelling) that brings to life their experiences and concerns, connects them to the imaginations of countless readers.
As I read through this book's dense excursions into a "war" that seems directed at feminist writers, who have had their own (quite understandable) reasons to worry about the way girls, and boys too, have come to regard their future prospects (and contemporary situations), I kept thinking of others who have been "anecdotal" and "impressionistic" in their attempts to know boys and girls adequately and fully -- writers with no claim to science, only the novelist's intuitions and descriptive, evocative capabilities. I thought of Elizabeth Bowen's girl Portia, in "The Death of the Heart," and Toni Morrison's girl Pecola, in "The Bluest Eye"; Tobias Wolff's chronicle of boyhood in "This Boy's Life"; Richard Ford's similar probing of a boy's fate under a particular set of American circumstances, in "Independence Day," and yes, the sonorous, echoing prefiguration of that book's title (and story) in the song of that name offered by our troubadour, Bruce Springsteen -- all of them quite able to give us searching glimpses of our sons and daughters, who Sommers worries are being shortchanged by some of our social scientists, and by the journalists she seems to regard as gullible or irresponsible. (She refers to "journalists who prefer disseminating sensational claims to looking for dissenting voices," and speaks of "uncritical journalism.") Let us hope and pray that more citizens of our country, and with them the author of "The War Against Boys," will seek the truths about those boys (and girls) that our novelists and poets and singers render for our consideration.
