HEADLINE: It's Been Hell on Earth

BYLINE: By Dick Teresi; Dick Teresi is writing a book about the non-European roots of Western science.

 BODY:

 SOMETHING NEW
 UNDER THE SUN
 An Environmental History
 of the Twentieth-Century World.
 By J. R. McNeill.
 Illustrated. 421 pp. New York:
 W. W. Norton & Company. $29.95. 
 On an April day in 1970 I was riding an elevator to my job at Fawcett Publications (our motto: "Something for every page!") when the executive vice president, a man not usually taken to speaking to science editors, cornered me and poked an executive finger into my sternum. "Y'ever heard of this ecology thing?" he demanded. He pronounced it with a long, hard "E." The previous day, after drinks at the Park Lane, he had wandered into Central Park, no doubt in search of bad novels to sign up, where he had run smack into the first Earth Day celebration. He had learned a new word. "Keep your eye on this EEE-cology thing," he barked at me. "It's going to be big!"
Not big enough, apparently, is the message of J. R. McNeill's "Something New Under the Sun: An Environmental History of the Twentieth-Century World." McNeill, a professor of history at Georgetown University, tells us how humans have altered the earth from the 1890's to the 1990's. We've done a lot. O.K., asteroid crashes and volcanic explosions, McNeill concedes, can do more in one fell swoop than we can. The five previous great extinctions, like the one that erased 90 percent of marine species, make our clubbing of harp seals and building of strip malls seem pathetic by comparison. When the biography of the earth is written, our effect on the planet will be a footnote at best -- until 1890. In the past century, McNeill says, that started to change. We are beginning, as high school valedictorians always promise, to make a difference.
The author has compiled a volcanic eruption of statistics to prove this. Usually such numbers, in the hands of environmentalists, are nothing more than "cocktail statistics," meaningless tidbits to share with Tipper and Al or Annette and Warren over tofu canapes and mineral water. My favorite: we lose a football field's worth of rain forest each second. About which I always wonder, American rules or Canadian? Or, 75 percent of the water we use in our homes is used in the bathroom, to which P. J. O'Rourke says: "Thank goodness. Think of the mess it would make in the den."
McNeill spares us such trivia, serving up his numbers rare, such as 13x, 16x, 40x (the increases, respectively, in the world's urban population, energy use and industrial output during the past century). He doesn't examine man's assault on the earth as an environmentalist, but as a historian: "The human race, without intending anything of the sort, has undertaken a gigantic uncontrolled experiment on the earth. In time, I think, this will appear as the most important aspect of 20th-century history, more so than World War II, the Communist enterprise, the rise of mass literacy, the spread of democracy or the growing emancipation of women."
McNeill's tone will not please liberals, because of his lack of moral outrage. He writes about deforestation with the same dispassion that one might use to describe the 17th-century defenestrations in Prague. And conservatives will not like the content he thus delivers: world economic growth, up 120 times since 1500, has exacted an enormous toll on the earth's crust, atmosphere, water supply, plants, animals and finally on its rogue species, us.
We used 10 times as much energy in the 20th century as in the 1,000 previous years. Before 1900, humans had little impact on earth and rock, compared with oceanic volcanoes, tectonic movements (mountain building) and glaciers. By the 1990's, we had surpassed all of them, moving 42 billion tons of rock and soil per year against 30 billion tons by volcanoes, 14 billion tons by tectonics and only 4.3 billion tons by glaciers. And why not? A single bulldozer operator today has as much power at his control as an Egyptian Pharaoh with all his slaves.
We have lost in one century an amount of topsoil it took 1,000 years to form, and we're running out of clean water. Take the Ogallala Aquifer, an underground river stretching from South Dakota to Texas. In the 30's, when we began using the aquifer for irrigation, it was equal in volume to Lake Huron. Nature took 25,000 years to make the Ogallala. We will sprinkle the remainder away within 20 to 30 years. Joining the assault on the earth is the chain saw, which allows us to cut trees 100 to 1,000 times faster than with axes; without it the clearance of tropical forests might not have happened. (The need for a new football field every second is not a driving factor.)
The author thinks we suffer from "ideological lock-in." Prevailing ideas and politics, from an ecological perspective, have changed little. After 1880 economists took nature out of economics. Robert Solow, the 1987 Nobel Prize winner in economics, claimed "the world can, in effect, get along without natural resources." There is plenty of blame to go around. "While economists ignored nature," McNeill says, "ecologists pretended humankind did not exist."
"Something New Under the Sun" is full of big numbers. I sought help from Michael Sutherland, the director of the Statistical Consulting Center at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst. Sutherland is an expert at detecting fake or misleading statistics, but found no such problem with McNeill's, pointing out that he always identifies his sources and is willing to cite numbers that point in different directions, as often happens in real life. McNeill doesn't attempt to make his statistics dovetail to further a point. Sutherland also applauded McNeill's penchant for not always interpreting the numbers, leaving that responsibility to the reader. He was amazed, however, at the dearth of data on the environment. "We know more about commercial shipping than about the condition of the earth," Sutherland says, "and we have few statistics beyond the U.S."
McNeill tempers his numbers. He points out that while soil erosion appears catastrophic, "more food per capita was available by the end of the 20th century than at any time in human history," thanks to better agricultural technology. And while air pollution killed as many people in the century as the two world wars, he points out that air pollution kills the sick, elderly and very young, while wars kill people in the prime of life -- quite a different matter from social and economic points of view.
This is a book about the collective work of lots of people (the 80 billion people born in the past four million years), but there are entertaining stories, too. There's Thomas Midgley, a chemical engineer who in 1921 figured out that adding lead to gasoline would allow it to burn better. By the 70's most Americans had elevated lead levels in their blood. In 1930-31, Midgley went on to invent Freon, which eats ozone molecules. He eventually contracted polio, and built a system of ropes and pulleys to help him in and out of bed. Midgley, perhaps the most politically incorrect man of the century, strangled himself in the contraption and died suspended in midair.
PRINCESS DIANA and President George Bush notwithstanding, land mines and Saddam Hussein have proved beneficial to the environment. "Iraqi land mines in the Kuwaiti desert kept people out and allowed a resurgence of animal and plant life in the 1990's," McNeill writes. Heinrich Himmler's SS was ecologically correct, too, with plans to establish an enormous wildlife preserve in Europe. The Poles, however, opposed the SS's choice of a site: Poland. An early conservationist, Peter the Great, introduced laws on wildlife conservation, forest preservation, overfishing, soil conservation and water pollution between 1689 and 1725. Catherine the Great, despite her fondness for horses, later rescinded most of these laws. Admirers of Eastern religions will learn that in the 1980's the Ganges was choked by several million tons of ashes per month -- cremated remains of the 30 million Hindus per year who sought post-mortem salvation in the sacred river. German U-boats helped restore marine life in the North Atlantic during World War II by scaring fishermen back into port. McNeill says that humans have done a good job of preserving several species -- those we find delicious.
"Something New Under the Sun" is an original work of history, exhaustively researched and carefully written. The message, however, is not particularly pleasant. McNeill writes that the future is "inherently uncertain" and that "sharp adjustments will be required." The most hopeful statement here comes from James Watt, President Ronald Reagan's secretary of the interior. Nominated by a man who blamed trees for air pollution, Watt said environmentalists were not real Americans and suggested they should be shot. At his Senate confirmation hearings, he said there was no need to worry about the environment. An apocalypse, being prepared by God, Watt told the senators, was imminent.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 5; Column 2; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 838 words

HEADLINE: You Go First. No, You.

BYLINE: By Stephanie Zacharek; Stephanie Zacharek is a staff writer for the online magazine Salon.com.

 BODY:

 Emotionally Weird
 By Kate Atkinson.
 355 pp. New York:
 Picador USA. $25. 
 SOMETIMES it's clear in a novel's first 50 pages that its story is going nowhere fast. But there are other times, and harder cases, when a novelist kicks off a book with such lively, crackling prose and such deft character descriptions that you hang on desperately to the hope that its plot is going somewhere good.
The British writer Kate Atkinson's third novel, "Emotionally Weird" -- her debut, "Behind the Scenes at the Museum," won Britain's Whitbread Prize in 1995 -- keeps hope alive so long that it's a bitter disappointment when everything ends up falling apart. The book's first third is a bustling affair, with Atkinson keeping us happily amused and distracted as she introduces a gleefully polychrome cast of characters, most of them students or teachers at Dundee University circa 1972. Here's how she describes one preternaturally disgruntled literature professor who specializes in the 19th-century novel (fixating on the topic "Why Women Write"): "Maggie Mackenzie's long iron-gray hair began each day anchored or plaited or rolled in a variety of vaguely Victorian styles but by lunchtime it had begun to work its way free of restraints and encumbrances and by midafternoon she had the appearance of someone leading a tribe of ancient Britons into battle, a gnarled warrior queen bearing grudges."
Atkinson has the gift of being able to describe a stereotype (in this case, the 70's-era angry feminist scholar -- the sort that Camille Paglia would later christen "hangdog dowdies") in terms that make you laugh in recognition even as they do more than simply recycle cliches. Many of us have encountered those uptight academic buns, but the idea of their wrenching themselves free of the tyranny of hairpins is a new twist.
But there's a problem with too much clever wordplay and so many enticingly detailed descriptions: they can build you up just to let you down. Atkinson is terrific at setting the stage for her story; she just hasn't given it a very good foundation, and eventually it crumbles away to nothing.
"Emotionally Weird" is really two intertwining stories that make for one gangly comic novel. As the book opens, Effie and her mother, Nora, have sequestered themselves in Nora's large, dank family home off the coast of Scotland, where they've decided to wrap themselves in shawls and blankets and tell each other stories. Effie regales her mother with a semi-surreal adventure about her life as a student at Dundee; her narrative includes an array of oddball teachers, a yellow dog that's hit by a car only to be miraculously brought back to life, and a hapless stoner boyfriend named Bob, for whom the Klingons on "Star Trek" are as real as "the French or the Germans, more real certainly than, say, Luxembourgers." The madcap tale she spins is made even more mysterious by the fact that someone just may be following her, and she has no idea why.
Nora's story is more gothic, more tragic, and it involves a series of secrets about Effie's past. It's darker and more conventional than Effie's story, but it's also more engaging, perhaps because it's much more economical. Effie's story, on the other hand, goes on. And on.
As Effie's tale trundles forward, it becomes more and more apparent that Atkinson is desperately trying to give us a rollicking good time; the harder she tries, the murkier her narrative gets. And she undoes herself by being too clever. At one point Nora interrupts Effie's narrative to ask, mockingly, if a detail that she's just revealed is supposed to be magic realism -- a sly wink from Atkinson that suggests she knows how tiresome that crusty old device can be. But that doesn't stop Atkinson from winking at us again some 100 pages later, when Effie performs a highly unlikely miracle using a scrap of paper and a lighter and then breaks her narrative to tell Nora, "Now that's magic realism." You can mock magic realism or you can punish your readers by subjecting them to it -- but you can't have it both ways.
Atkinson is so good at describing her characters that she introduces altogether too many of them, and many of the better ones don't have much to do. You want more of some (like Olivia, the quiet, intelligent student who's landed herself in an affair with a rakish teacher) and less of others (stoner Bob is mildly entertaining at first but becomes increasingly numbing with every "Star Trek"-related quip he comes out with). In the end, Effie's tale -- and Atkinson's whole novel -- becomes burdened with so many extraneous and forcedly bizarre details that it wobbles off its axis. "Emotionally Weird" is clearly supposed to be a rumination on the bond between mothers and daughters, and Effie's shaggy-dog story is most likely intended as a metaphorical reflection of her emotional state. Too bad it untwirls itself halfway through like poor Maggie Mackenzie's hairdo, and no amount of frantic wrapping and pinning can contain all its stray ends.

HEADLINE: Now You Can Take Your Office to the Gym

BYLINE: By DAPHNE PALMER GEANACOPOULOS 

 BODY:
IT happened while I was working out at my local gym not long ago, warming up on a treadmill and humming a jazzy tune. From the treadmill next to me came the sound of a woman giving a speech about economic policy. I turned to look, and sure enough, a fellow exerciser was reading out loud from a set of 3-by-5 index cards she held firmly while she ran 12-minute miles.
Another time, another song. A man on an adjacent Stairmaster was editing legal articles, scribbling in the margins (and dotting the pages with perspiration) as he listened to music on his headphones. 
 Still another afternoon, a phone rang. It was the Lifecycle next to me. A man wearing a "Just Do It" T-shirt answered his cell phone and gazed up at a ceiling-mounted television tuned to a financial channel. "Sell!" he shouted.
This was beginning to feel like a trend. Eager to learn more, I sought out the man on the Stairmaster and asked him why he had chosen to take his work to his workout.
He turned out to be Ken Anderson, a 44-year-old law professor at American University in Washington, who replied that he was pressed for time, juggling his family, job and five workouts a week. "It's the only way I can justify my time at the gym," he said. "I can't afford to be checked out of the day for two straight hours. It's a time management thing."
Mark Occhipinti, the president of American Fitness Professionals and Associates, a certification and educational organization in Ship Bottom, N.J., confirms that Mr. Anderson has lots of company. "It's a fitness trend of big cities and affluent suburbs, where people need information and are very stressed," Mr. Occhipinti said. "It's a symptom of our time."
Health clubs, once havens for relaxation, have responded to the new demands by providing equipment that enables members to mix efficiency with exercise. Televisions are tuned to the news, courtesy phones are within easy reach, and at some clubs, Netpulse stations (computers providing Internet access) are attached to Lifecycle and Stairmaster machines. They enable members to do work (and earn frequent-flier miles from Netpulse's airline sponsors for every mile they pedal or step), from their gym-desks.
"It's a fact of life that people are busy," said Maeve McCaffrey, a spokeswoman for the International Health, Racquet and Sportsclub Association, a trade group in Boston. "If members need to be productive while they exercise, we are going to do everything we can to make it easier for them to enjoy their time at the gym."
But not everyone is convinced that this is a good idea. "Doing anything while on the treadmill is dangerous," said Dr. Nicholas DiNubile, an orthopedic surgeon in Havertown, Pa., who is an adviser to the President's Council on Physical Fitness and Sports. "Talking on cell phones or reading while exercising can cause nerve strain in the head and neck. Workout form is important."
Multitasking may be an efficient use of gym time, but it compromises the quality of a workout, said Matt Johns, the former director of operations at the Regency Sport and Health Club in McLean, Va. "You still burn calories, but the workout is not the same," he said. "There has to be a mind-body connection."
Dr. David Brown, a behavioral scientist with the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, said that although there was little research on working while working out, "in general, disassociating from the exercise experience, by doing something other than exercise, can lead to risks."
Mr. Occhipinti knows that firsthand: he once saw a man fall and break his arm while reading on a treadmill. But he adds that health clubs are reluctant to reproach their clients. "It's a delicate situation," he said. "You don't want to offend or upset the client. We try to educate them about safety, but people are going to do what they want to do."
Richard Cotton, the chief exercise physiologist for the American Council on Exercise, a nonprofit watchdog organization in San Diego, agreed. "Clubs provide all sorts of equipment -- TV's, Netpulse, E-Zone," he said. "It would be difficult to tell someone not to use it."
Beyond safety, however, is another concern. Despite the lack of research, many experts share the view that people who take their work to their workout are missing a prime benefit of exercise: its ability to reduce stress. "Exercise is one of the few leisure activities for relaxation," Dr. DiNubile said. "Working while working out is a missed opportunity at stress reduction."
But he won't find much sympathy at my health club. "Working while working out is stress-reducing," Mr. Anderson said. "I'm away from my office, the computer, and I'm further ahead in my work. It's a sanity-saving device."

HEADLINE: How to Survive Economy Class

BYLINE: By DAISANN McLANE; DAISANN McLANE writes the Frugal Traveler column.

 BODY:
MANY of the great yoga masters of India spent decades sitting tightly crosslegged in minuscule caves, sustained only by an occasional meager meal slipped into the recesses of their cells. I draw inspiration from these yogis as I sit, hour after hour, strapped into the modern-day equivalent of a bed of nails: the economy class seat.
Usually, the passenger to my front has reclined his seat, forcing me to follow suit to keep my nose from being broken by his head cushion. The "recline" position is murder on the lower back, so I shove a pillow between the seat and the base of my spine. 
 Then there's the dilemma of knees. They bump against the seat pocket (filled to bursting with a thick stack of airline magazines, in-flight shopping catalogs, and entertainment guides for the movie that is being shown on a screen so small, and so far away, I wonder why they didn't pass out binoculars with the headsets). I can feel a wave of pins and needles coming on.
So I slip out my legs, carefully, and extend them, tucking one under the seat in the four-inch space beside my carry-on. I extend the other, discreetly, alongside the aisle. It's a position that's better for blood circulation, but not so good if the beverage cart comes down the aisle while you're napping.
In the last two years, I have flown economy class three times back and forth to Asia, eight times across the Atlantic, twice to California, Florida and the Caribbean, once to South America and once around the world. I've bought my tickets in a variety of ways, through travel agents, through airlines, on Internet sites and through air consolidator-brokers -- and I've found it possible, with a bit of effort, to secure a discounted fare (sometimes an amazingly discounted fare) for all my itineraries.
Although my tickets have been cheap, my flights, in nearly every instance, have been reasonably on time. I've traveled with airlines ranging from Continental to Egypt Air to Lao Aviation, and not once have I been bumped, forced to wait hours in an airport, or been poisoned by the in-flight food. My baggage, which I usually check, rather than carry on (more on this later) has never failed to arrive at its destination when I did (although once, in Brazil, it arrived before me). As far as the basics go, the airlines have delivered.
Cheap, safe and efficient though my economy air travel has been, I cannot recall a time, since my first Allegheny Airlines flight, in 1964, when flying coach class has been less pleasant. I am not talking about frills, now largely jettisoned, like toothbrush kits, menu cards, hot towels and hot meals on every flight over two hours. To get cheaper fares, I'm glad to relinquish such little extras to the folks in business class.
But the Faustian bargain that the economy-class traveler strikes with the airlines is not about frills, but basic human comforts. The discount fares come at the price of personal space, hygiene, breathable air and stress-free boarding and deplaning.
To offer these low fares, most airlines have reconfigured coach class so tightly it makes me wonder whether they consulted behavioral specialists to determine the exact number of centimeters of elbow room human beings will tolerate before breaking out in fist fights with strangers. The air circulation in cabins is often turned down to the minimum level to save fuel -- increasing the possibility of respiratory distress, and transmission of colds and flu. Food, never a strong point, has deteriorated, or shrunk to child-sized portions, or even, on shorter flights, disappeared altogether.
And the same advances in computer technology that have allowed the airlines to offer more last-minute discounts to customers have also enabled them to maximize passenger loads. As recently as a year ago, I could count on being able to snag a seat next to an empty seat at least half of the time. But in the last nine months or so, the empty seats have vanished.
As a result, flying economy class for longer than about three hours at a stretch has become a physical, even emotional, challenge. Because I'm flying economy class so often, I prepare for flying as diligently as I would a race or a rigorous hike. What follows are some of the strategies I've developed to improve my chances of survival in the bean-counting skies.
 
PREPARING FOR FLYING
I've always practiced yoga, but since I started to write the Frugal Traveler column, I've become a fanatic, attending classes three or four times a week when I'm home. There's no better way to cope with waiting in a crowded airline terminal, or shutting out the loud, unpleasant conversation of nearby travelers.
Another way I try to build up my stamina for long trips is with a light program of aerobic exercise, especially the day before I fly. I drink lots of water the day before a flight, and take my personal regimen of B-vitamins and Indian ayurvedic and Chinese herbs to toughen my immune system for those stifling, germ-laden cabins.
When I book my reservation, I also try to make my seat selection. It always feels like a bit of a crapshoot. Ideally, I want to get a seat next to an empty one, or one with a bit more legroom. I used to ask for window seats and bulkheads. But bulkheads nowadays are mainly given over to passengers with children, and window seats are claustrophobic when flights are completely full, which they are more often than not.
And so I usually ask for an aisle seat, in the center rows, which offer a better chance of having an empty seat in the middle than do side rows, and allow me to get up and walk.
 
WHAT TO TAKE
I chuckle when I read in fashion magazines about the various travel kits preferred by supermodels who fly around the world. They're usually the size of a picnic basket and contain "essential" items like blusher that doubles as eye shadow, and five different kinds of moisturizer.
My kit is the size of a pencil case, and contains two pairs of foam earplugs, toothbrush and paste, a nail clipper a sample-size vial of moisturizing eye drops from my doctor that help prevent red eye, and a pillbox with two Sudafed and two Advil tablets, and one five-milligram Valium. The Sudafeds are in case I'm forced to travel with a cold -- to prevent eardrums from painfully stretching on landing. The Advil is for headaches, and the Valium, broken in half, is what puts me to sleep on those 18-hour Asia flights.
After much experimentation with herbal jet-lag remedies, I've found the retro solution of the tranquilizer works best for me. And, yes, I pack a facial moisturizer -- but only one!
Besides my kit, on flights five hours or longer I drag along an inexpensive lightweight Indian shawl (not a Pashmina), an inflatable collapsible neck pillow, and two liter bottles of spring water.
And, if I have time, I pack a lunch -- a really nice one.
 
THE BAGGAGE DILEMMA
For years, I stuffed all my belongings into one carry-on duffel bag, believing the adage that Real Travelers Don't Check Baggage. But in the last year, I've come to believe that that maxim is outdated -- and not because airlines have cracked down on carry-ons.
The problem isn't the airlines, but that ubiquitous air travelers' accessory, the carry-on wheelie suitcase. Personally, I hate them -- they're bulky, make inefficient use of weight and space, and only make sense in airports and cities with paved sidewalks. But everyone else uses these wheeled albatrosses, which make boarding and deplaning an obstacle course fraught with peril.
To secure overhead compartment space, you've got to get on the plane early, which is why there's always an unpleasant stampede at the gates. When the flight arrives, a reverse scramble begins as passengers try to heave their trolleys out without inflicting concussions on each other. I stopped taking my bags on planes when I noticed that the process of unloading a gazillion wheeled suitcases from the overheads took so long that by the time I emerged, the checked bags were already rolling around the carousel.
So far, I've had no problems, and I enjoy being able to walk the ever-increasing distance from security checkpoint to departure gate relatively unencumbered. According to the Federal Department of Transportation's consumer air Web site (www.dot.gov/airconsumer), a fascinating array of statistics on United States airlines that's updated every month (it will tell you, for instance, what percentage of flights left a particular airport on time), baggage complaints among the major carriers are relatively low, on average about 4 per 1,000 bags.
I think those are pretty good odds -- between them and the tiny, colored Brazilian good-luck ribbons that I tie on my luggage to insure positive baggage juju, I'll continue to check my bags. At least until the airlines ban the wheelies.
 
IN-FLIGHT SURVIVAL
It's a jungle up there in economy class, and while I strive to maintain the civility nurtured by many years of flying in the good old days, I've also learned that the skies belong to the quick, the pushy and the vocal. I don't wait for the flight attendant to get me an extra pillow (I always use two, one for back support, one for my head) -- I look for the bin with the extras, and help myself.
If my seat turns out to be next to a passenger with an oversized child in his lap, or my seat is broken in some way, I'll find the head flight attendant and complain, and I've even resorted to standing immobile in the aisle to get attention.
I get up and walk as much as I can, particularly on longer flights. If there's a refueling stop with an option to get off the plane, even for just a half-hour, I take it. Not only does this let me breathe real air but it has also provided me with some unforgettable travel experiences, like being handed a frangipani blossom at 4 a.m. in the Tahiti airport, and shopping for lipstick in the Hong Kong airport after 18 hours with no sleep.
I strive to detach myself from the unpleasant surroundings and elevator-like crowding (earplugs and meditation really help) and concentrate instead on the small pleasures and unexpected surprises that in spite of the bottom line, airline companies (mostly foreign ones) still offer. Like the little terry cloth socks handed out by Japan Airlines (one of my favorite carriers) and Air New Zealand, the amazing Arabic music channels offered on Gulf Air (which also has some of the roomier coach seats around, and terrific food), or the vintage 1930's Malay films shown on Malaysia Airlines.
I adore the new, sharply tailored, red and yellow uniforms of the Cathay Pacific flight attendants, and I was impressed by the hip in-flight entertainment offered by Varig coming back from Brazil: a full-length concert film of Caetano Veloso.
But my favorite indulgence, perhaps the last vestige of the elegant early days of commercial air travel, is offered by Thai Airways to every female passenger as she exits the plane: a fresh orchid corsage.
With fresh flowers, fuzzy socks, good music and an empty aisle in which to practice my yoga stretches, I just may make it through another 100,000 economy-class miles.

HEADLINE: Getting There: A Reality Check

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD; MATTHEW L. WALD reports on aviation for The Times.

 BODY:
AMERICAN AIRLINES runs 699 restaurants, and each has dozens of seats with a really superb view, but in all of them, the food is lousy. United boasts that it has removed a row of seats to make coach passengers more comfortable, but its interior decorating is mediocre at best. Continental shows lots of movies, but the selection (not to mention the sound and the picture quality) is much better at the local cineplex.
How good are the airlines? It depends what you grade them on. Passengers might be forgiven for being confused on this point; after all, they expect to get more than just transportation. An airline customer is different from the customers of most other kinds of companies, being dependent for everything, from a place to sit to pretzels to eat, even air to breathe. Most airlines do not distinguish themselves in any of these categories. 
 But as transportation companies, they have a good product that is selling well. The industry will record more than 600 million domestic passenger "enplanements" this year, a statistic that counts a single passenger walking onto a plane, whether that is the entire trip or one leg. That number has risen sharply in the last few years, far faster than economic growth or population growth, and will grow further in years to come, as plane trips become more common than ship voyages or intercity train rides ever were, and almost as ordinary as long drives in the car. They move their customers at hundreds of miles an hour, day and night, winter and summer, sometimes late but almost always very safely.
And as the system grows, size helps. Collectively, the scheduled carriers move nearly two million people a day in the United States, on about 20,000 flights. As the system gets bigger, each flight is more valuable to the public as a whole, because more people can connect to it.
Still, the perception is that since the federal government deregulated the industry, in 1978, service has declined. Alfred E. Kahn, a professor emeritus of political economy at Cornell University, who was instrumental in deregulation as the last chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board before its demise, says he has heard the argument over and over. It was repeated quite eloquently, he said, in a letter from a business executive who was an acquaintance, complaining about "an unshaven and unwashed hippie" sitting next to him on a recent flight. The executive, Mr. Kahn said, preferred the old days, when he sat next to an empty seat.
Mr. Kahn said he answered the letter like this: "Before responding, I'm waiting to hear from the hippie."
"The market is shifting out there," Mr. Kahn said in a telephone interview. Often the first complaint people had in the years following deregulation, he said, was that the planes were more crowded, often with people who formerly did not fly. But that, he said, was "in a genuine sense, a counterpart of the cheap fares we wanted people to have."
In fact, in the decade before deregulation, planes on average flew just over half full. In the 1990's they broke into the 70 percent range and some are now above 80 percent full.
And that is certain to annoy passengers.
"The airline industry is a victim of its own success," said Clifford Winston, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution who specializes in airlines and other transportation issues. With more traffic, he said, "there is general tension in coach, people fighting for luggage space, and even if the space is there, you've got to climb over someone, and somebody's stuff is there, and you're in the middle row."
The good and bad news is that fares are down, he said: "With lower fares, you find people who couldn't do it before are now on the plane." Those who flew when fares were regulated, and higher, remember when planes were empty and airlines competed with amenities like better meals.
Mr. Winston, in fact, argues that the level of complaints to the government about airline service would be declining, but for the increasing crowding on planes.
There are other reasons, of course. In fact, the airlines are the companies everybody loves to hate. They charge prices many people find reasonable -- unless the traveler has a specific date and time in mind in the near future. When the airline knows the customer has little or no scheduling flexibility, it is merciless, and with sophisticated computer programs, the airlines always seem to know where demand will appear and they can ration supply, to achieve high prices.
Another airline innovation, frequent flier miles, also bothers some people. The miles may be the rubles of the American economy -- a currency that is easier to earn than to spend on anything worthwhile, since free seats are seldom available on popular routes at popular times -- but the strategy has helped make the airline industry a success, so other businesses, like hotel and rental car companies, have followed.
Probably at the top of every traveler's list is safety, a field in which the airlines excel. The Surface Transportation Policy Project, a nonprofit group in Washington that lobbies for help for mass transportation, calculated recently that the fatality rate per billion miles traveled by air carriers was 0.2. Car travel was more than 50 times more dangerous, with 10.5 deaths per billion miles traveled. That means that if you drive 10 miles to take a 300-mile flight, your chance of death is higher in the car than on the plane.
In fact, air travel is safer than every other mode but one, public city buses, which recorded deaths of 0.1 per billion miles traveled. By comparison, Amtrak was 0.5. Walking was somewhere between 147 to 316.
Those statistics give context to occasional catastrophes, like the Alaska Airlines crash off Los Angeles in January, or reports of aircraft parts that may not meet the required specifications.
The airlines are so safe, that you are arguably safer in the air than on the ground. In some years, the biggest cause of death on planes is heart attacks. There are about 60 such deaths a year, but that number will probably fall as the airlines install defibrillators on board. For people at risk of heart attacks, that may make a plane a safer place to sit than their own living rooms.
They are likely to get safer yet, although not through any public policy. The airlines are heavily regulated, but what drives them hardest in directions that are good for passengers -- in everything from flight safety to defibrillators -- is self-interest, not government regulation.
Take the defibrillators, for example. On May 20, President Clinton used his Saturday radio address to announce that the Federal Aviation Administration would propose making the defibrillators mandatory on all planes that carry at least one flight attendant. But most major airlines already have them on most of their planes. A defibrillator pays for itself quickly, they have determined, by reducing the number of times a plane must land for a medical emergency.
In the safety area, the F.A.A. proposes dozens of times a year to require inspection or replacement of a part that has been found to be causing trouble on some airplane somewhere. By the time those orders reach major airlines, they have generally already begun the inspections or replacements, and have often completed them, simply because acting fast reduces the possibility of disrupted operations.
That does not make them timely, of course. Only about three-quarters of planes arrive within 15 minutes of the scheduled time, and in bad months, about one flight in 40 is canceled altogether. There are a variety of reasons, but chief among them is congestion in the sky. Not much of that can be blamed on the airlines. Part of the problem is on the federal level; even the F.A.A. acknowledges that its air traffic control system is antiquated and inadequate. Part is local; in the last 20 years, only one major new airport has opened in the United States, Denver International.
David R. Hinson, a former administrator of the F.A.A., has been traveling the country lately arguing that every major airport should be trying to triple its runway capacity, because it takes so long to double the capacity, even more will be desperately needed by the time that work is done.
The airlines, in fact, don't like delays any more than passengers do. Their crews fear gridlock, too. A story among pilots, with a ring to it that is apocryphal but telling, deals with an airline nightmare called "the death spiral." A pilot brings his plane in very late, taxis to the gate and finds it occupied by another plane. The other plane is ready to push back, but can't because it is waiting for its crew. And who, asks the pilot waiting on the apron, is supposed to be on the plane at the gate? "Well," says the dispatcher, "you are."

HEADLINE: Promises in the Sky

BYLINE: By DAVID LEONHARDT; DAVID LEONHARDT is a business reporter for The New York Times.

 BODY:
ONE year ago this month, the nation's major airlines announced that they would make travel more pleasant by improving customer service. Fearing that Congress was about to pass a bill of rights for passengers in response to the increasing chorus of consumer complaints, airline executives pre-empted the government's plans by coming up with their own list of a dozen promises. They vowed to give travelers information about low fares and flight delays. They said they would make a "reasonable effort" to feed people who were waiting on runways for hours at a time. They promised to explain frequent-flier rules clearly.
"Our customers have just about had it," Leo F. Mullin, the chief executive of Delta Air Lines, said in a speech last year to the Wings Club, an aviation group in New York. It was time, he said, to "restore public confidence." 
 Here is what has happened since then:
Consumer complaints to the Department of Transportation have almost doubled. Virtually every independent measure of customer satisfaction has declined. Lines at airports seem longer, and many travelers say the airlines are not living up to at least some promises.
Welcome, travelers, to the year of restored public confidence. We hope you have enjoyed the trip.
The unfortunate truth is that flying on an airplane today, while the safest way to travel long distances, is as unpleasant for many passengers as it has ever been. The strong economy has sent more planes into the air and kept them nearly full, but airport space, the air-traffic control system and the size of airline staffs have all failed to keep pace.
Following the set of promises, the industry has improved in a number of areas, travel experts say. Airlines respond more quickly to complaints and seem to keep passengers better informed about delays. But the promises have not caused enough improvement to make up for the problems that remain. And because many travelers can cite at least one instance in which the airlines have not followed their own new rules, the industry has managed to raise expectations above the level of service they are providing.
The inspector general of the Department of Transportation, Kenneth M. Mead, is now studying how well the airlines are living up to their promises. As this section went to press early last week, the Senate was awaiting an interim report. The final version is scheduled for December.
Already, however, this much is clear: the airlines vowed to improve service, and few travelers think they have. "People who travel frequently think it's pretty tough out there," said Rustin I. Carpenter, vice president and general manager in Boston at American Express Consulting Services, which advises corporations on managing their travel.
In the American Customer Satisfaction Index produced by the University of Michigan Business School between January and March using telephone interviews, the airlines received lower customer satisfaction scores than any other industry. Their cumulative grade has declined since 1994, the survey's first year. It held steady this year mainly because Northwest Airlines saw its score rebound after it had been hampered by a blizzard last year and a strike in 1998. The scores of most carriers declined.
Other surveys offer similarly grim news. Since 1998, for example, the percentage of Americans who think the airlines do a good job serving their customers has fallen from 78 to 66, according to Harris Interactive, which conducted a telephone survey of 1,024 adults in April. Travelers' frustration has reached the point that on the day last month that biztravel.com announced an offer to give its customers partial or full refunds when a flight on selected airlines arrives late, its Web site received so many visits that it crashed.
A major part of the problem, industry executives and analysts agree, is an overburdened air-traffic system. The number of passengers on domestic carriers grew 40 percent from 1989 to 1999, according to the Air Transport Association, the major carriers' trade group. The traffic has increased delays, especially in the most crowded regions like the Northeast. Meanwhile, tighter security rules force people to spend more time in line as travelers in front of them show identification and answer questions about their bags' contents. "The whole airport process is much worse than it was five years ago," said Michael J. Boyd, president of the Boyd Group, an Evergreen, Colo., aviation consulting company.
Congress recently voted to increase the F.A.A.'s funding by 30 percent, which should help the agency improve air-traffic control technology and alleviate some delays. And the carriers are installing devices in airports that allow passengers who are not checking baggage to print their own boarding passes. Over all, though, few experts expect the crowds and delays to get much better soon. The airlines are unlikely to spend the millions of dollars to enlarge their staffs. And current efforts by government officials and executives to build new runways and airports face the usual resistance from nearby communities.
None of that is new, however. The promises are new, and the crux of them is a commitment to give passengers better information about everything from fares to delays to frequent-flier rewards. Airline executives say they are doing just that. "Delta has absolutely lived up to its promise," Mr. Mullin, the carrier's chief executive, said in a recent interview. The airline, for instance, now responds to consumer complaints in eight days on average, versus about a month last year, according to a spokesman for the airline, John Kennedy.
Some travelers say they see a difference as well. "I've noticed instances where they're saying things clearly and precisely that I'm surprised by and that I don't think I would have heard a couple years ago," said Mr. Carpenter, who flies at least once a week. He added, however, that "I don't think it's moved the needle substantially" from most travelers' perspective. In fact, some of the promises represented little change for the airlines. Two of the plan's 12 parts -- making provisions for passengers with special needs and treating travelers bumped from a flight fairly -- already existed in the airlines' written ticket contracts, and another four represented only a small change, according to an audit by the General Accounting Office, a government agency.
A number of other promises are vague enough to leave the carriers room for fudging. The airlines say they will strive to return lost bags within 24 hours. They also talk of providing "timely and complete information" about frequent-flier restrictions and other details, without saying whether the information will appear in the footnotes of a little-read document or more prominently in a monthly mailing, for example.
The holes in the plans have left the industry's critics and more than a few frequent fliers skeptical that the promises mean much. "Thus far it's a pretty flimsy showing -- lots of public relations and not much substance," said Senator Ron Wyden, Democrat of Oregon, who has pushed for a law that would fine the airlines for breaking their own rules. "The airlines are in denial," he said. "They refuse to acknowledge the seriousness of the problem and the breadth of the problem."
Most damaging of all, many travelers say they can readily cite a recent instance or two in which the airlines have broken one of their promises. That has aggravated the industry's credibility problem and is one reason that complaints to the Department of Transportation have increased so rapidly, travel experts say. (Another is the newfound ease with which travelers can register their complaints, via the Internet or a toll-free phone number.) "I wouldn't assume airlines are any worse than last year," said Terry Trippler, the airline expert for a travel Web site, onetravel.com, speaking of the spike in complaints. "Passengers are just more fed up."
They often have good reason. In late April, Continental Airlines' Flight 1031 was scheduled to leave Newark for Fort Lauderdale at 12:15. With storms over New Jersey, the flight was delayed. First it sat on the runway for about two hours, said William Friedman, a Fair Lawn, N.J., resident who was on the plane with five family members. Then it returned to the gate, and the passengers got off the plane and sat in the area around the gate for about an hour. After another unsuccessful boarding and more hours of sitting on the runway, the plane finally took off at 9 p.m. and arrived in Florida about 13 hours after the passengers had originally boarded.
BUT throughout the ordeal, Mr. Friedman said, Continental fed the passengers only the sandwich it had planned to serve on the flight. The uncertainty of when the plane might depart and the lines in the airport made it impossible for passengers to get food during the brief times they were waiting in the gate area, Mr. Friedman said. Recognizing this, a flight attendant asked for more food to be brought on the plane, but a ground supervisor refused, he said.
"We're not arguing they should have flown the plane in that weather," Mr. Friedman said. "But we went from 11:30 a.m. to midnight with a cheese sandwich. I just felt it was inhumane." It also seems to violate one of Continental's 12 promises, which is to make "every reasonable effort" to provide food to passengers stuck on planes for hours.
In general, the policy applies to planes that are stuck on a runway, not those that return to the gate for a time, according to David Messing, an airline spokesman.
When Mr. Friedman returned home and sent an e-mail to the airline, the response addressed only the delay, not the lack of food. "They either misunderstood the point or purposely evaded what the real issue was," he said. Continental did offer him a $25 voucher, but Mr. Friedman refused it on principle, he said.
In fact, one of travelers' biggest frustrations is the quality of information they get from airlines, in spite of the industry's promises. A Wednesday-night flight last month on American Eagle, a partner of American Airlines, from Ronald Reagan National Airport in Washington to Kennedy Airport, is an example. It was scheduled to arrive at 9:45 p.m. at Gate 40. By 10 p.m., it had not landed, but airport computer screens still showed it as a 9:45 arrival. Agents at Gate 40, working with travelers who were supposed to be on another late flight, said they did not have time to find updated information for the people who had come to meet the plane. American Airlines employees at a nearby gate said they could not help either because American Eagle, and not their airline, operated the flight. Finally, the plane pulled up to the gate at 10:07 -- without the computer screen ever showing it as delayed.
A J. D. Power & Associates survey suggests such anecdotes are more than just the rare exception. The research firm asked travelers in its most recent annual study of the airlines to rate the accuracy of information given at the gate, and the survey found virtually no improvement in the category over last year. Of the airlines rated the top three in communicating with passengers -- Continental, Southwest and TWA -- only Continental did better, said Michael Taylor, J. D. Power's director of travel services.
The gate isn't the only problem area, either. The airlines continue to exaggerate the benefits of some of their travel programs by omitting key information from the documents fliers are most likely to read. Delta's misleading frequent-flier rules are typical. In the main section of its membership guide, Delta says passengers flying economy class on Aeromexico receive Delta miles. There are no asterisks next to the statement. But 20 pages later, the footnotes reveal that passengers flying in fare classes G (for groups) and L (which are specially negotiated) receive no miles. "How does the ordinary person know what that is?" asks Milton Klein, a retired history professor at the University of Tennessee. He was surprised to return from a vacation and not be credited for part of the trip. "Apparently, truth in advertising does not apply."
A similar problem crops up on the mileage statement Delta sends each month to 27 million passengers. It neglects to mention that one of the most popular awards -- a trip to Europe -- cannot be used during the summer on the very days most people would want to use it: Fridays, Saturdays or Sundays. Asked about the problems, Kevin F. Pinto, system manager of SkyMiles, said the company would fix them. It is worth noting, though, that Mr. Klein's complaint led Delta to send him a copy of its rules but not to change them.
The overarching problem is that one year after making their promises, the airlines still seem to lack a basic understanding of how to treat passengers, travel consultants say. The carriers often reply to passengers' letters by restating a policy rather than responding to a specific complaint. Or they install baggage templates halfway between the ticket counter and the gate, forcing travelers whose bags are too big to retrace their steps. As Mr. Boyd, the Colorado aviation consultant, said, "Airlines still want to make passengers do business their way."
 
The 'To Do' List
 
 In June 1999, 14 major United States airlines made a dozen promises to passengers. Here are excerpts from the list issued by the Air Transport Association, the carriers' trade group.
 
Each airline will:
 
Offer the lowest fare available for which the customer is eligible.
Notify customers of known delays, cancellations and diversions.
Make every reasonable effort to return checked bags within 24 hours.
Support an increase in the baggage liability limit (to $2,500 from $1,250).
Allow reservations to be held or canceled for 24 hours.
Issue refunds for eligible tickets within 7 days for credit card purchases and 20 days for cash.
Properly accommodate disabled and special-needs passengers.
Meet customers' essential needs during long on-aircraft delays.
Handle bumped passengers with fairness and consistency.
Disclose cancellation policies, frequent flier rules and cabin configuration.
Ensure good service from code-share partners.
Be more responsive to complaints . . . All written complaints are responded to within 60 days.

HEADLINE: Bedding Down At 35,000 Feet

BYLINE: By PETER H. LEWIS; PETER H. LEWIS covers technology for The Times.

 BODY:
WE are not even off the runway yet, and already a chubby businessman is shuffling along the aisle in his jammies and socks, a contented smile on his face. It is nearly 7 p.m. in New York in the thorax of a Boeing 747 headed for London, and he is headed for bed in the new British Airways flying dormitory for trans-Atlantic business travelers.
There are about 70 of us getting ready to tuck in for the night, 20 in the upstairs loft of the 747, the rest of us downstairs behind the first-class compartment. We each have a snug little pod that converts from a seat to a bed. We have been promised warm milk and cookies as we doze off in New York, and hot tea and breakfast when we wake up before arrival in London. It sounds heavenly. 
 Beginning with a single volley of flights between Kennedy Airport in New York and Heathrow near London, but expanding to all of its long-haul routes by the end of this year, British Airways is the first major airline to equip its business-class cabins with reclining chairs that convert into fully flat six-foot beds.
Although it was not first, Virgin Atlantic also went horizontal last week with flat beds in its Upper Class service, which is a hybrid of first and business classes. The service is currently offered only on selected flights between Dulles near Washington and Heathrow.
Flat beds have been part of first-class airplane travel for several years, at least on long flights across the oceans. But as airlines step up the competition to entice the lucrative business traveler, the flying bed is certain to become one of the more attractive perks -- at a price that could cause most leisure travelers to lose sleep.
My bed, for example, costs $2,986.40 for the night. Even so, I'm guaranteed not to get eight hours of sleep, because the flight from New York to London lasts only seven.
Forget counting sheep; I'm too busy counting dollars.
With very little planning, for example, an economy-class ticket on this same plane costs $564.40, one way. (With a lot of planning, a round-trip fare of just $352 can be found.) Subtracting the element of travel, then, I'm spending nearly $2,500 extra for the possibility of a restful sleep in what British Airways describes as a "lounge in the sky."
Or, more to the point, my employer is spending the money. Airlines long ago recognized that business travelers rarely spend their own money. As a result, the cost of the ticket is often less important than the cushier amenities like food, wine, entertainment and, now, beds.
By some lofty standards, my British Airways business-class sleeper seat may actually be a bargain. Sometime in the next couple of years, according to Sir Richard Branson, founder of Virgin Atlantic, Virgin will "bring the romance back to flying" by offering private cabins with double beds and showers on some of its trans-Atlantic crossings. No pricing has been determined, but one can expect fares to be mile-high.
The beds in first class on this British Airways flight, just a few steps in front of me, go for $4,895.40 (what's with the 40 cents?) one way. The extra $1,909 over business class entitles the elite flier to a cotton sleeper suit, more attentive service, fancier food and wine, more privacy, more space and a bed that is six inches longer than mine.
It is possible, of course, to sleep in a coach-class seat, just as it is possible to sleep behind the wheel of a car or on a bench in a bus station. The most relaxing thing about sleeping in coach is that you are not wasting your entire vacation budget on what is likely to be a few hours of slumber.
But just for the sake of argument, let us attempt the justification that business travelers use: A flying bed allows us to arrive in London well rested at 7 a.m., ready for a day of important meetings. Sleep, after all, is the best defense against jet lag.
British Airways boasts that it enlisted the aid of National Aeronautics and Space Administration scientists in the effort to improve the sleep of its most valued travelers. Among the findings was that people achieve deep, dream-filled sleep only when they are fully reclined 180 degrees -- flat, that is. On a typical business-class seat, in contrast, the maximum angle of repose is about 130 degrees.
The NASA influence is evident from the moment I wedge myself into my cloth-upholstered seat, 18J of business class, on Flight 174. Although not as claustrophobic as the Mercury space capsule mockup I once entered, it clearly reflects the fact that on an airliner, even one as large as a Boeing 747, every inch is precious.
Veteran business travelers know this, and as a result they know about such things as seat pitch. Pitch, defined as the distance between a spot on a seat to the same spot on the seat in front, is 73 inches on these sleeper seats -- at least a foot more, British Airways says, than the pitch of its major competitors' business-class seats and nearly two feet greater than average for all business class.
To fit the maximum number of beds into business class with the minimum loss of privacy, British Airways has arranged the pods in a most peculiar way. There are eight pods in each row, two by the port windows, four in the middle, and two by the starboard windows. All aisle seats face forward. The rest -- the seats closest to the windows, and the center two rows -- face backward. The pods are staggered slightly so that the feet of one passenger are not directly in the adjoining passenger's face. It is the original S-type love-seat configuration, so that when the seats are in their upright position, passengers in adjoining seats are almost thigh to thigh in opposite directions. The two center pods are the only ones in the traditional side-by-side alignment, except that they both face backward.
It is in this love-seat fashion that I meet the gentleman in 18G, facing backward, who greets me by offering any kind of software I want for my laptop computer, free, if I will change seats to enable him to travel with his business partner. "Anything," he says. "Microsoft Office, anything by Adobe, you name it, I've got it." And to prove it, he opens a suitcase crammed full of shiny CD-ROMs.
Declining his offer of bootleg software, I agree to change to an aisle seat opposite.
It is then that the happy-looking businessman pads down the aisle in his jammies. We are not even aloft, and he has already changed into his nightclothes, no small feat given his generous girth. While the seats have been expanded, the lavatories are still about the size of a phone booth.
I DID not think to pack pajamas. People in first class get sleeper suits and a duvet and cover, a flight attendant named Omros tells me, but in business class we get a pair of cotton slipper socks, a sleep mask and a faux cashmere blanket, along with a toiletry kit that includes a toothbrush and toothpaste, a razor and assorted lotions.
I ask Omros if people in first class snore, but this is British Airways, of course, and he is too discreet to answer. Later, another flight attendant confides that snoring is indeed a problem throughout the plane.
Before going to sleep, I examine my pod. It reminds me of an armchair, with a hard plastic cocoon around my shoulders and waist. Around me, I notice that there is no place to put my junk. There is precious little storage space within easy reach, although there is ample storage overhead (business class allows two carry-ons). A small compartment under my knees can hold business papers, but it is hardly deep enough to hold a teddy bear. A reading light on a flexible stalk snakes out from over my left shoulder. There is a "cocktail table," a fold-down tray just large enough to hold the glass of milk and cookie. Beneath that, a power plug for a laptop computer (but it requires an adapter, which fortunately I had bought in advance).
A larger tray, for a meal or a laptop computer, is embedded in the right arm of the cocoon. Everyone seems to have trouble extracting the tray. I break a fingernail.
Under my left elbow is a telephone that doubles as a video game controller. Games are displayed, along with flight information and a selection of movies and television shows, on a small, 8.4-inch video screen that swings out on a swivel arm from the back of my neighbor's cocoon, just to my left. There are 18 channels, including one that shows the plane's current position on a map, and the startling news that it is 70 degrees below zero outside. Built into the cocoon are a pair of Sally Rand-style plastic fans that, when fully raised, afford about as much privacy as Miss Rand's fans did many years ago. That is to say, it is more perceived than real.
It is a snug affair. I am not a large man -- a little over 70 inches tall -- yet I fill every available inch of my bed and then some. I notice that several passengers who appear to be much taller are sleeping reclined but not supine, including a tall, elegant woman facing me from a center seat. Tall people just won't fit on the bed without bending somewhere.
Length is not the only problem. The seats are narrow, and the only way my arms will fit inside the hard cocoon is to jam them against my sides.
I look back at the plump businessman in his pajamas, and he, like many others around me, is sleeping on his side, perhaps because he and they cannot fit otherwise.
I choose to stay on my back, with my arms folded over my chest, but that makes it impossible to banish thoughts of mummies and coffins -- except that I imagine few people would be climbing over my coffin. And that is the major design flaw of the flying dormitory.
The beds are 72 inches long. The seat pitch is 73 inches. So, passengers are literally sleeping head to toe. Because there is only one inch between rows, people who are not on the aisle -- that is, half of business-class passengers -- are trapped in their seats when their neighbors travel to dreamland. The only way to get out to the lavatory is to climb awkwardly over the passenger sleeping on the aisle, or to wake the person and ask him or her to drop the footstool that acts as the bottom foot of the bed. In first class, every sleeper seat is on an aisle, which avoids this problem. (Toward the bulkhead I watch one woman in a skirt manage to hurdle the aisle bed several times in the night with perfect composure.)
Bill Blacker, a businessman from New York City, notes from across the aisle that, conversely, it is equally difficult for the flight crew to serve the inside rows without reaching over the sleeper. He later says he stayed in the fully upright position for the whole trip.
Adam Schwam, a businessman from Westbury, N.Y., who has a window seat, says he slept for most of the flight, but he complains about the hard headrest, the lack of air-conditioning controls, and the cloth seats. He says he prefers the leather seats of American's business class, and knocks the love-seat arrangement. "I feel like I'm on one of those old Coney Island rides," he says.
Still, he says, the beds will probably entice more customers to fly business class.
Mr. Blacker, one seat over, has an epiphany. "I know what it feels like," he says after his night aloft. "It feels like a dentist's chair." Others, pointing out the little metal trays and swivel arms, agree.
In the end, I do manage to snooze an hour or two and awake not feeling the need to visit a chiropractor. At Heathrow, as part of the renovations that include the business-class sleeper seats, British Airways has also spent millions expanding the business-class arrivals lounge, with showers, a workout room and a free breakfast.
But alas, my luggage fails to make it onto the plane in New York. I'm told it will catch up to me when the Concorde arrives that evening. (It actually arrives later that morning.) This gives me time to kill, since the check-in time for most hotels in London is 2 p.m.
Chatting with some of my dormitory comrades in the arrivals lounge, it appears that the bed service is, overall, a popular success. But one experienced trans-Atlantic traveler tells me that he books a London hotel room for the night before, paying a couple of hundred dollars extra to have a room ready for his early morning arrival.
I do the math in preparation for the next time I cross the ocean, spending my own dollars. Budget an extra day, fly economy, endure the relative discomfort of coach for a few hours, forgo a bit of pampering in the air, and save a couple of thousand dollars. Then, pay a few hundred dollars to guarantee a real bed and a few hours of sleep on arrival, and take myself out for a good meal.
With the money I save I could even buy a nightshirt at Harrod's.

HEADLINE: The Way We Live Now: 6-25-00: Questions for Jeff Koons;
Puppy Love

BYLINE: By Deborah Solomon 

 BODY:
Q: So many art stars of the 80's disappeared, but your stock seems to be rising. Who expected to see your giant puppy covered with 60,000 flowers in midtown?
I'm very pleased to see "Puppy" at Rockefeller Center. It really feels like the center of the universe. You have NBC located there, so every day during the "Today" show, "Puppy" is on television. People in Oklahoma or California can see it in bloom. 
 What kind of dog is it?
A West Highland terrier. If I had done a poodle, it would have seemed very feminine. And if I had done a Doberman or a sheep dog, it would have come off as masculine. But a West Highland terrier seems neutral that way, which is good, because I don't want anyone in the audience to feel alienated. It's a very spiritual piece.
Since when did you start sounding like a choirboy? About a decade ago you were married to the Italian porn star Cicciolina and making paintings and sculptures that showed you copulating in every which position.
At that time, I wanted to make a body of work that was romantic in the tradition of Boucher and Fragonard. I don't think I would show those pieces today.
I'm not surprised. For a while, your divorce and custody battle got more attention than your artwork. Is all that settled?
My son and I received tremendous injustice from the Italian government. It's not in the interests of my son that he's in the custody of his mother. For the past six years I've gone to Italy every month to visit my son. I hope "Puppy" is a symbol of the rights of children. The rights of children are neglected.
That's quite a switch for an artist who began his career making consumerist fetish objects like floating basketballs and stainless-steel bunnies. Are you trying to distance yourself from the 80's?
As time goes on, the 80's artists will gain more support. I enjoy Julian Schnabel and David Salle. Andy did great work, too. But visually, I'm more stimulated by advertising than by the art I see in galleries. I like a lot of ice cream advertising. I like a lot of cereal-box advertising.
Are you saying that a box of Frosted Flakes is more compelling than any of the art in the Manhattan galleries?
Yes. Visually, it's just more exciting.
What's your idea of a great cereal box?
I've always enjoyed Cheerios. But all the breakfast-cereal boxes are exciting. The reason is they're trying to pump energy into people in the morning, make people feel good about the day.
Are you really this corny, or is it just a kind of Warholish pose?
I mean it. It's not a mask. So much art is very, very gloomy now. Cereal boxes are just the opposite. Art is obsolete now. New technologies are taking over.
You don't really believe that art is obsolete.
I do. There was a time when Picasso was the wealthiest man in France and Henry Moore was the wealthiest person in England, other than the Queen. There's no such thing as that anymore. Bill Gates and your technology leaders are the ones with money. Artists today -- they're nothing within the landscape of economics.
How, then, have your interests changed?
I think my interests have remained the same. I'm interested in making objects that you would want to grab and take with you if your house was burning down.
You're kidding. Why would I want to grab a 42-foot-tall puppy covered with begonias if my house was on fire?
"Puppy" is a shelter. It's built out of stainless steel. It's like the fuselage of an airplane. You could live inside it.
If it had closets. Didn't you begin your career as a commodities broker who made millions of dollars a year?
I started selling commodities in order to support my art. But all
I ever thought about was art. When I was at Smith Barney, instead of working I'd be speaking with Richard P. Feynman, the Nobel Prize physicist, asking how I could get the basketball to float in the water.
I'm glad to hear you're so involved with your art. You've often said that you let your assistants make your art for you.
I'm looking forward to the day when the flowers on "Puppy" can
be planted without my involvement.
Do you have a dog yourself?
I have a bichon frise. They're nonallergenic. They don't shed. -- Deborah Solomon

HEADLINE: The Way We Live Now: 6-25-00: Economics of Phone Bills;
Please Deposit 72.4 Cents

BYLINE: By Stephen Labaton 

 BODY:
When William E. Kennard can't explain to his wife the complexities of their phone bill, it's time for the telephone companies to make their bills simpler. Kennard is the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission. And that's why he was the one to announce recently that the government and the nation's leading telecoms have agreed both to simplify their bills by clarifying hidden subsidies and to pass on to consumers the savings from reduced access charges that long-distance companies pay to the regional bells.
One reason phone bills have been -- and despite all intentions, are likely to remain -- dauntingly complex is because telephone companies have in effect become great tax collectors, raising money for everything from the Metropolitan Transit Authority in New York to Internet service in inner-city schools. Other complicating factors include the variety of cross-payments between companies for access to equipment and facilities as well as for subsidies to finance service for the disadvantaged and others. Finally, the phone companies operate in a system that encourages them to keep two different sets of books: "For Wall Street, the phone companies want to show they're lean and mean," said Brian Moir, counsel for the International Communications Association, a coalition of businesses that are heavy telephone customers. "For the F.C.C., they want to show they're bleeding on the streets." 
 The government estimates that the typical consumer spends about $69 a month on residential phone charges. Last year Bell Atlantic's New York subsidiary earned revenues of $8.3 billion from both New York customers and other sources, including payments from long-distance companies using Bell Atlantic's telephone lines, advertising revenue from Bell Atlantic's Yellow Pages and payments from the Universal Service Fund to help low-income customers and provide service in areas where telephones are not generally available. The chart at right shows what New Yorkers will be paying to Bell Atlantic (currently in the process of merging with GTE and becoming Verizon Communications) every month starting July 1 and what Bell Atlantic, according to government reports, does with all the money it gets.
 
http://www.nytimes.com

* $7.53 Package of specialized services (call waiting and three-way calling). Individually, caller ID costs $7.99, voice mail $6.23..
 
* $6.60 Dial-tone rate. The charge for basic local service. For every minute of calls outside of the immediate community but still in downstate New York, additional charges depend on the distance of the call.
 
* $4.35 Subscriber line charge. Covers the cost of telephone lines (charge includes the old presubscribed interexchange-carrier charge that a long-distance company pays the local company for borrowing its line to complete a call).
 
* $2.10 Optional monthly maintenance charge to cover the costs of Bell Atlantic repairmen's visits to your home.
 
* 35 cents Universal Service Fund. Supports a nonprofit company under the federal government's supervision that underwrites telephone service to Americans with low incomes, to consumers who live in areas where the costs of providing phone service are high and to schools, libraries and rural health-care providers. The federally mandated charge is eventually returned to Bell Atlantic and other telephone companies that provide universal service.
 
* 35 cents Enhanced 911. The telephone company collects this money for the city or county to pay the cost of 911 emergency service.
 
* 23 cents Portability charge. Pays the expenses that arise when a customer switches phone carriers but keeps the same phone number. The charge is mandatory even if no switch is ever made, the theory being that it encourages consumers to shop for the most competitive provider.
